An experienced English-speaking KE leader

· 
Pokhara-Kathmandu flight fares 
The trip cost does
not include
· 
International flight fares 
· 
Nepal visa
· 
Travel insurance (must cover emergency
air evacuation)
· 
Optional tours
· 
Lunch and dinner in Kathmandu and
Pokhara 
· 
Pure personal nature expenses, e. g. bar
bills (bottled and canned drinks), laundry and telephone bills
· 
Guide and driver tipsThe ImpactThe measurable objectives of this program are to reduce wild harvesting of endangered herbs by 80%. We believe this is an attainable goal because over 99% of Nepali production of the endangered herbs selected for our program are wild-harvested by hand by herb collectors. Training herb collectors how to farm these herbs will allow them to grow these herbs in much greater quantities than they are able to pick in the forest. Thus, we can end the necessity to pick herbs from the forest. Second, we can improve farmer incomes by 300%. 80% of Nepal's workforce are comprised of farmers, half of whom live beneath the poverty line. Many of these farmers live in such remote areas of the country that they must walk for hours to reach the nearest dirt road. Therefore, they lack the capacity to connect effectively with the herb supply chain and as a result are susceptible to exploitation by "herb middlemen." By forming worker cooperatives, Healing Herbs Nepal can cut exploitative middlemen out of the equation and return profits to farmers thereby significantly improving incomes and elevating them out of poverty. Healing Herbs Nepal Team•  Bhupendra Nirajan - Bhupendra is the Nepal coordinator for Healing Herbs Nepal. Bhupendra has over 10 years experience in the field of traditional Nepalese medicine. •  Deepak Prakash Baskota - Mr. Baskota pioneered organic tea production in Nepal and founded the first successful organic tea cooperative in 1984, which today has over 600 members. http://www.organickte.com/?page=show_page&c=50•   Dr. Rishi Ram Koirala - Dr. Rishi is one of Nepal's top Ayurvedic physicians. He is recognized internationally for his extensive expertise in the medicinal herbs of Nepal and in their use for maintaining health and treating disease.      Dr. John Fagan - John is a successful social entrepreneur. He has founded or co-founded several organizations, including Genetic ID, Cert ID, the ProTerra Foundation, and Food Chain Global Advisors, which have contributed significantly to improving the sustainability of the food system globally. He is also co-author of the Reports Roundup and Birth Defects and GMO Myths and Truths.•  Dr. Romy Das - Romy is a professor of Business Management at Maharishi University of Management, USA. Romy is a long-time consultant and holds a PhD in agricultural economics. •  Shane Zisman - Shane is an environmental lawyer and advocate. He holds a J.D. from Vermont Law school and is a long-time environmental advocate.   Other Ways You Can HelpSome people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help:The success of this campaign is directly correlated with our ability to connect with the greatest number of people possible. If you resonate with what Healing Herbs Nepal is trying to accomplish please consider sharing our video with your friends on Facebook, Twitter, and by email.

story:
ELYSIUM ARTISTS FOR THE ARCTIC is a project that combines the expertise of some of the world’s top scientists, artists, and explorers to create a multi-faceted interpretation of the Arctic. Artists for the Arctic hopes to inspire greater appreciation, understanding, and love for this critically important part of our planet, while drawing attention to the impacts of climate change. This icy ecosystem is regarded as one of the most enchanting wilderness regions of our planet, yet volatile and under severe threat from the warming of the world’s climate. This expedition promises to deliver the most awe-inspiring and stunning visual representation ever seen of the Arctic. The sights, sounds, and science captured by the Elysium Team will inspire ways to preserve and protect life at the top of the world through art, education, and outreach. 

The Elysium – Artists for the Arctic is a Save Our Seas Fund project by Ocean Geographic, a society managed by OceanNEnvironment Ltd, a non-governmental charity status organization registered with Environment Australia. OceanGeographic.org 

THE MISSION: The Explorer Team’s mission is to encapsulate the splendor of the Arctic through the sights and sounds of this enthralling region, into one exquisite volume, a film and exhibitions around the world in eight major cities in 2016-2017. Elysium's science team will record and study the impacts of disappearing sea ice in the Arctic, inspiring, educating, and engaging the public about the wonders of the Arctic and its importance to our global climate. Through cross-cultural dialogue and educational outreach programs, Artists for the Arctic aims to exchange knowledge with Inuit groups and Elders about their home and the animals that live there. These first-hand accounts will be broadcast through a series of exhibitions worldwide, global social networks, and media channels, inspiring conservation for the diverse life of the Arctic as well as drawing attention to the impacts of climate change, ocean change, and disappearing sea ice. Only with your support will we be able to spread this critical message around the globe. You can have a direct impact on the way the world sees and understands the Arctic, and consequently on how we protect this precious polar region in the near future.


THE EXPLORERS: To achieve the results we have assembled 60 of the world’s most celebrated artists, explorers, and scientists as principal team members. We are delighted that Sylvia Earle PhD, Michael AW, David Doubilet, Wyland, Susan R. Eaton, Leandro Blanco, Ernie Brooks, Magnus Elander, Johan Ernst Nilson, and Halla Gunnarsdóttir are confirmed as principal team members. 


Sylvia Earle PhD (Chief Explorer/Scientist):  Dr. Earle is a National Geographic Explorer in Residence, recipient of a 2009 TED prize, and founder of Mission Blue. "No ocean, no life. No blue, no green." http://mission-blue.org

Michael AW (Project Founder and Director): Explorer, Conservation Photographer Founder of Elysium Epic, Ocean Geographic, Celebrate the Sea Festival, Asian Geographic.        http://www.michaelaw.com     http://www.elysiumepic.org

David Doubilet (Principal Photographer): National Geographic Photographer. David Doubilet has shot more than 65 stories for National Geographic and has won countless awards solidifying his reputation as an extremely influential force in ocean conservation.  http://www.daviddoubilet.com

Wyland (Official Expedition Artist): Wyland is an accomplished painter, sculptor, photographer, writer, and founder of the nonprofit Wyland Foundation. http://www.wylandfoundation.org 

Leandro Blanco (Principal Film Crew): Leandro has received over 50 international awards for his documentaries and yet others for his acclaimed music scores. http://vimeo.com/leandroblanco

Ernie Brooks (Principal Photographer): Ernie Brooks is the most recognized underwater black and white photographer in the world.  http://www.erniebrooksphotography.com/thephotog...

Johan Ernst Nilson (Principal Explorer): Johan is one of the world’s leading explorers with over 30 expeditions in 142 countries. http://www.johanernst.com

Susan R. Eaton (Geoscientist): Susan is a geologist, geophysicist, journalist, polar snorkeler, and founder of the 2014-2016 Sedna Epic Expedition,  a team of female explorers who intend to snorkel the Northwest Passage, bringing global attention to disappearing sea ice. http://sednaepic.com

Magnus Elander PhD (Naturalist Guide): Magnus is a photographer and writer with publications in National Geographic, BBC Wildlife and many other international magazines. http://www.magnuselander.com

Halla Gunnarsdóttir (Principal Artist): Halla holds a MFA in sculpture and a MBA from the Sorbonne, and currently has an art studio in Sweden.

Check out our website to learn more about the  60  Explorer team


THE VISION: For millennia, a thick layer of sea ice has covered much of the Arctic and Greenland oceans. Serving as a reflective cap on the ocean, the sea ice reflects sunlight back into the atmosphere, insulating polar locales and maintaining lower global temperatures in the process.  Arctic sea ice is our planet’s air conditioning system and has been regulating Earth’s climate for millions of years.

The Arctic is warming, acidifying, and changing faster than any other place on Earth, making its inhabitants incredibly vulnerable and in need of attention. The Elysium Artists for the Arctic project’s diverse artistic interpretation and educational outreach program shall deliver much-needed ocean education, inspiring arctic conservation and education for citizens of the world, especially youths. After the expedition, the Elysium Artists for the Arctic project will have the resources to generate memorable, hands-on learning experiences that can be shared worldwide. 

The Elysium Arctic explorers are each committed to using their expertise to increase worldwide understanding of ocean change as a key element of climate change. The explorers will take on the personal responsibility of achieving that goal by creating an unparalleled artistic portrait and crucial scientific index of the current conditions in the Arctic as climate change begins to take a toll on the region. The explorers hope the fruits of their efforts will bring the plight of this crucial region to the attention of the world, inspire action to fight climate change, yield vital benchmark data for measuring the future effects of Arctic warming, and will comprise a magnificent collection of sights, sounds, and information to be treasured by future generations.

We believe the Arctic can be saved. We truly believe a small group of people can change the world, and this imaging epic must inspire, invigorate, and serve as a call for action to ensure the survival of artic keystone species and ultimately our very own future on planet Earth. If you are a naturalist, scientist, photographer, artist, or musician, consider securing YOUR LEGACY in the Elysium Artists for the Arctic project by using your talent to inspire others to better understand and care for our beautiful blue marble.

“Never doubt that a small group of thoughtful, committed citizens can change the world; indeed, it's the only thing that ever has.” –Margaret Mead

STRATEGIES: Elysium’s professional science team is headed by Mission Blue founder Sylvia Earle PhD and Cabel Davis PhD of the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution. Drs. Earle and Davis and the other science team members will deploy specialized oceanographic equipment including plankton nets, a remotely operated vehicle (ROV),  and the video plankton recorder (VPR) to collect data documenting ocean change in the Arctic. During the expedition, the VPR, sampling nets, and ROV will be deployed several times to collect biological samples as well as capture video and still images.The Elysium’s science team also plans to engage Inuit communities in educational programs aimed at increasing awareness of ocean biodiversity and the impacts of climate change in the Greenlandic Arctic. Aboard the expedition vessel, guests from each community will have the opportunity to see and participate in citizen science in action. 

Susan R. Eaton, the expedition geologist and science journalist, will manage Elysium's “Bringing the Ocean to Eye Level,” an innovative ocean educational outreach program designed to provide Elysium’s Greenland Inuit guests with a platform to share their valued local knowledge and traditions, contributing to a broader body of scientific knowledge about the Arctic. In parallel, Elysium’s artists will interact with their Inuit counterparts, contributing to a cross-cultural exchange that’s focused on the arts and culture. Employing the Elysium’s social networks and media coverage, the Inuit and local peoples will have the opportunity to reach out to people around the globe. 

Elysium's Artistic team is comprised of photographers, cinematographers, musicians, fine artists, and modern artists who are tasked with producing images and sounds of the Arctic in their respective interpretations of this region of immense beauty.

On board the expedition platform or support zodiac, the live feed from the ROV inspection camera will feed directly into a laptop. For observational science the ROV will be capable of moving underneath and around sea ice. Data collected during the expedition will be made available to the OpenROV community, Google Ocean, and WISE (Women in Science and Engineering) and to school children all over the world, including students living in the Arctic. Elysium will connect to the world before, during, and after the expedition via blogs, tweets, videos, media interviews, magazine articles, and other outreach materials.

The 71.61m MV Polar Pioneer also known as the Akademik Schuleykin (Академик Шулейкин), has been specially chartered for this expedition. Built in Finland in 1982 this 71.61m is an ice-strengthened research ship. For the Elysium expedition, this vessel will also be supported by six zodiacs. The Polar Pioneer will be equipped with remote operated vehicles (ROV), video plankton recorder (VPR) plus plankton sampling equipment.

Elysium Artists for the Arctic is a carbon neutral expedition funded by Ocean Geographic Society.

WHAT WE NEED: We need to maximize our time in the Arctic, and what we can accomplish will directly depend on how much money is raised in the next 2 months. Our goal for this campaign is to raise $350,000.  

We projected $80, 000 to bring in specialized scientific equipment: Open source ROVs with HD cameras, temperature and salinity instruments, mobile aquarium and scientist to bring in the video plankton recorder, laboratory and plankton sampling equipment. We'll need $85,000 to create and produce the Elysium limited edition book and movie, $25,000 for the Elysium Arctic Report,  $20,000 to produce the full soundtrack, and $150,000 to transport and curate exhibition for eight cities. 

WHAT WE WILL DO:  Elysium Science - with a specialised scientific team and equipment, the Elysium team will engage an educational outreach program utilizing mobile aquariums and tethered ROVs equipped with HD video cameras and instrumentation, to a couple of isolated Inuit hamlets in northeastern Greenland.

With scientific research capturing data, samples, photographic documentation, an in-depth Elysium Art and Science Expedition Report will be published for distribution to  schools and universities at eight major cities and available for download and shared free of charge.

A fine art limited edition book titled “Artists for the Arctic” will also be produced for collectors and expedition sponsors. This book shall be dedicated to Sir George Hubert Wilkins - the last of the Polar explorer who first discovered that the Arctic and Antarctic as the climate engine of our planet. This benchmark production shall feature images and artwork from the expedition artistic team comprised of some of the world’s most influential conservation artists, musicians, and  photographers. While the expedition report  is designed to educate, this fine art production aims to inspire a greater appreciation of the Arctic and concern about danger of climate change.

Expedition members Eric Bettens (composer) and Alex Rose (Assistant Project Director/violinist) shall compose and perform the original soundtrack music of “Artists for the Arctic.” A CD and electronic version shall be published and released in conjunction with the limited edition book.

A feature length documentary shall also be produced, sharing Elysium's first-hand account of the splendour and plights of the Arctic through the context of the expedition and the perspectives of the explorer members.

In 2016 to 2017, a series of “Artists for the Arctic” exhibition will be launched around the world in eight principal cites: Sydney, Singapore, Shanghai, Manila, Los Angeles, Oslo, London and New York. The Elysium Arctic exhibition is designed as a première for the movie and book to reach out to a greater audience inspiring greater preservation of the polar region and the danger of rising global temperature. 

THE DECLARATION: This declaration affirms that the Elysium Artists for the Arctic Epic Expedition is more than just an exploration event. It is a commitment by the team of explorers to a greater goal beyond the adrenalin rush of a challenging adventure. This Elysium Epic Expedition is a continuation of our ongoing commitment to inspire and enlighten the general public and government decision-makers around the world, and to motivate everyone to take essential actions to restore the health of our planet. Elysium Epic’s Manifesto – A Call for a Change in Attitude Toward Our Oceans.

WHY SHOULD WE CARE ABOUT THE ARCTIC?

1.  Arctic sea ice is our planet’s air conditioning system and has been regulating Earth’s climate for millions of years.

2.  The Arctic Ocean and the seas that surround it are extremely diverse and contain a wide range of unique life.

3.  There are over 1000 species of ice algae, primary producers that inhabit the underside of the sea ice, that form the foundation of the Arctic Ocean food web upon which all other marine life depends.

4.  Many species of fish, birds, and marine mammals are directly dependent upon the presence of arctic sea ice, and consequently a cold enough Arctic, in order to survive.

5.  Indigenous peoples still lead subsistence lifestyles in the Arctic and heavily depend on stable conditions and reliable food sources to maintain their traditional culture.

6.  Climate in the Arctic directly affects weather patterns, storms in particular, all over the planet.

7.  Frozen ground sequesters vast amounts of carbon, all of which will be released as permafrost thaws with warming temperatures.

8.  Subsea permafrost also stores huge amounts of carbon in the form of frozen organic matter that could be released as the Arctic warms.

9.  The Arctic is warming, acidifying, and changing faster than any other place on Earth, making its inhabitants incredibly vulnerable and in need of protection.

10. Unprecedented losses of Arctic sea ice will lead to sea level rise that will inundate coastal areas all over the world, making the Arctic the linchpin in our global climate system. 


GLOBAL WARNING

1.  Average global sea level reached a record high in 2012, 3.5 centimeters above the 1993 to 2010 average.

2.  Arctic ice levels reached record lows in 2012. The six lowest September ice extents have occurred in the last six years, and September 2012 holds the lowest ice extent on record.

3.  2012 brought the world's highest levels of greenhouse gases released by the burning of fossil fuels.

4.  2012 was among the top 10 years on record for the highest global land and surface temperatures since modern data collection began.

5.  Surface temperatures in the Arctic are increasing at a rate about two times faster than the rest of the world.

6.  The amount of carbon dioxide emissions from burning fossil fuels hit new highs; for the first time, in Spring 2012, the atmospheric CO2 concentration exceeded 400 parts per million (ppm) at seven of the 13 Arctic observation sites.

7.  Evidence from lake sediments, tree-rings and ice cores suggest that temperatures in recent decades have been higher than at any time in the past 2,000 years.

8.  The ice that forms over the Arctic sea is shrinking so rapidly that it is predicted to melt away by the summer of 2015.

9.  In the Arctic, precipitation is increasingly falling as rain during the winter months.

10. Due to the unprecedented loss of Arctic sea ice, 2/3 of the world’s polar bear population could be gone by 2050.

CONSEQUENCES -Arctic sea ice is melting so fast that scientists are having a difficult time keeping pace with its disappearance. We must understand the specific processes that are causing this rapid loss of sea ice so that we can better predict the environmental changes that will occur and the ramifications of these transformations for not just the Arctic, but the rest of our planet as well. What we do know without any doubt is that the massive floating ice sheet of the Arctic Ocean is being lost at an increasingly fast pace as a result of anthropogenic climate change.  There is a natural expansion and contraction of Arctic sea ice due to seasonal changes, but with an ever-warming climate, sea ice has been steadily declining in both surface extent and thickness on an annual basis. According to the National Snow and Ice Data Center (NSIDC), 2012 saw the smallest and thinnest ice cover ever reported in the Arctic Ocean, a mere 51% of the average sea ice extent and only 20% of the average volume from 1979. The disappearance of this much ice is particularly disturbing because of the prominent role Arctic sea ice has in regulating Earth’s climate.

Many globally significant populations of animals can be found in the Arctic, including over half of the world's shorebird species, 80% of goose populations, several million reindeer, beluga whales and narwhals. Sea ice is an important element in the Arctic ecosystem for many species, from bacteria and unicellular algae on the underside of the ice to large mammals such as the polar bear and ringed seals. Sea ice is akin to an upside down coral reef; over 1000 species of ice algae that live in direct association with Arctic sea ice require its presence for survival. Ice algae along with some species of sub-ice phytoplankton are essential food sources for many animals and their survival and proliferation are paramount to a healthy food web. Copepods, amphipods, and other lipid-rich herbivorous zooplankton are uniquely adapted to eat these primary producers. All of these co-dependent species will be adversely affected by the loss of sea ice. Many species of animals including seabirds, whales, and Arctic fishes will have trouble keeping themselves fed without a proliferation of these fatty crustaceans and will suffer as populations of ice-associated zooplankton diminish along with the sea ice.

Shrinking sea ice is a major problem for Arctic marine mammals not just because their sources of food will diminish, but because these animals are fundamentally reliant on sea ice for many essential aspects of their lives including hunting, reproducing, and raising their young. The most well-known mammal suffering from the loss of Arctic sea ice is the polar bear. Their primary prey items are ice-dependent seals and with the ice thinning and being absent for more of the year, the polar bears’ hunting season has been shortened. This results in thinner bears, declining reproductive rates, and increasing cub mortality. It is projected that we will lose two-thirds of the world’s polar bears by 2050.

Vanishing sea ice is just the beginning of an imminent climate crisis and is an indication that we need to act now in order to prevent further irreparable damage to our planet. We must act together on a global scale to drastically reduce greenhouse gas emissions quickly and permanently. It is not too late to re imagine our future, but our window of opportunity to incite these critical changes is closing as rapidly as our arctic sea ice is melting.

RISK AND CHALLENGES-In February 2010, a similar group of scientists, explorers, and artists became part of the Elysium Shackelton Antarctic Visual Epic, whereby a team of 57 explorers comprising some of the world's best wildlife photographers, film makers and marine scientists -- David Doubilet, Jennifer Hayes, Emory Kristof, Michael AW, Goran Ehlme, Ernest Brooks II, Amos Nachoum, Wyland, Leandro Blanco, Jenny Ross, Cabell Davis, Steve Nicol, Stuart Ireland, and Jonathan Shackleton (cousin of the legendary Sir Ernest Shackleton) -- embarked on a voyage to Antarctica. The expedition loosely followed the footsteps Sir Ernest Shackleton and his crew travelled after they lost the Endurance in 1915, from the Weddell Sea, across the treacherous Drake Passage to South Georgia. The team captured the splendor of the fauna, terrain, sights and sounds of this enchanting region in a perspective that no one has ever seen before.

The Elysium team documented the current state of this last pristine wilderness: biological samples, photographic and video documentation were captured every step of their journey. Their adventures were revealed on 13th April 2013 - the launch of the multi-faceted movie.

In addition, the finest of the 20,000 images captured were displayed for the first time in an exhibition from April 13 to November 4, 2013 at the Australian National Maritime Museum. As 2014 is the 100th anniversary of Ernest Shackleton’s Trans Antarctic Expedition, the Elysium movie and exhibition will premiere and launch around the world in commemoration of this journey, being featured in Hobart, Singapore, Toronto, New York, Belgium and Hong Kong.

To further commemorate the 100th Anniversary of Shackleton's 1914 heroic Trans Antarctic Expedition, a limited box edition hardcover book featuring exquisite images by the photographers from the Elysium Epic expedition has been released. The book,  "Elysium – Shackleton Antarctic Visual Epic," is dedicated to the legendary Australian photographer Frank Hurley. This pictorial tribute succinctly encapsulates the best of the 2010 photographic epic.

The Antarctic Epic was a huge success and we will continue to promote it and expose people all over the world to the unique beauty of our South Pole. Hopefully with the help of the generous IndieGoGo community, Elysium Arctic will be able to do the same and much more for the North Pole. There are always unforeseen obstacles to overcome while completing an endeavor of this magnitude, but we are confident that with the incredibly capable team we have assembled that any problem can be solved.

inspection camera will feed directly into a laptop. For observational science
the ROV will be capable of moving underneath and around sea ice. Data collected
during the expedition will be made available to the OpenROV community, Google
Ocean, and WISE (Women in Science and Engineering) and to school children all
over the world, including students living in the Arctic. Elysium will connect to
the world before, during, and after the expedition via blogs, tweets, videos,
media interviews, magazine articles, and other outreach materials.
The
71.61m MV Polar Pioneer also known as the Akademik Schuleykin (Академик Шулейкин),
has been specially chartered for this expedition. Built in Finland in 1982 this
71.61m is an ice-strengthened research ship. For the Elysium expedition, this
vessel will also be supported by six zodiacs. The Polar Pioneer will
be equipped with remote operated vehicles (ROV), video plankton recorder
(VPR) plus plankton sampling equipment. 
Elysium Artists for the Arctic is a carbon neutral expedition funded by
Ocean Geographic Society.

WHAT WE NEED: We need to maximize our time in the Arctic, and
what we can accomplish will directly depend on how much money is raised in the
next 2 months. Our goal for this campaign is to raise $350,000.  
We projected $80, 000 to bring in specialized scientific
equipment: Open source ROVs with HD cameras, temperature and salinity instruments,
mobile aquarium and scientist to bring in the video plankton recorder,
laboratory and plankton sampling equipment. We'll need $85,000 to create
and produce the Elysium limited edition book and movie, $25,000 for the Elysium
Arctic Report,  $20,000 to produce the full soundtrack, and $150,000 to
transport and curate exhibition for eight cities. 

WHAT WE WILL DO:  Elysium Science - with a specialised
scientific team and equipment, the Elysium team will engage an educational
outreach program utilizing mobile aquariums and tethered ROVs equipped with HD
video cameras and instrumentation, to a couple of isolated Inuit hamlets in
northeastern Greenland.
With scientific research capturing data, samples,
photographic documentation, an in-depth Elysium Art and Science
Expedition Report will be published for distribution to  schools and
universities at eight major cities and available for download and shared free
of charge.
A fine art limited edition book titled “Artists
for the Arctic” will also be produced for collectors and expedition
sponsors. This book shall be dedicated to Sir George Hubert Wilkins -
the last of the Polar explorer who first discovered that the Arctic and
Antarctic as the climate engine of our planet. This benchmark production shall
feature images and artwork from the expedition artistic team comprised of some
of the world’s most influential conservation artists, musicians, and 
photographers. While the expedition report  is designed to educate, this
fine art production aims to inspire a greater appreciation of the Arctic and
concern about danger of climate change.
Expedition members Eric Bettens (composer) and Alex Rose (Assistant
Project Director/violinist) shall compose and perform the original
soundtrack music of “Artists for the Arctic.” A CD and electronic
version shall be published and released in conjunction with the limited edition
book.
A feature length documentary shall also be
produced, sharing Elysium's first-hand account of the splendour and plights of
the Arctic through the context of the expedition and the perspectives of the
explorer members.
In 2016 to 2017, a series of “Artists for the
Arctic” exhibition will be launched around the world in eight
principal cites: Sydney, Singapore, Shanghai, Manila, Los Angeles,
Oslo, London and New York. The Elysium Arctic exhibition is designed
as a première for the movie and book to reach out to a greater audience
inspiring greater preservation of the polar region and the danger of rising
global temperature. 

THE
DECLARATION: This declaration affirms that the Elysium Artists for the Arctic Epic
Expedition is more than just an exploration event. It is a commitment by the
team of explorers to a greater goal beyond the adrenalin rush of a challenging
adventure. This Elysium Epic Expedition is a continuation of our ongoing
commitment to inspire and enlighten the general public and government
decision-makers around the world, and to motivate everyone to take essential
actions to restore the health of our planet. Elysium Epic’s Manifesto – A
Call for a Change in Attitude Toward Our Oceans.
WHY SHOULD WE CARE ABOUT THE ARCTIC?
1.  Arctic sea ice is our planet’s air conditioning system and has
been regulating Earth’s climate for millions of years.
2.  The Arctic Ocean and the seas that surround it are extremely
diverse and contain a wide range of unique life.
3.  There are over 1000 species of ice algae, primary producers that
inhabit the underside of the sea ice, that form the foundation of the Arctic
Ocean food web upon which all other marine life depends.
4.  Many species of fish, birds, and marine mammals are directly
dependent upon the presence of arctic sea ice, and consequently a cold enough
Arctic, in order to survive.
5.  Indigenous peoples still lead subsistence lifestyles in the
Arctic and heavily depend on stable conditions and reliable food sources to
maintain their traditional culture.
6.  Climate in the Arctic directly affects weather patterns, storms
in particular, all over the planet.
7.  Frozen ground sequesters vast amounts of carbon, all of which
will be released as permafrost thaws with warming temperatures.
8.  Subsea permafrost also stores huge amounts of carbon in the form
of frozen organic matter that could be released as the Arctic warms.
9.  The Arctic is warming, acidifying, and changing faster than any
other place on Earth, making its inhabitants incredibly vulnerable and in need
of protection.
10. Unprecedented losses of Arctic sea ice will lead to sea level rise
that will inundate coastal areas all over the world, making the Arctic the
linchpin in our global climate system. 
GLOBAL WARNING
1.  Average global sea level reached a record high in 2012, 3.5
centimeters above the 1993 to 2010 average.
2.  Arctic ice levels reached record lows in 2012. The six lowest
September ice extents have occurred in the last six years, and September 2012
holds the lowest ice extent on record.
3.  2012 brought the world's highest levels of greenhouse gases
released by the burning of fossil fuels.
4.  2012 was among the top 10 years on record for the highest global
land and surface temperatures since modern data collection began.
5.  Surface temperatures in the Arctic are increasing at a rate
about two times faster than the rest of the world.
6.  The amount of carbon dioxide emissions from burning fossil fuels
hit new highs; for the first time, in Spring 2012, the atmospheric CO2
concentration exceeded 400 parts per million (ppm) at seven of the 13 Arctic
observation sites.
7.  Evidence from lake sediments, tree-rings and ice cores suggest
that temperatures in recent decades have been higher than at any time in the
past 2,000 years.
8.  The ice that forms over the Arctic sea is shrinking so rapidly
that it is predicted to melt away by the summer of 2015.
9.  In the Arctic, precipitation is increasingly falling as rain
during the winter months.
10. Due to the unprecedented loss of Arctic sea ice, 2/3 of the world’s
polar bear population could be gone by 2050.
CONSEQUENCES -Arctic sea ice is melting so fast that scientists are having a difficult
time keeping pace with its disappearance. We must understand the specific
processes that are causing this rapid loss of sea ice so that we can better
predict the environmental changes that will occur and the ramifications of
these transformations for not just the Arctic, but the rest of our planet as
well. What we do know without any doubt is that the massive floating ice sheet
of the Arctic Ocean is being lost at an increasingly fast pace as a result of
anthropogenic climate change.  There is a natural expansion and
contraction of Arctic sea ice due to seasonal changes, but with an ever-warming
climate, sea ice has been steadily declining in both surface extent and
thickness on an annual basis. According to the National Snow and Ice Data
Center (NSIDC), 2012 saw the smallest and thinnest ice cover ever reported in
the Arctic Ocean, a mere 51% of the average sea ice extent and only 20% of the
average volume from 1979. The disappearance of this much ice is particularly
disturbing because of the prominent role Arctic sea ice has in regulating
Earth’s climate.
Many globally significant populations of animals can be found in the
Arctic, including over half of the world's shorebird species, 80% of goose
populations, several million reindeer, beluga whales and narwhals. Sea ice is
an important element in the Arctic ecosystem for many species, from bacteria
and unicellular algae on the underside of the ice to large mammals such as the
polar bear and ringed seals. Sea ice is akin to an upside down coral reef; over
1000 species of ice algae that live in direct association with Arctic sea ice
require its presence for survival. Ice algae along with some species of sub-ice
phytoplankton are essential food sources for many animals and their survival
and proliferation are paramount to a healthy food web. Copepods, amphipods, and
other lipid-rich herbivorous zooplankton are uniquely adapted to eat these
primary producers. All of these co-dependent species will be adversely affected
by the loss of sea ice. Many species of animals including seabirds, whales, and
Arctic fishes will have trouble keeping themselves fed without a proliferation
of these fatty crustaceans and will suffer as populations of ice-associated
zooplankton diminish along with the sea ice.
Shrinking sea ice is a major problem for Arctic marine mammals not just
because their sources of food will diminish, but because these animals are
fundamentally reliant on sea ice for many essential aspects of their lives
including hunting, reproducing, and raising their young. The most well-known
mammal suffering from the loss of Arctic sea ice is the polar bear. Their
primary prey items are ice-dependent seals and with the ice thinning and being
absent for more of the year, the polar bears’ hunting season has been
shortened. This results in thinner bears, declining reproductive rates, and
increasing cub mortality. It is projected that we will lose two-thirds of the
world’s polar bears by 2050.
Vanishing sea ice is just the beginning of an imminent climate crisis and
is an indication that we need to act now in order to prevent further
irreparable damage to our planet. We must act together on a global scale to
drastically reduce greenhouse gas emissions quickly and permanently. It is not
too late to re imagine our future, but our window of opportunity to incite these
critical changes is closing as rapidly as our arctic sea ice is melting.
RISK
AND CHALLENGES-In February 2010, a similar group of scientists, explorers, and artists
became part of the Elysium Shackelton Antarctic Visual Epic, whereby a team of
57 explorers comprising some of the world's best wildlife photographers, film
makers and marine scientists -- David Doubilet, Jennifer Hayes, Emory Kristof,
Michael AW, Goran Ehlme, Ernest Brooks II, Amos Nachoum, Wyland, Leandro
Blanco, Jenny Ross, Cabell Davis, Steve Nicol, Stuart Ireland, and Jonathan
Shackleton (cousin of the legendary Sir Ernest Shackleton) -- embarked on a
voyage to Antarctica. The expedition loosely followed the footsteps Sir Ernest
Shackleton and his crew travelled after they lost the Endurance in 1915, from
the Weddell Sea, across the treacherous Drake Passage to South Georgia. The
team captured the splendor of the fauna, terrain, sights and sounds of this
enchanting region in a perspective that no one has ever seen before.
The Elysium team documented the current state of this last pristine
wilderness: biological samples, photographic and video documentation were
captured every step of their journey. Their adventures were revealed on 13th
April 2013 - the launch of the multi-faceted movie.
In addition, the finest of the 20,000 images captured were displayed for
the first time in an exhibition from April 13 to November 4, 2013 at the
Australian National Maritime Museum. As 2014 is the 100th anniversary of Ernest
Shackleton’s Trans Antarctic Expedition, the Elysium movie and exhibition will
premiere and launch around the world in commemoration of this journey, being
featured in Hobart, Singapore, Toronto, New York, Belgium and Hong Kong.
To further commemorate the 100th Anniversary of Shackleton's 1914 heroic
Trans Antarctic Expedition, a limited box edition hardcover book featuring
exquisite images by the photographers from the Elysium Epic expedition has been
released. The book,  "Elysium – Shackleton Antarctic Visual
Epic," is dedicated to the legendary Australian photographer Frank Hurley.
This pictorial tribute succinctly encapsulates the best of the 2010
photographic epic.
The Antarctic Epic was a huge success and we will continue to promote it
and expose people all over the world to the unique beauty of our South Pole.
Hopefully with the help of the generous IndieGoGo community, Elysium Arctic
will be able to do the same and much more for the North Pole. There are always
unforeseen obstacles to overcome while completing an endeavor of this
magnitude, but we are confident that with the incredibly capable team we have
assembled that any problem can be solved.

story:
UPDATE JULY 19, 2013

The ad was published and appeared in the New York Times page A18 on July 19, 2013. Sincerest thanks to everyone who contributed. Even though we did not meet our goal, we did earn enough to:

1) Publish a press release on July 10, 2013 ($1360 + $195 fee)

2) Publish a 1/8th page New York Times ad on July 19. 2013 ($5580)

Out of the $7628 we raised, our net after Indiegogo platform and credit card fees was $6692.95. 

We exceeded our budget by $442.05, which was covered by one of our team members.

The press release is viewable here:

http://www.cnbc.com/id/100877247

A PDF copy of the ad is available here:

http://files.savetheworldport.org/STWP-NYT-A18.pdf

_____________________________________________

HELP TELL DELTA AIR LINES AND THE PORT AUTHORITY TO STOP DEMOLISHING HISTORY!

For over two years, our campaign has sought to save the iconic Worldport – pushing for the historic flying saucer-shaped terminal to be preserved, restored, re-purposed and operated for revenue-generating aviation or non-aviation public uses. 

We are only asking to save the historic saucer section, whose four-acre roof and less than two-acre footprint take up very little of the 48-acre terminal property. The rear extension of the terminal can still be demolished to provide adequate aircraft staging and parking area as per the existing redevelopment plan!

On June 19, 2013, the National Trust for Historic Preservation gave us our biggest boost yet, placing the Worldport on its list of America’s 11 Most Endangered Historic Places. This was a significant victory for our cause, as the Trust agrees wholeheartedly with our arguments for preservation, which include the following:

  • This magnificent structure is a striking example of Mid-Century Modern design and function that deserves to be saved, restored and re-used – preserving the unique character of JFK International Airport from a bygone era while still serving as a viable airport terminal or for other services.

  • Opened in May 1960 as the home of legendary Pan American World Airways, the Worldport still serves as a showcase for Jet Age International travel – and still embodies the excitement of exploring an ever shrinking world – a purpose which it can easily continue to serve!

  • The structure has seen more than its fair share of history, welcoming historic figures of all stripes: everyone from the Beatles to Martin Luther King Jr. to Winston Churchill has passed underneath its iconic cantilevered roof.

  • As with the TWA Flight Center, the Worldport has served as the visible face of JFK International Airport for many years, and it has been featured in countless movies, television shows, and newspaper and magazine stories. Its loss would mean the permanent alteration of the New York landscape.

WE NEED YOUR HELP FOR THE FINAL PUSH TO PREVENT THE LOSS OF AN IRREPLACEABLE JET AGE ICON!

Even as we mobilize for this final push, the building is fighting for its life. Demolition equipment has been moved to the location, and some exploratory work on abating hazardous materials in the structure has begun to take its toll.

But some of this abatement work on the structure would be needed for a restoration – so the end is not yet here.  There is still some time – but we need as much support and attention as possible to push this campaign over the top and convince Delta Air Lines and the Port Authority that the public wants to see this building stay.

Now is the time to concentrate all efforts and unleash the power of the public’s imagination.

TO THIS END, WE HAVE DECIDED TO RUN A CROWDFUNDING CAMPAIGN WITH THE GOAL OF RAISING SUFFICIENT FUNDS TO PUBLISH AN ILLUSTRATED AD IN THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Given the recent surge in media attention to our cause,  we believe our best approach is to focus solely on drawing additional media and public attention. We believe that the time is right to ride the crest of a growing wave – but we need your help to do it.

  • Our goal is to raise sufficient contributions through crowdfunding to place an illustrated ad in the New York Times, informing the general public of what's happening, and why the building should be saved.

  • The ad will draw attention to the ongoing demolition, and argue that Delta and the Port Authority can find a “better way” that will not only benefit historic preservation, but will provide the airline with a marquis symbol of their presence in the New York area.

  • The ad will urge the general public to take action to contact Delta Air Lines and the Port Authority and tell them to stop further demolition of the building.

  • If our funding goal is exceeded, we will invest in further advertising. If our funding goal is not reached by the end of the fundraising campaign, all contributions will go towards less expensive advertising. And finally - ff we really fall short, under $2500, we will refund your contribution.

As a historic testament of our efforts to save this magnificient building and for preservation efforts around the globe, we will run the ad whether the building stands or falls.

EVEN IF YOU CAN'T CONTRIBUTE, YOU CAN STILL HELP!

Join our campaign via Facebook and Twitter and get involved with letter-writing and social media promotions to help us spread the word! Anytime you reach out to friends, fellow aviation enthusiasts, or even family – you are helping to build the crescendo to preserve this unique and irreplaceable icon.

http://www.SaveTheWorldport.org 

http://www.huffingtonpost.com/helen-davey/a-desperate-plea-to-save-_b_3580367.html

http://www.brandlandusa.com/2013/07/10/delta-has-time-to-save-the-worldport/

http://www.vanityfair.com/online/daily/2013/07/jfk-pan-am-terminal

http://www.SaveTheWorldport.org 
http://www.huffingtonpost.com/helen-davey/a-desperate-plea-to-save-_b_3580367.html
http://www.brandlandusa.com/2013/07/10/delta-has-time-to-save-the-worldport/

story:
Our Story

We at PlasticNotSoFantastic are one of the only global plastic pollution campaigns which focus on land based plastic pollution, rather than marine based plastic pollution.  

Shown above is the post mortem room at the Central Veterinary Research Laboratory (“CVRL”) in Dubai, where Dr. Dr. habil Ulrich Wernery (Dr. Ulli), is the Scientific Director (pictured).

He is holding an accumulation of rope and plastic in his right hand and a gastriclith (gastric meaning relating to the stomach, and lith meaning stone) is his left hand.  Both were extracted from the remains of the camel laid out on the operating table behind him.

The jumbled mass of plastic and rope is a precursor to the gastriclith, which takes time to calcify in the animal’s stomach, eventually resulting in the animal starving to death.  Dr. Ulli has found gastricliths weighing up to 58 kilograms.

Finding such accumulations of plastic waste in the digestive systems of animals on which he operates is unfortunately no longer an unusual occurrence.  As a result, Dr. Ulli coined the term “Fatal Pollution” to describe this type of pollution, which is primarily plastic based, and we founded the PlasticNotSoFantastic (PNSF) campaign in order to spread the Fatal Pollution message to the widest possible audience.

Why does it matter?

While the ingestion of pure plastic is relatively harmless from a toxicity perspective, as shown above, the accumulation of plastic waste in an animal’s stomach has fatal consequences.  The death of productive animals, such as goats, cows and camels, has an immediate economic impact for the owner and the community.

Furthermore, there are a vast range of chemicals which are added to plastics, in order to achieve malleability, temperature resistance, texture and colour changes.  These chemicals can leach from the plastic into the consuming animal.  It is for this reason that plastic pollution is fatal not only to the animals which directly forage on the plastic waste, but also for us humans who consume the meat and milk from contaminated animals.

Spreading the word

Our passion is the great outdoors. We love to discover new places, but unfortunately we have encountered all too often the destructive effects of plastic pollution in the most remote corners of the globe.

Thus the idea came to combine the two – a great journey with a great cause. The PlasticNotSoFantastic Expedition was born… 

The PNSF Expedition is a global road trip, with Stage 1 stretching from the United Arab Emirates to Norway and back again.  We will be leaving the UAE on the 24th April 2012 and intend to return to the UAE at the end of September 2012.

The PNSF campaign is endorsed by UNESCO Arab Region, the Plastic Pollution Coalition, the Emirates Marine Environmental Group, Project Kaisei, Tangaroa Blue, Ocean Voyages Institute, Plastic Oceans and Goumbook.  

Join us in our quest to: explore – encounter – investigate – learn – ACT!

What We Need 

The PNSF Expedition is primarily privately funded.  Our budget for the Expedition has had to include costs such as car insurance (USD 3,000), Carnet de Passage (deposit of USD 18,000), ferries and visas (USD 2,500), private health insurance and numerous other small and large expenses.    Fuel will also be a big cost element in Europe, and we will therefore be converting the car to run on Liquified Petroleum Gas (LPG) as well as normal petrol.  This will cost us in the region of USD 3,500.  We will be camping in our roof top tent wherever possible and therefore we can save on hotel bills.

However, we have limited private resources, and we are therefore offering corporate sponsorship opportunities.  We are also in need of photographic and audio visual equipment, with which we intend to more effectively document instances of plastic pollution on our route.  We will be undertaking regular presentations, seminars and workshops at schools, universities and Rotary Clubs and therefore a projector would also be helpful.

Camcorder such as the JVC GY-HM100U (USD 2,995), Sony's HXR-MC2000U (USD 1,699) or Sony's HVR-Z7U (USD 5,999)

Lavalier microphone such as Sony's UWPV1/4244 (USD 575)

Camera support (tripod / monopod / harness) auch as Sony's VCT-SP1BP  (USD 845)

Extra batteries x 4 (USD 200 approx)

Tough external hard drive / recording media such as the Hitachi Simple Tough x 4 (USD 100)

MiniDV tapes x 20 (USD 10 per pack)

Pelican case (USD 150)

Projector such as Epson Megaplex MG-850HD WXGA (USD 580), NEC NP M300W WXGA (USD 800) or View Sonic PJD 5123 SVGA (USD 320).

The data we gather will be placed on the World Waste Map - a global initiative run by Let's Do It World to map illegally dumped waste.  Our data can later be used as a resource to arrange local cleanups.  

We also intend to produce a photographic collage of the Expedition, which we will use in our almost daily school events in the UAE.

The photographs, interviews and data collected will also be provided to our various endorsers, who may then use the material in further raising awareness of the issues surrounding plastic pollution.  

Other Ways You Can Help

You can help us by liking us on Facebook and following us on Twitter.  Please visit our website, and let us know of any instances of plastic waste pollution, cleanups, or anything else that you think might be of interest for us on our route.

Join us in our quest to: explore – encounter – investigate – learn – ACT!



What We Need 
The PNSF Expedition is primarily privately funded.  Our budget for the Expedition has had to include costs such as car insurance (USD 3,000), Carnet de Passage (deposit of USD 18,000), ferries and visas (USD 2,500), private health insurance and numerous other small and large expenses.    Fuel will also be a big cost element in Europe, and we will therefore be converting the car to run on Liquified Petroleum Gas (LPG) as well as normal petrol.  This will cost us in the region of USD 3,500.  We will be camping in our roof top tent wherever possible and therefore we can save on hotel bills.
However, we have limited private resources, and we are therefore offering corporate sponsorship opportunities.  We are also in need of photographic and audio visual equipment, with which we intend to more effectively document instances of plastic pollution on our route.  We will be undertaking regular presentations, seminars and workshops at schools, universities and Rotary Clubs and therefore a projector would also be helpful.
Camcorder such as the JVC GY-HM100U (USD 2,995), Sony's HXR-MC2000U (USD 1,699) or Sony's HVR-Z7U (USD 5,999)
Lavalier microphone such as Sony's UWPV1/4244 (USD 575)
Camera support (tripod / monopod / harness) auch as Sony's VCT-SP1BP  (USD 845)
Extra batteries x 4 (USD 200 approx)
Tough external hard drive / recording media such as the Hitachi Simple Tough x 4 (USD 100)
MiniDV tapes x 20 (USD 10 per pack)
Pelican case (USD 150)
Projector such as Epson Megaplex MG-850HD WXGA (USD 580), NEC NP M300W WXGA (USD 800) or View Sonic PJD 5123 SVGA (USD 320).
The data we gather will be placed on the World Waste Map - a global initiative run by Let's Do It World to map illegally dumped waste.  Our data can later be used as a resource to arrange local cleanups.  
We also intend to produce a photographic collage of the Expedition, which we will use in our almost daily school events in the UAE.
The photographs, interviews and data collected will also be provided to our various endorsers, who may then use the material in further raising awareness of the issues surrounding plastic pollution.  


Other Ways You Can Help
You can help us by liking us on Facebook and following us on Twitter.  Please visit our website, and let us know of any instances of plastic waste pollution, cleanups, or anything else that you think might be of interest for us on our route.

story:
Our Story

Earth Day SF is a dynamic new, free, family friendly and fun event which will take place Saturday, April 23rd outdoors at the Civic Center Plaza in downtown San Francisco.  Showcasing the savviest eco speakers, the coolest conscious eco vendors, awesome green movies, organic food, stellar music and dance performances on several stages, the event also features a wide variety of hands-on workshops where you can connect with inspired leaders in the fields of sustainable living, social media, youth empowerment, peace, permaculture, raw food, holistic wellness and much much more.

This entire event is designed to assist YOU and the larger Bay Area community to connect — share — learn — and express your own desires for co-creating a sustainable, regenerative future for our children, grandchildren and beyond.

The Impact

Together, we are solutions in action! 

WHERE WE ARE:

Clearly we are at a crucial juncture in our planet's history where our collective response-ability is to galvanize information, energy, resources and action steps to co-create the solutions and the change we desire, and which future generations depend on. Challenges face us on every front: environmental, ecological, health, economic, social, organizational...

VISION:

Our conscious collective desires to cultivate a healthy, balanced biosphere, a positive, regenerative economy, clean oceans, clean fuel, clean air, safe healthy food, soil and seeds, healthy people, and responsible corporations and businesses who care about the planet, her creatures and people...

We see and stand for a future brightened by a conscious, enlightened humanity, where resources of our beautiful earth are shared fairly caring for the needs of all creatures. We see clean rivers and oceans, clean air, pollution-free commerce and trade, an organically grown economy, plenty of healthy, gmo-free organic food for everyone, and a society based on love, trust and harmony.

Won't you join us in setting this vision further into manifestation?


What We Need & What You Get

WHAT WE NEED:

This all-volunteer production of a free public event is a co-creation of about 20 individuals and groups.  These people and organizations have come together to launch this amazing educational and community service event,  envisioning the production of more consciousness raising events in the months and years to come. 

While we are offering spaces for sponsors and vendors, we are still needing some additional funds to make the event the very best it can be.

In an effort to bring you the very best show, we are asking for donations, large and small.

We are asking you, our friends of the Earth and event supporters, to donate what you can and to spread the word so others can help support the event too. Any amount will help! We have decided to set a goal of $20,000 that can be accomplished by just 1000 supporters giving $20 each!   And you can get your name mentioned as a supporter, as well as a free gift too!


The funds received will go towards bottom line production costs. If we exceed our total, we have no shortage of expenses, and we are hoping to build our funding for next year so we are not starting from scratch. Even if we do not reach our goal, all the money gifted to Earth Day SF will be used toward the many costs associated with running such a large, free, public event. Licenses, permits, tents, stages, equipment, rentals, material items for presentations..... all these items and more add up! We are grateful for your assistance.


WHAT YOU GET:

$10 or more—your name on our website sponsor page

$25 or more—an Earth Day SF T-Shirt that you can pick up at the event information table, your name on our website sponsor page!

$50 or more—a Klean Kanteen drinking bottle (while supplies last—50 Earth Day SF branded bottles are available) plus, you'll receive an Earth Day SF T-Shirt that you can pick up at the event information table, your name on our website sponsor page!

$100 or more—a VIP Backstage Pass, a Klean Kanteen drinking bottle (while supplies last—50 Earth Day SF branded bottles are available), a free ticket to our After Party at Temple SF, an Earth Day SF T-Shirt that you can pick up at the event information table and your name on our website sponsor page

$500 or more—a set of free food passes redeemable at our healthy food vendors, a VIP Eco-Goodie Bag, a Klean Kanteen drinking bottle (while supplies last—50 Earth Day SF branded bottles are available), a free ticket to our After Party, an Earth Day SF T-Shirt that you can pick up at the event information table and your name on our website sponsor page

$1000 or more—your photograph and name [if desired] on our site as a Key Sponsor, a set of free food passes redeemable at our healthy food vendors, a free ticket to our After Party at Temple Night Club, a VIP Eco-Goodie Bag, your logo on the front of our site, a VIP Backstage Pass, a Klean Kanteen drinking bottle (while supplies last—50 Earth Day SF branded bottles are available), an Earth Day SF T-Shirt that you can pick up at the event information table


Other Ways You Can Help

Make some noise! Shout it out! Help us spread the word and get this free public event launched, in service to people and planet! Thank you!


Please share this opportunity to assist Earth Day SF with your friends, family and associates, your facebook and twitter fans, and conscious community organizations. Together, we are solutions in action!


If you'd like to volunteer at the event, purchase a booth, or become an official event sponsor, please visit our website.

Please share this opportunity to assist Earth Day SF with your friends, family and associates, your facebook and twitter fans, and conscious community organizations. Together, we are solutions in action!

If you'd like to volunteer at the event, purchase a booth, or become an official event sponsor, please visit our website.

story:
About ShaleTest and FLIR Videography

ShaleTest is a non-profit organization that provides FLIR video and environmental testing to families and communities who are negatively impacted by shale oil and gas extraction. The FLIR camera detects and visualizes harmful gases quickly from a safe distance and in real time. FLIR technology has been a game-changer in the fight to protect our environment from dangerous impacts of shale oil and gas development. 

  • Based on the extraordinary need for this type of testing, the Earthworks organization agreed to act as ShaleTest’s fiscal sponsor. Earthworks is a non-profit organization dedicated to protecting communities and the environment of irresponsible mineral and energy development while seeking sustainable solutions.

Frank Finan is our chief FLIR Videographer on the Marcellus Shale. He volunteers for ShaleTest and accepts no fees for his services. As demonstrated by this video, Frank's videography and contributions to ShaleTest are extremely valuable and have helped hundreds of individuals. 

Frank's FLIR Camera Needs Repair

The estimated cost for repair is between $20,000 - $25,000

  • We appreciate Frank's hard work and dedication. To show that appreciation we would like to give him at least 10% of those costs, or more if possible, so we can get him back in the field protecting the environment and individuals like you! Insurance will cover some of the cost but the rest is out of pocket for Frank. 
  • Everyone deserves clean air and the sooner we can get Frank's FLIR camera fixed, the sooner we can get him back in the field protecting those in need.
  • All the money raised from this campaign will go towards repairing Frank's FLIR Camera.

Toxic pollution from shale oil and gas drilling and production are real and our use of FLIR videography is of benefit to all citizens, scientists and grassroots organizations.

Public health, safety and environmental justices are basic human rights. Our goal with ShaleTest is to bolster these rights through responsible and informed scientific testing, discloser and transparency.

  • These FLIR videos are used for education, research and community outreach.
  • The findings stand in strong contrast to statements made by industry representatives and policymakers seeking to expand drilling by dismissing these claims of health impacts as personal anecdotes and isolated incidents.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute we understand, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help:

  • Spread the word about negative impacts of shale oil and gas development.
  • Volunteer for local environmental groups
  • Of course, we all need to reduce our carbon footprint – simply reduce, reuse and recycle. Use less plastic and rely on wind and solar as much as possible!

story:
Hi. I’m Brian, and I’m an electric vehicle owner. 

I’ve driven over 25,000 miles without ever once stopping for gas, and I’ve learned a lot in the process. 

I want to tell you my story...I think it will change the way you think about driving.


My campaign is about exposing the myths of electric vehicle use. I want to show people what electric vehicles can do--because seeing is believing. 

As Yogi Berra said, "You can observe a lot by just watching."

To me, it’s a shame that so few of us take advantage of such an easy way to reduce the impact we have on the world we live in. But doing things differently starts with thinking differently.


The Union of Concerned Scientists, on electric vehicles


Let me give you a short synopsis of my project…

On Monday, August 24th, I will depart from my hometown of Albion, New York on a one-hundred day, 26,219 mile all-American road trip in a base model Nissan Leaf. The equivalent of 1,000 marathons in 100 days.

In a car with an EPA-estimated range of just 84 miles.

With your help, I’ll be planting trees in each of the 48 states I stop. The same way John Chapman did back in 1800. One tree at a time, one step at a time.




Nothing worth doing gets done until someone decides to do it. Unfortunately, that usually means someone stopping whatever it is they’re already doing. 


This time, it doesn’t have to.


I’ve already driven 25,000 green miles. 


This time I’ve just planned a different route…and I’m bringing a shovel.


My campaign will be both strictly budgeted and 100% transparent.

Every dollar pledged to this project will help reduce carbon pollution. Every dollar will be spent toward planting good-quality, hardy, long-lived, climate-appropriate trees.

  • There will be no money spent for sightseeing (it’s not about the destinations, it’s about the journey.)
  • There will be no money spent for accommodations (just a tent, a sleeping bag, and a whole lot of stars.)
  • There will be no money spent for advertising (but I’ll need you to talk about it.)

...just tell one person then follow the blog here: Negative Carbon roadtrip

I'll chronicle the daily victories of the trip—as well as the inevitable setbacks. This is your shotgun ticket to emission-free driving without the range anxiety of a long uphill climb in the wilderness with no outlet plugs in sight.


Could we all be driving electric cars? Maybe—but it won’t happen until people really believe they’re a viable means of getting around.


They are, and I’m going to prove it.

On Wednesday, August 26th, help get us ‘over the hump’ of misconceptions about electric vehicles. Let’s finally decide that every mile we go on petroleum is another mile we’ve gone too far. It's all downhill from here!


What I Need & What You’ll Get

I’m targeting $2500—about enough to buy and ship about 48 strong and healthy trees. Each will be carefully selected based on region, soil, and growing conditions.

They will be shipped to locations along the trip route, which will eliminate transport issues and ensure they’re as fresh as they can be when planted. I’ll be coordinating the delivery addresses with the help of my backers (more on that below.)

Where possible, I will be sourcing the trees from The Arbor Day Foundation, a reputable 501C-3 organization you can find here: 

The Arbor Day Foundation

I have planned the route to take full advantage of seasonal temperature fluctuations and the existing electric vehicle charging infrastructure--which in some cases means 30 or 50 AMP RV service locations. In some of the most desolate places, I'll still need to use regular outlets to 'trickle charge.' This is where you may be able to help me.

The unique nature of my project offers me the chance to meet with many of my supporters in the U.S. In the most remote locations, I may need a place to plug in--otherwise be forced to drive a long distance out of the way.

The route I've chosen takes me through virtually all of the most populous areas of the lower 48 States. I estimate that it will take me within about 25 miles of 95% of the country's population. 

I would welcome the opportunity to sit down for a coffee or a bite to eat with anyone who chances to find this project and happens to be nearby as I'm passing through.


I would also welcome help in the way of tentative send-to addresses for trees.

This project is happening very fast, and has been difficult to coordinate--in terms of dates, times, stops, and people. The logistics of averaging 262.2 miles per day in a car that can only go about a third of that on a charge for 100 days straight...well, let's just say they're challenging.


Thanks for all the support I've received so far, and all the support that's yet to come! With any luck, we'll remove about 100 tons of carbon dioxide from the atmosphere with this project. It will take the trees a while--trees work a lot more slowly than we do.


Some interesting links:




Global warming is not a hoax (Canada)

The Complete Idiot's Guide to Deforestation

...and finally, if Elon can do it:

story:
Micro-plastics are the oceans deadliest predator. These tiny pieces of plastic are in every ocean on the planet. Most marine animals confuse it with plankton, the base of our food chain, poisoning EVERYTHING including us.


Source: http://newswatch.nationalgeographic.com/files/2013/04/MicroplasticsPenny-as-Smart-Object-1.jpeg


HELP MICRO PLASTIC STUDIES

These 5 Gyers are said to be SWAMPED with micro-plastics.



I need money to buy these nets


Using GIS (map making software) and Remote Sensing (satellite imagery) and modified plankton nets, I plan to count and map micro-plastic contents.

- Email: seanlynch@umail.ucc.ie

- LinkedIn: http://www.linkedin.com/profile/view?id=281319345&trk=nav_responsive_tab_profile
If you would like to see some of my work experience and interests, you can check me up on LinkedIn.

Micro-plastic is part of the wider marine litter problem.


The mighty Albatross. One of many species that confuse plastic for food, slowing them down and starving them to death. Source: Google Images

Just as this bird confuses plastic with food, smaller animals consume micro-plastic even with the smallest of organisms.


Did you know even your toothpaste and facewash contain micro plastics?


Left finger: Micro-Plastic that is put in face-wash and toothpaste:Right finger: Sand


Comparing Micro-beads in facial cleaner to Sand-Grains. Animals like this isopod eat sand-sized foods. Larger animals eat isopods and micro-plastic travels up the food chain. Source: http://1.bp.blogspot.com/_WqeebKHnx54/S7kLDglnF7I/AAAAAAAAAFs/CLHbH2sAnGw/s1600/photo+detail+of+microplastic.jpg

http://5gyres.org/wp-content/themes/5gyres_theme/images/Campaigns/MicroBead/Slide32.jpg

All of these products contain micro-plastic


If you're not already familiar with micro-plastic, please watch these videos:

and read one of many papers about the products you use that you probably didn't know pollute the ocean DAILY:
http://5gyres.org/media/5_Gyres_Position_Paper_on_Microplastics.pdf


I will need:


1. At least ONE Micro-Plastic and Plankton Filter Feeder
Nets are €1000 each + additional + spare parts = €2,000
Two would mean mean I can train someone to bring it to another part of the world.


This is a 'Manta-Net' used by NOAA which is a modification of a Neuston-Net. Source: http://oceanexplorer.noaa.gov/okeanos/explorations/ex1006/background/summary/media/manta_net_600.jpg adapted and sold by http://www.sea-gear.net/neuston-nets.html


Your money will be pooled to support environmentally-supportive industries.
I will train divers to use these tools who will hopefully buy more!


2. I need to use an underwater video recording camera (can be rented)


6 weeks rent: about €200
Buy new and share with other scientists: €500+


3. In addition to a recording device, I will also need mapping equipment. These will include various types of ropes, measuring lines and other survey equipment to the value of about €200 - €300 or more

4. Open-Source Underwater Remotely Operated Vehicle.
see www.openrov.com
ONLY €650!!!
With enough funding, I would be able to purchase an open-source underwater ROV. I have ideas to take it into some of Ireland's lakes. If I get the money for this, I will donate the robot to UCC.

5. Satellite Data.
If I get enough funding, my options will open up beyond my wildest dreams!
Did you know that we all have free access to Landsat data? Landsat is an American Satellite that has been continuously recording environmental data from the 1970s that is entirely free to download at landsat.usgs.gov


The Impact



    

                                LESS OF THIS


Supporting this project is a way to pool resources to strengthen environmentally active industries such as www.sea-gear.net and other supportive businesses in Thailand such as Big Blue and others along the way.

Supporting me is also a way to strengthen my ability to articulate my concerns about these environmental threats with modern spatial, marine and satellite resources.

You are supporting independent science and education. I want to educate people with my research and educate myself about how to recontribute to these communities. I want to teach people modern skills with open-source technologies.

A big thank you to Big Blue Diving who have been very keen on this project from the beginning. This project would absolutely not have been possible without them and they have put many resources in place that has allowed this project to come into fruition. Big Blue have done wonders over the years to educate 10,000s of people about the values of coral reefs and their team have played a significant role in inspiring this project. http://www.bigbluediving.com/



Other Ways You Can Help


If you can't afford to fund this campaign,


You can still be a massive asset to this campaign


Help increase awareness of this project.

Please share it widely across all forms of social media.

Email it to everyone in your contact list.

Print it out and stick it on your college / work noticeboard.

Start a fundraiser at work.

Think about how much plastic you can see right now.

Imagine what's in the ocean.

How can you decrease your plastic consumption today?

What about tomorrow?

Think about what businesses you support the next time you're doing some shopping.

Google Micro Plastic.

Look around and see who is making an effort in the world. How can you support?

Educate yourself about how you can lower your plastic consumption.


Additional Info

http://5gyres.org/

http://5gyres.org/how_to_get_involved/campaigns/

http://marinedebris.noaa.gov/sites/default/files/Gen_Plastic-hi_9-20-11_1.pdf

Got Doge? DCrjzrMxUqFQViTqicmRJvHyrnitF7Dgvj
story_txt:
Micro-plastics are the oceans deadliest predator. These tiny pieces of plastic are in every ocean on the planet. Most marine animals confuse it with plankton, the base of our food chain, poisoning EVERYTHING including us.
Source: http://newswatch.nationalgeographic.com/files/2013/04/MicroplasticsPenny-as-Smart-Object-1.jpegHELP MICRO PLASTIC STUDIES
These 5 Gyers are said to be SWAMPED with micro-plastics.I need money to buy these netsUsing GIS (map making software) and Remote 
Sensing (satellite imagery) and modified plankton nets, I plan to count 
and map micro-plastic contents.- Email: seanlynch@umail.ucc.ie- LinkedIn: http://www.linkedin.com/profile/view?id=281319345&trk=nav_responsive_tab_profileIf you would like to see some of my work experience and interests, you can check me up on LinkedIn.Micro-plastic is part of the wider marine litter problem.The mighty Albatross. One of many species that confuse plastic for food, slowing them down and starving them to death. Source: Google ImagesJust as this bird confuses plastic with food, smaller animals consume micro-plastic even with the smallest of organisms. 
Did you know even your toothpaste and facewash contain micro plastics?
Left finger: Micro-Plastic that is put in face-wash and toothpaste:Right finger: SandComparing Micro-beads in facial cleaner to Sand-Grains. Animals like this isopod eat sand-sized foods. Larger animals eat isopods and micro-plastic travels up the food chain. Source: http://1.bp.blogspot.com/_WqeebKHnx54/S7kLDglnF7I/AAAAAAAAAFs/CLHbH2sAnGw/s1600/photo+detail+of+microplastic.jpghttp://5gyres.org/wp-content/themes/5gyres_theme/images/Campaigns/MicroBead/Slide32.jpgAll of these products contain micro-plasticIf you're not already familiar with micro-plastic, please watch these videos:and read one of many papers about the products you use that you probably didn't know pollute the ocean DAILY: http://5gyres.org/media/5_Gyres_Position_Paper_on_Microplastics.pdfI will need:1. At least ONE Micro-Plastic and Plankton Filter FeederNets are €1000 each + additional + spare parts = €2,000Two would mean mean I can train someone to bring it to another part of the world. This is a 'Manta-Net' used by NOAA which is a modification of a Neuston-Net. Source: http://oceanexplorer.noaa.gov/okeanos/explorations/ex1006/background/summary/media/manta_net_600.jpg adapted and sold by http://www.sea-gear.net/neuston-nets.htmlYour money will be pooled to support environmentally-supportive industries.I will train divers to use these tools who will hopefully buy more!2. I need to use an underwater video recording camera (can be rented)6 weeks rent: about €200Buy new and share with other scientists: €500+3. In addition to a recording device, I will also need mapping equipment. These will include various types of ropes, measuring lines and other survey equipment to the value of about €200 - €300 or more4. Open-Source Underwater Remotely Operated Vehicle.see www.openrov.comONLY €650!!!With enough funding, I would be able to purchase an open-source underwater ROV. I have ideas to take it into some of Ireland's lakes. If I get the money for this, I will donate the robot to UCC.5. Satellite Data.If I get enough funding, my options will open up beyond my wildest dreams!Did you know that we all have free access to Landsat data? Landsat is an American Satellite that has been continuously recording environmental data from the 1970s that is entirely free to download at landsat.usgs.govThe Impact                                     LESS OF THIS
Supporting this project is a way to pool resources to strengthen environmentally active industries such as www.sea-gear.net and other supportive businesses in Thailand such as Big Blue and others along the way.Supporting me is also a way to strengthen my ability to articulate my concerns about these environmental threats with modern spatial, marine and satellite resources. You are supporting independent science and education. I want to educate people with my research and educate myself about how to recontribute to these communities. I want to teach people modern skills with open-source technologies.A big thank you to Big Blue Diving who have been very keen 
on 
this project from the beginning. This project would absolutely not have 
been 
possible without them and they have put many resources in place that has
 allowed this project to come into fruition. Big Blue have done wonders 
over the years to educate 10,000s of people 
about the values of coral reefs and their team have played a significant
 role in inspiring this project. http://www.bigbluediving.com/
Other Ways You Can HelpIf you can't afford to fund this campaign, You can still be a massive asset to this campaign Help increase awareness of this project. Please share it widely across all forms of social media. Email it to everyone in your contact list. Print it out and stick it on your college / work noticeboard. Start a fundraiser at work. Think about how much plastic you can see right now. Imagine what's in the ocean.How can you decrease your plastic consumption today?What about tomorrow?Think about what businesses you support the next time you're doing some shopping. Google Micro Plastic.Look around and see who is making an effort in the world. How can you support? Educate yourself about how you can lower your plastic consumption.Additional Info
