story:
UPDATE: New Goal of $17,500

Dimock PA families with water contamination will finally have their day in court against Cabot Oil & Gas, but only with your help. The federal jury trial will start on November 30, 2015 in the Scranton Federal Courthouse and will be the highest-profile court case related to shale gas development in history.

We have set a new goal for online fundraising of $17,500 by the end of July. We are soliciting large donors and foundations to meet our overall goal of $50,000, but we can't get there without the donations of so many of you to this campaign.

Remember, if you haven't claimed a perk yet (like the waterfall tour, dinner with the eagles, or a weekend in Promised Land State Park) summer is the perfect time to visit northeast Pennsylvania!

Right now, the Dimock plaintiffs are in discovery phase, the part of litigation where each side presents its expert witnesses, affidavits, and questions for each other. 

We successfully raised enough to cover costs into July, but Cabot Oil has now been approved to depose nine expert witnesses in Houston TX in less than two weeks and the plaintiffs' attorneys and experts must be flown down to be present for those depositions. Our expert witnesses will be billing us additional time to prepare responses to Cabot's witnesses and we need this IndieGoGo campaign to cover the costs.

After discovery, the attorneys will be preparing for trial. Energy Justice Network is assisting with research at no cost, but this online fundraiser will be active until the trial date in November to make sure all expert costs are covered.

Again, please share this campaign to your friends and family using the Facebook and Twitter buttons at the top. 

Earlier this year, we completed this online fundraiser for $10,000, but the total trial costs will be at least $50,000.

Can you join the 256 donors who have already given and make a donation to the Dimock legal fund? All donations are tax-deductible.

Donations of $1,000 or more can be made out to "Action Center Inc.", our 501(c)3 name, with “Dimock Legal” in the memo and mailed to Action Center Inc. 1434 Elbridge St Philadelphia PA 19149.

Dimock, PA

There have been 119 Marcellus Shale wells drilled in Dimock Township, Susquehanna County.

Jared Ely near gas wells leased on his family's land near Dimock, Pa. Credit: Ruth Fremson/The New York Times

We Need To Cover Trial Costs

Expert witnesses and knowledgeable attorneys are invaluable when presenting allegations of water contamination and damages before a court of law. Scott Ely, who has spoken out as a gas industry whistle-blower, his family, and their neighbors, the Huberts, are proceeding with a landmark federal lawsuit over drilling-related water contamination in Pennsylvania. In 2014, the judge ruled that the plaintiffs' case can proceed to trial, permitting jury selection.

The lawsuit entitled Norma Fiorentino et al vs Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation and Gas Search Drilling Services Corp. was brought in the United States District Court for the Middle District of Pennsylvania (Civil No. 3:09-CV-2284) on November 19, 2009.  The case eventually included 22 families from Dimock and Springville Townships in Susquehanna County, Pennsylvania, who sought fair compensation for damages to their property and their lives caused by Cabot’s failed natural gas drilling operations.

Beginning in the fall of 2008, Dimock families with children noticed problems with their drinking water, and began to experience rashes, nausea, headaches and dizziness. A trigger point to the litigation was the explosion of an elderly resident’s private water well on New Year’s Eve, December 31, 2008 due to methane gas accumulation in the well head.

Holding up a sample of Scott's water, hydrologist Paul Rubin said, "Here, you can see it as it now comes out of the well – the color of chocolate milk, five times the maximum allowable PA MCL Safe Drinking Water standard (75 vs. 15 color units) for color. Even after weeks, it still does not settle out" 

Following the public announcement by the federal Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) in the summer of 2012 that the water was safe to drink, the vast majority of the families settled their lawsuits against Cabot. Two families, totaling four adults and five children, whose water wells were ordered permanently plugged by the Pennsylvania Department of Environmental Protection in connection with Cabot’s drilling operations, did not agree to settle. A third non-settling case is that of the Estate of Kenneth Ely whose claim was dismissed by the Court and is being appealed.

The accuracy of EPA’s statement in 2012 that Dimock’s water was safe to drink was later called into question as a result of disclosure of contradictory statements contained in internal EPA documents.

The remaining plaintiffs in the case, which has now been re-captioned as Nolen Scott Ely, et al. v Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation et al., are Nolen Scott Ely and his family and Ray Hubert and his family. Ray Hubert and his family live up the hill from the Elys. The Ely family has lived in Dimock since the 1800’s.

Except for a two year period when Cabot supplied these plaintiffs with water, since 2008, the Elys and Huberts have been living without reliable access to water and under rationing conditions.  To survive day to day, these families haul water at their own expense every week for drinking, bathing and other daily basics. They purchase bottled water for drinking and cooking. The Court has recognized that these plaintiffs have a case against Cabot which they are preparing to present to a jury of their peers. The trial date is expected to be set in April, according to court documents.

In order to effectively try the case, the Elys and Huberts must retain witnesses including a hydrologist, an engineer, and property expert. Our administration fees include our accountant’s time and will be five percent of funds raised. Legal fees for attorneys will be paid with the remainder of funds.

We estimate that costs associated with the trial will be between $50,000 and $100,000. As part of our Energy Jutice Shale Initiative, we are committing to raising a substantial portion of these funds.

Water Contamination in Dimock

In 2008, well water in homes along Carter Rd went bad after Cabot Oil & Gas developed the first drilling operations in northeast Pennsylvania. Pennsylvania Department of Environmental Protection determined that well casing failures in the Baker, Gesford, Ratzel, and Ely wells had caused 17 water wells to become contaminated. Subsequently, Cabot entered into several consent orders regarding that contamination.

In 2011, HydroQuest's Paul Rubin, an expert hydrologist, determined in his initial findings that Scott Ely's water contained lead and manganese at 5.8 and 10 times State Maximum Contaminate Levels and arsenic at 15 times the State MCL level. He found aluminum concentration of 28 mg/l, some 140 times the State MCL.

Aluminum is a potent neurotoxin that may be linked to dementia, including Alzheimer’s like health symptoms. Similarly, iron was detected at 34 mg/l, some 113 times the State MCL Safe Drinking Water standard. 

At the time, Mr. Rubin stated, "While all analyses have not been completed, preliminary findings also indicate the presence of low level hexanes, octanes, and decanes."

He added "However, the high pH of the water indicates the presence of SIGNIFICANT other frack - related chemicals that are both unknown and untested – chemical compounds that do not have MCLs – chemicals that potentially present long-term chronic exposure to toxins and carcinogens."

Rubin found that the pH of the water has repeatedly been found to be around 9.5 – a very basic water, some 10 times the normal outer MCL State drinking water standard range of pH 8.5 and, quite likely, 100 times that of a more normal Dimock groundwater pH. "This is highly unusual and extremely troubling. Something is VERY wrong with this water," he wrote in testimony offered at a press conference.


What We Need & What You Get

We need to raise $50,000 to cover the costs of depositions (recorded testimony) of our experts and the company's witnesses.

  • For all donors, we will mention you in a video to thank you for your support.
  • You will be the first to know the progress on the Elys and Huberts landmark case.
  • You or your group will be welcome in Dimock for a private tour of fracking, related infrastructure, and to meet families with water contamination.

The Impact

If the Dimock case is successful, we will finally have some closure and fair compensation.

At the very least, the trial phase will expose information about Cabot's operations that have deprived Dimock families of there basic rights, such as clean drinking water.

Anyone interested in public health, environmental justice, and corporate accountability, should find our fundraiser a worthy cause.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute money, that doesn't mean you can't help. Please share this page and encourage your friends and family to donate.

story:
WE DID IT!  Thanks to you we exceeded our goal and are now able to finance solar energy for Other Avenues! As Other Avenues pays us back over time, we'll be able to use your donations to pay for three more solar projects!

While the campaign is over, you can still support the Solar Seed Fund and help us put solar energy in more communities by donating today! We still have some great perks available and all donations will be used for our next solar energy project.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

We believe that everyone should have the ability to support clean energy.

So we created a new way for people to take action.

It's a pretty simple idea actually...

We're raising money in this campaign to put solar on Other Avenues, a worker-owned cooperative grocery store.  As they pay us back, we reinvest the money into more solar projects in communities across the country.

It's a pay-it-forward model for community solar.

We call it the Solar Seed Fund.

RE-volv is a nonprofit organization based in San Francisco dedicated to fighting climate change by supporting the growth of solar energy in communities across the United States.

By supporting this campaign you are helping Other Avenues fulfill its commitment to sustainability, while growing the Solar Seed Fund that will finance solar projects around the country.

RE-volv has financed two solar projects so far through crowdfunding on Indiegogo (Check out our previous campaigns Plant a Seed for Solar Energy and Revolving Fund for Solar Energy).  The Solar Seed Fund is already revolving, and over $7,000 in lease payments from our last two projects are helping to fund this one! And with your help, we can make this our biggest project yet!

****Referral Contest****

Our hope with this campaign is not just to raise enough money to install solar for Other Avenues. We also want to include as many people as possible in the effort. In other words, we want to build solar through community, and build community through solar!

That's where you come in.

The 5 individuals who refer the most donors to the campaign will each receive the $1,000 perk!

How it works: When you donate, Indiegogo will provide you with a unique URL to share the campaign with your friends.  This keeps track of how many people who you referred to the campaign donated.

Remember, your friends have to use your unique URL in order for it to be tracked!

About Other Avenues

Other Avenues is a worker-owned cooperative grocery store that's been serving the Outer Sunset community of San Francisco for 40 years.  It serves local, organic, and healthy food and is deeply committed to sustainability and workplace democracy. With your support, Other Avenues can fulfill a long-held dream of going solar!

Benefits for Other Avenues and the Environment

This campaign will finance a 36 kW solar energy system for the Other Avenues worker-owned cooperative grocery store, saving them $335,000 over the life of the system, and saving our atmosphere from the emission of 24,000 pounds of carbon dioxide each year! That's equivalent to planting over 100 acres of trees over the life of the system.

About our model


By donating to the Solar Seed Fund, you’re investing in this solar energy project and future projects for other communities. RE-volv pays for solar energy installations for nonprofits and cooperatives that serve their community. As these community-serving organizations pay RE-volv back over time, RE-volv reinvests the principal and the interest it earns with each project into additional solar projects. On average, each project ends up funding another 3 solar projects!  Investing in the Solar Seed Fund means every dollar you donate will go further- your donation will multiply over time, serving more and more communities with solar.

*All donations to this campaign are tax-deductible.*

**Check with your employer to see if they'll match your donation!**

About our Perks

All of our perks were carefully selected by our team to support your passion for the environment, solar energy, and healthy food.

Of course the biggest perk of all is knowing that each dollar invested in solar today will benefit the community and the environment for years to come.

You'll notice that for each perk level we've figured out how much carbon dioxide will be avoided because of your donation over the 25 year warranty of this solar array.

*Exact perk details are subject to availability.*

Supporting Organizations
We are extremely grateful for our partner organizations that support this campaign.

                                             

                                                       

                                   

                                      

                                              


Campaign Sponsors
We owe a huge debt of gratitude to our sponsors who have donated products and contributed financially to this campaign.

As Other Avenues pays us back over time, we'll be able to use your donations to pay for three more solar projects!While the campaign is over, you can still support the Solar Seed Fund and help us put solar energy in more communities by donating today! We still have some great perks available and all donations will be used for our next solar energy project.---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------We believe that everyone should have the ability to support clean energy.So we created a new way for people to take action.It's a pretty simple idea actually...We're raising money in this campaign to put solar on Other Avenues, a worker-owned cooperative grocery store.  As they pay us back, we reinvest the money into more solar projects in communities across the country.It's a pay-it-forward model for community solar.We call it the Solar Seed Fund. story:
Short Summary of the Project and Its Impact

Elijah Martineau is a 12-year old from Lansing, Michigan who loves birds.  He has engaged in bird conservation for about 2 years now, with projects put on by bird clubs and by volunteering at a local urban natural area, Fenner Nature Center.  Elijah is also great at designing things.  He decided that he’d like to put these two passions together and redesign the feeder area at the nature center to help migrating birds on their journeys north and south and to help the birds that live here year round. 

Elijah will create a design for the feeding area to promote native plants, insects, birds and mammals.  Many of plants in Fenner's bird feeding area are non-native, so insects that need native plants are not found in the area.  That, in turn, affects the diversity of birds that use the feeding area.  Because of this, Elijah will start with the plants.  Then he will add in features that make a great bird feeding station.

Particularly because Fenner is an urban nature center, supporting more diversity in the bird feeding area will give children and adults more opportunities to learn about and observe wildlife they may have never seen before.  He wants to share his experience of learning about and becoming an advocate for birds or other wildlife.  He may even have the chance to teach summer camp kids about conservation and about his project!

Fenner Nature Center is an urban, 134-acre oasis.  The land is owned by the city of Lansing, but managed by the non-profit organization, Fenner Conservancy.  Because Elijah is working with a non-profit organization, he needs to raise funds for this project.

What Elijah Needs & What You Get

Elijah has spent the last few weeks researching for and budgeting his project.  He has conducted telephone interviews with various nature centers about their feeding areas.  He has done online research to find great products.  He has asked questions about plants that are native to our area and gotten information on which ones attract birds and insects.

He needs to raise about $1,200 in order to:

  • Buy native plants and shrubs from a local nursery.

$290 for wholeshale prices from WildType Nursery

  • Build a path through the feeding area, build and paint a blind for people to observe birds, build a trellis for native vines, and build nesting spaces for native bees.

$315 for wood, hardware, paint, edging, and paving stones

  • Purchase a new birdbath with a winter heater.

$80 for a birdbath, heater, extension cord, and cord protector

       •  Purchase Michigan-made cedar feeders, a roost box, and butterfly house

$132 for purchases from Stovall feeders, Mr. Stovall has invited Elijah to his workshop!

  • Purchase binoculars for viewing the feeders from inside the building.

$80 for two pairs of low-cost, high-quality binoculars (he can apply to the American Birding Association for these)

  • Sand and pea stones for the pathway (doubling as grit that birds need), plus other miscellaneous items.

$117

Elijah has some amazing prizes for those who can donate to the cause, which you can see to the right.

If Elijah is not able to raise the entire amount, he will decide which parts of the design can be left out.  If he is able to raise extra funds, he will be able to help Fenner stock birdseed, suet, and fruits for the feeding area.

How You Can Help!

Of course, Elijah would love it if you could donate.  Even $5-10 will make a difference toward reaching his goal!  Whether or not you are able to donate, please share the link for this campaign with your friends and encourage them to contribute!  Let's give Fenner Nature Center the most thoughtfully designed and most effective bird feeding area we can!

Updates

Make sure to check the "updates" tab for more videos by Elijah.  We want to keep everyone up-to-date on the progress Elijah is already making on his project!

story:
Summary

RE-volv is a non-profit organization that is growing the movement for community-based solar energy. By crowdfunding, RE-volv will finance community-based solar energy projects using a revolving fund called the Solar Seed Fund. The Solar Seed Fund pays for solar energy installations on local community centers like schools and non-profits.  The community centers pay RE-volv back over time through the savings on their electric bill. RE-volv reinvests the principal and the revenues it earns on each project into additional solar projects, creating a revolving fund in a pay-it-forward model.

What We Need & What You Get

RE-volv needs an additional $10,000 to finance the first community-based solar energy installation to get the revolving fund off the ground.  We've already raised $20,000. With $10,000 more we will be able to afford a $30,000 solar installation for a community-serving organization. This one installation will generate enough revenue to fund an additional three solar energy systems over time!

By supporting this campaign you have a number of amazing perks to choose from including access to events, a certificate or photo of the solar you helped install, and a choice of amazing books about solar energy and the future of environmentalism.

If we don’t reach our entire goal with this campaign, we will still use all of this money for the first solar energy project and your impact will still have the same multiplier effect.

All donations to this campaign are tax-deductible.

Also, let us know if you'd like to make a donation in someone else's name.  This can be a great holiday gift!

The Impact

Our vision is to see people come together to build solar energy projects in our communities. With each project we do, we will show more people the benfits of solar energy and help raise awareness of solar energy nationwide.

By making a donation to the Solar Seed Fund you are planting a seed for a renewable energy future in communities in the United States. Your helping to build a new, decentralized, distributed, community-based way of generating energy.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please help spread the word about this campaign to your friends and family. You can also like us on Facebook, follow us on Twitter, and sign up for our mailing list to hear RE-volv's latest updates.

story:
Short Summary

I am an artist who is ecologically concerned and passionate about doing my part.

I have developed an amazing packaging that is not only home-compostable, but is also embedded with wildflower seeds! So much of the world's packaging ends up as a non-sustainable addition to our filthy land fills, whereas my packaging ends up as clean soil and beautiful flowers. By purchasing my vegan, organic chocolate in my wildflower seeded packaging, you can help to beautify the world and be an integral part of the solution after enjoying one of our planet's most decadent treats.

Our packaging serves to delight and to educate simultaneously.

 

What We Need & What You Get

This project needs funding to pay for mostly manufacturing labor and raw materials. We use recycled paper to create packaging and embed high-quality organic seeds so that you, the purchaser, can have a wonderfully satisfying results when the packaging is planted.

We want you to enjoy a seedless paper greeting card for a donation of $15. Our appreciation gift for a $35 donation is a box of our organic chocolates in our seeded paper packaging. For $60, our thank you gift is one pound of chocolates in a large seeded box, and for and for a $100 donation, our gift is two 2 one pound boxes of our organic chocolates in our seeded paper packaging. You will not only enjoy our delicious chocolates, but you will feel amazing knowing that you helped to positively change the planet for present and future generations.

The Impact

As the founder and product developer of Native Gardens Chocolates, our motto is that “what is good is good for the planet", and this is our effort not only to change our own product packaging, but to inspire other companies to use home-compostable packaging.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot donate, please forward this link on your facebook, twitter, linked-in to any social network you are connected to.  Thank you so much for your time!

story:
We believe that this new and emerging field, where ecology and sexuality meet, is a new and exciting frontier where real world problems can be solved, love can be restored to the planet, the war of the sexes can be healed, and we can learn how to honor and cherish the earth. 

What is Eco Sex?

  1. Going Green between the sheets with body/earth safe products,
  2. Green Dating, ecosexuals only date other ecosexuals,
  3. Choosing life and love styles that are sustainable,
  4. Creating a culture that values nature, even our sexual nature
  5. My body, my gender, my orientation: Baby I was Born This Way!
  6. Nature is sexy - Let's make Nature our lover, not our mother. 

What is a symposium?

We know what you’re thinking…But it’s NOT (boring, that is)! We like the definition of a symposium referencing an ancient Greek tradition in which people gather for a “convivial party with music and conversation, usually following a banquet or dinner.” So it’s a…PARTY!

The ECO SEX SYMPOSIUM will be held June 29 to July 1 in Portland, OR, and will include 21 workshops, 3 keynote speakers, live entertainment, and live-raw food, plus vendors, free talks, and an Eco Ball.

SPEAKERS:

Our keynote speakers are Bob Czimbal, author, workshop leader, nationally sought after presenter, and Serena Anderilini, Ph.D., professor, author and interntional speaker.

Plus 16 other presenters from near and far on topics ranging from alternative economies, sustainable communities, permaculture, conscious birthing, reproductive choice, and birth control methods that don't harm the ecosystem, live raw food, sex, love, and relationship, activisim, sex, and ecology, and more!

FUNDING:

We need funds to pay speaker fees, rental costs, food costs, and to help fund a “free marketplace” to help encourage the “gift economy” (We plan to trade goods and services for GoddessBucks, so no one is turned away and everyone contributes). We also want to pay our volunteers and key organizers a small stipend.
 

Visit our website www.ecosex.org For more info, please contact Gabriella Cordova at: gabriella@lotusheartcenter.org or Teri Ciacchi at livingloverevolution@me.com. 


Please help us spread the word & make it a better, sexier world!


Campaign cover photo by Mina Bast. All rights reserved.

story:
We've made i! With all your help, and your friends help, and their moms help too! Thank you everyone, to those who contributed through thought, word, and deed alike. We now have 9 hours left and $100 dollars left to reach our challenge goal. 

Stay tuned...

Here's the scoop:

We are Mourette Valcin and Chris Bashirov Newton, and we have the opportunity of a lifetime.  We will become stewards of an 80 acre property in North Michigan.  The land has been used for agroforestry and permaculture, and is surrounded by land rich in resources, beautiful lakes, and fruit orchards.  We hope to continue the practice of cultivating Pine forest, and using the rich resources on the land that are often overlooked, to further our mission.  The land will become a homestead and institute fostering education as well as self-sufficiency, and we will be documenting our experience in the process.

This includes:

-Planting food forests as perennial poly-culture gardens, allowing production of fruit, vegetables, herbs, and flowers, which will grow into a mature ecosystem.

-Building infrastructure from natural materials on site for educational purposes, and self maintaining dwellings. 

-Connecting with local, and global communities to share and engage in research in order to continue the propagation of sustainable practices. 

-Continuing research and agroforestry 

-Inviting others to learn,  live, and visit onsite, and to practice alongside us

-Creating a legacy for those involved and generations to come


Fortunately, the costs for development using Permaculture methods, such as stacking functions, using recycled materials, and an abundance of onsite resources, is extremely low! We are asking for $2,500 start-up funds for our sustainable homestead and institute.   See the Video for more details!

Where will the money go?

 
Stacking Functions of $2,750

costs and budget

Cleaning the Earth Lodge - $10

Fixing the Earth Lodge Roof - $10

Installing a floor in the Earth Lodge - $10

Rocket Mass Heater - $25

Inoculating 300 Shiitake Logs - $50

Seeds - 30 Packs- $100

Rabbits and Feed - $120

Trees - $150

Local/Organic Food - $200

Tools - $200

Transportation (Bus, Car, Horse) - $1500

Miscellaneous Costs of Administrative Duties and Rewards - $375
 

If we raise more than our goal, your funds will go towards;

-Additional fundraising events

-Mason jars for canning

-2 Beehives

-Founding a non-profit organization

-Developing a nursery of trees

-Building a cafe

-Tools for outreach to the community

If our $2,500 goal is not reached, we will persevere and will execute the plan taking housing, warmth, and food security as priority, and will target these as funds permit;

 

-Reconstructing the earth lodge

-Building a rocket mass heater

-Inoculating mushroom logs

-Planting gardens

 

Pics of our trip to visit the site on Jan 1, 2013 -

Earth Lodge

Yurt

 

What is permaculture you ask?

In my opinion, a fancy word for working with the land and people instead of against land and its people which we have seen happening to this date. Permaculture stemming from permanent agriculture/culture has been growing and will continue to grow especially with the help of community members, those who feel it is something to invest in. Permaculture is a lifestyle. 

 

Agroforestry?

Agroforestry is a term which describes the propagation and cultivation of trees strategicallyused as a means of preserving/enhancing the productivity of land.  All trees have various uses and benefits, all of which benefit humans and nature, as they provide micro climates for liveable temperatures, as their roots hold the soil from flooding, and their leaves produce oxygen and help the atmosphere.

 

Background:

we are:

2 new permaculture designers

2 yoga instructors

2 cooks

1 baker

1 musician,

and most of all 2 students, the universe our classroom.

 

For the past year, we both lived in a community setting at Sivananda Yoga Ashram, which led us to take a permaculture design course, and become certified yoga instructors. We were able to gain invaluable skills from teachers Charles and Julia Yelton and are more then ready to get our hands dirty on our future site. 

 

Building a Pond- Applied Permaculture April, 2012 Day 1

Day 3

Filling the Pond

Final Pond, 4 Days of hard work and a great team at the ashram, within days there were tadpoles swimming at the bottom, introducing water into a landscape is both beautiful and beneficial to permaculture techniques. 

 

Being the cooks for the ashram for a year, helped us bring food from the farm, to the table, aiding in both the garden work, seeing the process from start to finish

 

 

You can imagine that seeing this, and being part of the process peaked our interest for building our own homestead, contributing to the many before and those to come. 

 

We were able to help in October, 2012 to build a movable greenhouse in efforts to create more self-sufficiency.

Two days later

Food Forest

 

 


This campaign is more than planting trees and creating sustainable structures. Sustainability has become a new buzzword, in all honesty it is an effort to build a place for learning and acceptance. It is for those who want a deeper connection with the land and aim for self-resilience. 

YOUR contribution is not without value, ANYTHING counts. We are asking for your assistance to make this ideal a reality. Though we may be constantly bombarded with fundraisers, this campaign counts because without you, there is no sustenance.

This endeavor speaks for our generation, and will be a unique place to come and connect through community. The communal experience is full of ups and downs though it is rewarding and something that is extremely important with the changes we have seen over time. We are not generation F'ed, as we have been described, we are with tools of nature backing us to live happily.  The impact of this project is beyond our two lives, and is beyond a material reality. It is allowing us to become stewards but also allowing us to create a safe haven.

Aside from the rewards listing on the right, you get that fuzzy feeling of putting smiles on our faces, and knowing what you have given will be for a lasting cause.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you cannot help monetarily, you can help by spreading the word through the plethora of social media sites, word of mouth, and in your own lives by supporting locally, with a global attitude. 

For your reading pleasure, two articles which explain our motives and inspiration for our project, plus our blog which shares insights, recipes, and will be a place for updates about the project. 

Blog: http://ohhmblog.wordpress.com/

Articles:

http://www.naturalnews.com/039342_urban_farms_self-reliance_food_production.html

http://www.agrowingculture.org/2013/02/beginning-farmers-learning-networking-and-connecting-to-place/

 

BIG Thank You to our supporters and teachers:


Charles and Julia Yelton

Wendy Newton and Peter Ferko @ http://www.thetable-brooklyn.org/

The Woodlanders

The Valcins

Ashram Folk
story_txt:
We've made i! With all your help, and your friends help, and their moms help too! Thank you everyone, to those who contributed through thought, word, and deed alike. We now have 9 hours left and $100 dollars left to reach our challenge goal. 
Stay tuned...
Here's the scoop:
We are Mourette Valcin and Chris Bashirov Newton, and we have the opportunity of a lifetime.  We will become stewards of an 80 acre property in North Michigan.  The land has been used for agroforestry and permaculture, and is surrounded by land rich in resources, beautiful lakes, and fruit orchards.  We hope to continue the practice of cultivating Pine forest, and using the rich resources on the land that are often overlooked, to further our mission.  The land will become a homestead and institute fostering education as well as self-sufficiency, and we will be documenting our experience in the process.
This includes:
-Planting food forests as perennial poly-culture gardens, allowing production of fruit, vegetables, herbs, and flowers, which will grow into a mature ecosystem.
-Building infrastructure from natural materials on site for educational purposes, and self maintaining dwellings. 
-Connecting with local, and global communities to share and engage in research in order to continue the propagation of sustainable practices. 
-Continuing research and agroforestry 
-Inviting others to learn,  live, and visit onsite, and to practice alongside us
-Creating a legacy for those involved and generations to come 
Fortunately, the costs for development using Permaculture methods, such as stacking functions, using recycled materials, and an abundance of onsite resources, is extremely low! We are asking for $2,500 start-up funds for our sustainable homestead and institute.   See the Video for more details!
Where will the money go?
 Stacking Functions of $2,750
costs and budget
Cleaning the Earth Lodge - $10
Fixing the Earth Lodge Roof - $10
Installing a floor in the Earth Lodge - $10
Rocket Mass Heater - $25
Inoculating 300 Shiitake Logs - $50
Seeds - 30 Packs- $100
Rabbits and Feed - $120
Trees - $150
Local/Organic Food - $200
Tools - $200
Transportation (Bus, Car, Horse) - $1500
Miscellaneous Costs of Administrative Duties and Rewards - $375 
If we raise more than our goal, your funds will go towards; 
-Additional fundraising events
-Mason jars for canning
-2 Beehives
-Founding a non-profit organization
-Developing a nursery of trees
-Building a cafe
-Tools for outreach to the community
If our $2,500 goal is not reached, we will persevere and will execute the plan taking housing, warmth, and food security as priority, and will target these as funds permit;
 
-Reconstructing the earth lodge
-Building a rocket mass heater
-Inoculating mushroom logs
-Planting gardens
 
Pics of our trip to visit the site on Jan 1, 2013 - 
Earth Lodge

Yurt



 
What is permaculture you ask?



In my opinion, a fancy word for working with the land and people instead of against land and its people which we have seen happening to this date. Permaculture stemming from permanent agriculture/culture has been growing and will continue to grow especially with the help of community members, those who feel it is something to invest in. Permaculture is a lifestyle. 
 
Agroforestry?
Agroforestry is a term which describes the propagation and cultivation of trees strategicallyused as a means of preserving/enhancing the productivity of land.  All trees have various uses and benefits, all of which benefit humans and nature, as they provide micro climates for liveable temperatures, as their roots hold the soil from flooding, and their leaves produce oxygen and help the atmosphere.
 
Background:
we are:
2 new permaculture designers
2 yoga instructors
2 cooks
1 baker
1 musician,
and most of all 2 students, the universe our classroom.
 
For the past year, we both lived in a community setting at Sivananda Yoga Ashram, which led us to take a permaculture design course, and become certified yoga instructors. We were able to gain invaluable skills from teachers Charles and Julia Yelton and are more then ready to get our hands dirty on our future site. 
 
Building a Pond- Applied Permaculture April, 2012 Day 1

Day 3

Filling the Pond

Final Pond, 4 Days of hard work and a great team at the ashram, within days there were tadpoles swimming at the bottom, introducing water into a landscape is both beautiful and beneficial to permaculture techniques. 

 
Being the cooks for the ashram for a year, helped us bring food from the farm, to the table, aiding in both the garden work, seeing the process from start to finish

 
 

You can imagine that seeing this, and being part of the process peaked our interest for building our own homestead, contributing to the many before and those to come. 

 
We were able to help in October, 2012 to build a movable greenhouse in efforts to create more self-sufficiency.

Two days later


Food Forest
 
 
This campaign is more than planting trees and creating sustainable  structures. Sustainability has become a new buzzword, in all honesty it is an effort to build a place for learning and acceptance. It is for those who want a deeper connection with the land and aim for self-resilience.

story:
Our Roots

The double earthquakes of April/May 2015 spawned our first works, instigated to interrupt the bleak day-to-day outlook that existed in those broken times. After all nothing gets you looking forward like imagining a tree--you planted--growing and fruiting hey? 150 fruit and nut trees were distributed to 30 youths between 10-14 years of age in our village of Gaggle in Bhumi Dhara, Kavre District.

As we believe that empty giving rarely helps, a day long class was hosted with the children and community on how to plant and care for their trees.

Trees For Relief  is grown and maintained by a small group of foreigners, who combined have a history of two decades working, planting and growing in Nepal. The project is cared for and hosted by 5 Elements Organic Bastion--an organic farm run by some members of Trees For Relief--this way nothing is ever left unattended.

Our works were further boosted after the Nepal Earthbag Project came to Gaggle in November 2015 building an Earthbag Dome to help show locals stronger affordable construction methods for the post earthquake rebuild. This dome was gifted to Trees For Relief  to serve as our future classroom and center.                                                      

In January 2016 Trees For Relief  hosted 3 days of tree-training, where about 20 people learned how to care and expand on the trees that were distributed post earthquake. The workshop was received warmly by all who participated.

So, what are we looking for?

1. Complete Classroom (Dome)--$2500.

This beauty's got to get plastered--preferably using old-style lime plaster, its kitchen room needs completion and a modest solar system installed to keep it "off-grid".

2. "Mother-Tree" Resource Garden--$500.

Plant 25 well sourced, high value fruit and nut trees, creating an onsite resource for cutting and grafting future tree populations.

3. Greenhouse & Native Nursery System--$2500.

Its great to have cuttings grafted but, they need somewhere to be safe and grow strong before moving to permanent locations. A modest greenhouse for 1000 cuttings annually is in the planning design.

To not loose focus on native plants we have a nursery setup planned for starting native root-stocks for graftings. And importantly, to propagate native hardwood trees from seed and clone for future supplies of quality timber.

4. Purchase The Land--$3000.

Keeping this project safe for future generations is important and nothing does that like land deeds. Purchasing has been negotiated for the 500sq/m area of dome, garden and greenhouse/nursery for the very reasonable price of $2500 plus legal fees, etc $500.

5. Classes, Teachers, Knowledge--$1500

Open classes to all, on the first Saturday of each month, with teachers receiving a fair payment of $50 per class. And lets shake it up, teachers from anywhere who have credible knowledge to share in all aspects of "Organic" farming throughout the year, whether its Grafting in winter, or Bee-keeping in spring, Mulching, Composting... you get the idea.

The Impact

When society wishes a better future, one of the best places to invest is in community building, environmental protection and youth development. Daily, Nepal sees 1500-2000 people leave home and family to toil abroad in countries like Saudi Arabia, Qatar and Malaysia. Few leave for education. Even less return wealthy. Those who do quickly leave village-life as its seen as "backwards".

Young people have little or no facilities except school, if they go. Village life has little pastime activities other than festivals or marriages etc. Alcoholism and domestic violence have become real issues in modern society.

Through this project it's hoped to create a small bubble--helping to "lightly" address these issues, while also helping answer the larger questions of deforestation, global warming and outward migration.

Why Us?

Nepal, ranked as one of the poorest countries in the world has seen its fair share of problems: civil war, political upheavals, national strikes, fuel shortages, border blockades and natural disasters to name but a few. In fact we've probably seen more things go wrong than most.

So what qualifies us? Well that's just it, we've been through it all and still standing, still growing. We are surrounded by a small group of dedicated people not easily shocked or prone to leaving. Despite all the daily struggles and hurdles we are still here. Our community has seen that too, earning a respect for hard work, steadfastness and sharing.

We can't promise much, other than we are here working, doing and will continue to do so.

Don't Be Shy

Good people doing good things has more weight than machinery and finances combined. Tell your friends, family, co-workers, bosses, random people at the bus-stop, even your neighbours' dog. Help us get the word out: Facebook, Twitter, letters in bottles, messenger pigeons, don't think your personal effort has no value.

Every dollar helps, but we have learned money's not everything. If you are not able to personally contribute that's fine, but please share the word, help us get Trees For Relief out there. What we really need--and always will--is help.

  Thank you for taking the time to read this.

story:
Each purchase of an Ocean Bottle funds the collection of 1000 ocean-bound plastic bottles. And, the Ocean Bottle combines the best features of reusable bottles in one:

 

OUR INDIEGOGO CAMPAIGN HAS NOW CLOSED. YOU CAN STILL BE THE OWER OF A FIRST BATCH BOTTLE BY VISITING OUR SITE HERE.

 

                    

The average rate of plastic currently flowing into our oceans is 22 million kgs per day, essentially the volume of a truck each minute.

 

 

Plastic pollution is a symptom of the real issue: a lack of infrastructure and incentives to recycle where it is needed most. 

We’ve teamed up with The Plastic Bank to pay above market rates to plastic collectors and set up recycling infrastructure so that plastic can be sold and created into new products. 

Together, we’re enabling people living in poverty all over the world to make a fair living from collecting plastic, and creating an economy where plastic has a value. 

 

11.368kgs of plastic? More bottles than you might use in 6 years? Enough to fill a small car?

1000 plastic bottles can be hard to imagine. So we collected 1000 bottles from the favelas of Brazil to demonstrate the impact of one Ocean Bottle. It's more than you'd think and bear in mind we don't just collect bottles, we actually collect all types of plastic which can be even more: 

The Ocean Bottle is designed to be the last reusable bottle you’ll ever need to buy. We partnered with the award-winning Norwegian design agency K8 to create a 500ml bottle that combines the best features that exist with a series of new innovative functions.

Featured in...

The final bottle will mirror the renders above. 

The Ocean Bottle is vacuum insulated, so it keeps hot drinks piping hot

and cool drinks ice cold.

Our cap contains anti-leak technology which means it's safe in your bag,

while the easy carry loop makes it a breeze to take on the go.

There are two openings; a small one for easy drinking and a big one for easy filling.

The base made of up-cycled ocean plastic lands softly on your table.

It designed for everyday use and wherever else your life takes you.

And when you go to clean your bottle at the end of the day, you're in luck.

The Ocean Bottle is the one of the only dishwasher safe vacuum insulated bottles.

 

Our colours represent the ocean and its surrounding environment. 

Each bottle is activated with an NFC smart chip, so in future we plan for individuals and organisations to be able to contribute more to plastic collection each time an Ocean Bottle is filled up in participating retail and business locations.

Our next phase of the Ocean Bottle project is to forge partnerships with lunch chains, juice bars, coffee chains, water fountain companies, subscription systems, and loyalty programmes to provide for continuous ocean impact.

Interested in joining as a partner? email partnerships@oceanbottle.co

 
 
Our challenge was to design a bottle that is both beautiful and functional. To anticipate the users every need, without compromising on sustainability.
 

 
We examined over 60 bottles, scoured product reviews and conducted countless user interviews to understand the users journey and to develop the ultimate reusable bottle.
 
 
We also chose a selection of sustainable materials to help us deliver the functions while setting a new benchmark for environmental products.
 
 
 
Our co-founder Will was working as a deckhand in the Indian Ocean when he saw the effect of plastic pollution firsthand. It was then he decided to focus on finding a solution. During his masters, Will met 3 individuals who were also determined to make an impact on the ocean plastic crisis. Together, they had just one requirement for a potential solution: develop a system that addresses the root of the problem, rather than a one time fix. After many brainstorming sessions, the Ocean Bottle was born. 
 
 
The root of the idea is in people: The Ocean Bottle funds an ecosystem of plastic collectors, paying them 3x the rate they could previously earn for collected plastic through an IBM Blockchain backed system. The impact is threefold: less plastic entering the ocean from top sources, a reduction in poverty, and the creation of a circular economy around collected plastic reducing the need for new plastic.
 
 

By 2025 we plan to be stopping the equivalent of 3 billion plastic bottles from entering our oceans each year and expanding recycling infrastructure, taking on new plastic projects, and supporting plastic collectors worldwide. But we can't do this without you. We need your help to grow the team of plastic collectors. 

 
This is our mantra, our company culture, and our mission.
 
Many companies tack on corporate responsibility as an added layer to their business, or donate a vague “percentage of profits” to various causes. Don't get us wrong, that impact is helpful. But this company is focused on sustainability to the core. That's why we've engineered a defined impact per product which is non-negotiable. We're committed to transparency around our impact and empowerment to the consumer. Being a revenue and profit sharing social enterprise also enables us to do even more, beyond our minimum pledge. On that note, let's start with some transparency around where your money is going: 
 

 
 
 
 

We've started partnering with organisations to fund ocean-bound plastic projects worldwide through the Ocean Bottle. Interested in purchasing Ocean Bottles for your team?

Email co-branding@theoceanbottle.com

 

We owe a great deal to our partners, who have helped us bring the Ocean Bottle to life.

Other advisors include UN Oceans, WEF, World Ocean Headquarters, World Wild Life Fund, Gallifrey Foundation, A Plastic Planet.

 

The core team met while studying entrepreneurship at London Business School. We hail from the USA, UK, Norway and Mexico. But we share a common interest in the environment and a desire to change the world. We also bring a diverse skill set to the project, including crowdfunding, engineering, eco-products, venture building, operations, blockchain and eCommerce from companies including P&G, Amazon, Scatec Solar, Rocket Internet, United Nations and Ogilvy.

 

Contact us:

ahoy@theoceanbottle.com

Follow us:

Like us:

Risks & Challenges

We are so excited about the Ocean Bottle and its potential to impact both oceans and coastal economies. We’ve had many sleepless nights making sure that everything is perfect.

We understand that no project comes without risk and challenges. Despite our planning, there are circumstances that may be out of our control. Our identified risks include product quality and timeline delays. If we are met with any issues in these areas, we promise to communicate with full transparency to you.

How we are mitigating risks

Product Manufacturing 

  • We vetted and toured the facilities of 4 stellar manufacturers referred by our design partners
  • We've produced and tested multiple prototypes and will be testing more before shipping
  • We will maintain constant communication with our manufacturer to promote on-time delivery and resolve any challenges that arise

Shipping 
We have negotiated warehouse space in both the UK and the US, and will be shipping the bottles globally as soon as we receive them

Other Ways You Can Help

If you want to support the project, but don't want a bottle, help us get the word out! Share our campaign on social media, start a conversation about ocean plastic with a friend, or support Plastic Bank and the amazing work they are doing. 

Your feedback is also greatly appreciated. 

Looking for more information or have a question? Check out our FAQ - which reaches to the moon and back.

We vetted and toured the facilities of 4 stellar manufacturers referred by our design partners
We've produced and tested multiple prototypes and will be testing more before shipping
We will maintain constant communication with our manufacturer to promote on-time delivery and resolve any challenges that arise

Shipping We have negotiated warehouse space in both the UK and the US, and will be shipping the bottles globally as soon as we receive them
Other Ways You Can Help
If you want to support the project, but don't want a bottle, help us get the word out! Share our campaign on social media, start a conversation about ocean plastic with a friend, or support Plastic Bank and the amazing work they are doing. 
Your feedback is also greatly appreciated. 
Looking for more information or have a question? Check out our FAQ - which reaches to the moon and back.

story:
Who We Are

CACALENEL CAR SA NIMA (CCSN) is a community based organization at San Miguel Village Belize that conserves the upper Rio Grande River.  The river literally flows in the middle of the village, a community of about 800 Q'eqchi' Maya people.

Over the years we have been engaging residents to value the river by maintaining living environmentally friendly habits along the river.  We have been particularly engaging young people in tree planting, river cleanups, summer camps, and lately a textbook scholarship program.

Yes a textbook scholarship program.  After all, if we engage young people, it’s only right that we find a way to help them with their education.  That is the reason the CCSN textbook Scholarship program started: A blend between education and nature.  These high school students commit to community service by helping CCSN with its conservation activities, so that one day they can value the importance of our environment and development. 

CCSN has been coordinating river-friendly activities in the community for eleven years now and we can say for sure that we have brought immense awareness about the importance of watersheds in our daily lives.

 

Our Campaign

CCSN Textbook Scholarship program is a textbook program only that assists 5 students per year.  We started with our very first recipients in 2014, who are now going to third form at two high schools in the Toledo District: Julian Cho Technical High School and Toledo Community College.  Now that we are three years into the program, we now have a total of 15 students, it’s definitely growing!

This campaign though will enable CCSN to purchase all textbooks for 5 students at third form, the pioneers of the program.  The textbooks they had left behind will be used by the new students enrolled in the program.  However, this campaign will also purchase books that are added on the book list for 1st and 2nd year students as well. 

By next year, we expect to have 20 students in the program and perhaps make it an official scholarship foundation!

What We Need

Textbooks $250/student x 5 third year students = $1250

Indiegogo Fees = $200

Fulfillment of perks = $250

Additional new textbooks for forms 1 and 2 = $300

TOTAL= $2000

 

Our Thanks

Because you care about education like we do, we will offer Maya souvenirs to show our appreciation.  These include Maya baskets, T-shirts, embroidery and other special gifts.  However, the most important gift is when the students you help make it eventually with a high school diploma in their hand with smiling faces.

 

Other ways you can help

If you cannot help financially, there are other ways even more valuable that you can help.  You can share the link with a friend, post it on your facebook page, email someone, or just follow us on our facebook page. 

 

Regards:

story:
My Story

My name is Kailash Cook. I am 12 years old. I grew up on a small island in the Gulf of Thailand with my little sister and my parents. Koh Tao was home and a special place to grow up. I loved the ocean, swimming among the coral reef and tropical fish.

I started diving when I was three and was immediately drawn to the reef. The wonders of the animals that lived there astounded me so much that when I was four, I replicated an entire reef using play doh.

It wasn’t cartoon characters which plastered my walls with, nor were my bed covers decorated with Superman and Batman. Instead, marine creatures and coral took these rolls. They were my heroes growing up.

As I grew older and became more comfortable in the water, I tagged along with my dad on the conservation work he was doing to protect the coral reefs. I learned they were in trouble from our actions and I felt like I should do something about it.

Koh Tao receives more than half a million visitors each year coming to visit the beautiful reefs and the colorful fish. That’s a lot of people on the small reef! Some might say it is too many and they are right.  There are too many people coming to this small 21km2 island that the coral reefs are getting overrun.

Koh Tao seems like a microcosm of the world and the issues faced there are reflective of what is happening on a global scale.

Inspired to find solutions to these problems facing the coral reefs globally, I worked with local conservation teams Eco Koh Tao & Save Koh Tao. Together we have been working for years now on a lot of projects to try and help the coral reefs around Koh Tao. Our work has included:

·  Informing & educating visitors about the importance and the fragility of the reef

·  Monitoring of reefs to quantify ecosystem health and identify threatened areas

·  Restoring threatened or endangered species (Specifically corals and giant clams)

·  Protecting natural reefs from over-exploitation by designing and developing custom designed training locations for novice divers to reduce pressure on natural reef

·  Managing invasive species and explosive populations of marine creatures that threaten the reef

One of my favourite projects has been the construction of custom-designed underwater training  for new divers that have turned into underwater gardens exploding with colour and life. It is the kind of diversity that we could never have hoped for. 


Over the past 18 months I along with my dad a bunch of volunteers have been researching how artificial reefs compare to surrounding natural reefs. The aim of my research is to confirm the viability of these locations as perfect refuges and breeding grounds for the restoration and recovery of biodiversity that may eventually aid the recovery of threatened natural reefs.

Eventually, we hope to develop protocols & guidelines for reef restoration based on my research which proves the ideas as being usable in developing countries with limited financial resources. Conservation is often overshadowed by economics but we believe the two can be complimentary and visitors will enjoy the benefits of such conservation work and consequently support such efforts. 

The aim is to complete my research and present my findings on the world stage at the 13th International Coral Reef Symposium (ICRS) in Hawaii in 2016.


Why is this research important?

Coral reefs exist throughout the tropics and it’s not just Koh Tao that is affected. Many reefs around the world are being pressured by human activity. But it is reparable; you just need the right knowledge and a little will power.  By presenting this research, I hope to show the world that we can save the coral reefs, it’s not too late. Furthermore this research will provide building blocks to make it happen on a more widespread basis.


Where Does this Money go?

The money raised will go to funding the following…





Risks & Challenges

There is a risk that funding is incomplete however we believe that our campaign will be successful to support the goals I hold so dear to my heart.

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand than not everyone can contribute actual cash. But that doesn't mean you can't help spread the word:

·  Send out an email to your friends or personal network telling them that YOU support this awesome project and they can help make this happen! Emails magically produce contributions. So share this campaign through your personal email network.

·  Post this on Facebook...and Twitter...and Instagram...and all those newfangled social media sites that we don't even know about.

With thanks to our supporters....

story:
The Environmental Visual Communication post-graduate program

The environmental movement in Canada is at a crossroads. Decades of considerable action by non-governmental organizations, concerned scientists, and citizens have helped identify the extent of the crisis as well as proposed solutions, but the beat of the development drum largely drowns out this progress.

We cannot let this course continue, and we need new strategies to accelerate the adoption of serious conservation goals and targets in Canada.

The students of the Environmental Visual Communication (EVC) program need a platform to bring their work to Canadian decision-makers and influencers. The class of 2013 is the second cohort to take the program; 16 diverse individuals want to have a greater impact with their work and turn their graduating event into a legacy affair that ensures that their contribution reaches an influential audience. Each cohort hosts an Annual Gala event at the Royal Ontario Museum (ROM) to showcase the best examples of effective environmental visual communications in practice. This year the target is to have 144 influencers from non-profit organizations, environmental publications, design and media firms, universities and colleges, and philanthropists in attendance on Tuesday, October 29th, from 6:30 to 9:30 pm, in the c5 Restaurant Lounge at the ROM. 

Torrent2013: [un]natural interruption

We have pooled our creative energy and come up with a name and concept for this year’s event. Torrent2013: [un]natural interruption reflects our vision for what environmental visual communication can and needs to be.

Effective communication is like magic, and storytelling is at the centre of winning hearts and minds. After decades of environmental decline, it is clear that we need better storytellers. We are here to change the current conversation and spark accelerated action.

How can we accomplish this?

We will act as an [un]natural interruption. Industry currently does a better job at storytelling than the environmental movement. We’re here to change that - when communicating effectively, we do make an impact, and we need to scale up this effect. Environmentalists, conservationists, and scientists are calling for their messages to become more visible and need allies to make this possible.

Effective visual communication makes issues relatable and understandable to everyone. Images are more powerful than text, and can be used in unique and creative ways to bring issues to the public’s attention. We are pioneering the best practices of strategic communications for use across the environmental sector.

Environmental visual communication is the new current. Contemporary culture is showing that it is cool to be into the environment - the time for doom and gloom messaging and awareness raising is over. We are about building relationships with Canadians because they care, and if we communicate with them effectively, they will act.

What We Need & What You Get

Your contribution enables us to make Torrent2013 an inspiring event, and produce a video series that will expand its impact beyond the people in attendance on the evening of October 29th.

Funds raised will go towards event logistics including keynote speaker fees, audio-visual rentals, and venue costs (since Torrent2013 will be a free event); as well as the production of a video series featuring interviews with innovators in attendance.

We plan to document the event and invite selected attendees to participate in EVC Insights, a video series for distribution on our website and social media channels. As practitioners in this newly developing field of communications, EVC faculty and students seek to become leaders in advancing the discourse around effective environmental communications and distributing this message to our intended audiences.

Funds raised above our $2500 goal will be used to support the production of the EVC Insights video series.

Please join us as collaborators in bringing this event to life - we couldn’t do it without you. Torrent2013 will be a free event, and we hope that all backers in the Toronto area will attend, so we can meet you in person!

story:
WPD2014
On March 16, 2011, a horrific environmental disaster occurred at the most remote inhabited island group in the world, Tristan da Cunha, that threatened the second largest concentration of seabirds in the world.

Marine scientist Dr. David E. Guggenheim, president of the Washington, DC-based nonprofit organization, Ocean Doctor, was aboard a ship that received a distress call from a Maltese freighter that had run aground at Nightingale Island. The catastrophic oil spill that ensued was captured on film, and Dr. Guggenheim has turned that footage into a film that explores this tragedy and others like it, as a warning signal and call to action to prevent future tragedies and prepare local managers for any that might occur.

The wreck unleashed a catastrophic oil spill at the doorstep of the second largest concentration of seabirds in the world, home to 65 percent of the world’s population of the endangered Northern Rockhopper penguin. Beloved and iconic, it is a surprise to many that most penguin species are in trouble and have declined by as much as 90 percent since the 1950s. Equally surprising is a growing global threat, hiding in plain sight: The common cargo vessel, whose dismal safety record is proving over and over again that it doesn’t take a supertanker or oil well blowout to create an oil spill disaster.


The film reveals why the disaster occurred, its unthinkable aftermath, and how such “statistically impossible” disasters aren’t nearly as impossible as we once thought.

Past Screenings:
  • April 25, 2013: World Penguin Day Event (Washington, DC) — Sneak Preview
  • May 13, 2013: 4th Blue Vision Summit (Washington, DC) — Sneak Preview
  • November 1-3, 2013: 5th Artisan Festival International – World Peace Initiative (Hamptons, NY)
  • October 19-26, 2013: Cine’Eco – International Environmental Film Festival of Serra da Estrela (Seia, Portugal)
  • October 15-20, 2013: 4th Annual New York Wildlife Conservation Film Festival (New York, NY)
Upcoming Screenings:
  • May 6, 2014: International Oil Spill Conference (Savannah, Georgia)*
  • June 6-11, 2014: EcoCinema 2014 Film Festival (Israel)
  • October 30-November 2, 2014: American Conservation Film Festival (Shepardstown, West Virginia)*
  • November 3-9, 2014: BLUE Ocean Film Festival (St. Petersburg, Florida)*
Now Ocean Doctor is working to share the message around the United States and the world by bringing the film conferences, film festivals, communities and schools. Trevor Glass, Director of the Department of Conservation for Tristan da Cuhna, co-authored a paper with Dr. Guggenheim that has been accepted to the International Oil Spill Conference in Savannah, Georgia in May 2014. Included in the paper's recommendations  is the importance of supporting resource managers in remote locations which are especially vulnerable to disasters around the world.

Ocean Doctor would like to bring Trevor to the United States this fall to participate in the American Conservation Film Festival and BLUE Ocean Film Festival, meet with environmental agencies and decisionmakers in Washington, DC and make presentations in schools. The funds will also be used to print copies of the DVD for distribution to groups interesting in hosting screenings. Please help us raise funds to spread this important message and share the tragedy in hopes that future disasters can be averted and also so local managers can be equipped with the tools required to mitigate the impacts of such tragedies.

In order for Trevor to visit the United States, he must endure a week-long journey by boat from Tristan da Cuhna to South Africa (Tristan has no airport.) followed by a 16-hour plane journey. Travel from remote areas of the world is a lengthy process and quite expensive. We'll house and feed him while he's with us and take him on an east coast tour of schools and fora with the goal of reaching people and inspiring them to take action for penguins and ecosystems.


This limited-edition Ocean Doctor Penguin T-shirt, featuring our favorite, the Northern Rockhopper Penguin. Get this T-shirt, along with a signed DVD and your name in the credits for a contribution of $100 or more.

* Pending confirmation

story:
Short Summary

     James and Duane Sanders are brothers. James is a U.S Disabled Veteran and Duane is a Retirement Investment Advisor.  James and Duane have always had innovative minds and have the ability to make their ideas materialize.  A perfect example of that is the SRT Sprinkler Removal Tool that comes in two sizes, (the SRT 1000 for sprinklers with tops 1 3/4" to 2 1/4" in diameter and the SRT 2000 for sprinklers with tops 2 1/2" to 2 3/4" in diameter) that they have a Utility Patent pending on and currently have local retailers including a number of nationally known ACE Hardware Stores. 

     This direct sales campaign is two fold: one, to inform Sprinkler System owners across the nation that this tremendous lawn tool exists and two, to raise the funding required for equipment that will allow mass production of the SRT. The SRT allows one to quickly remove and replace pop-up lawn sprinklers versus having to use a shovel to dig the broken sprinkler up which leaves a circle of dead grass and disturbed soil in your lawn.  The SRT grips the top of the sprinkler and enables one to unscrew it from the riser below the surface and twist it right out of the ground leaving a perfectly formed hole for the installation of a new sprinkler.

     The intent of this campaign is to inform individuals who work on sprinkler systems and sprinkler system owners across the nation that this Brand New Lawn Tool exists and is available to them immediately through this campaign.  The SRT literally allows one to "Leave the shovel in the tool shed and use the SRT instead" when repairing broken sprinkler heads.

What We Need & What You Get

     Through this campaign, we need to raise $22,500.00. The funds will be used for the needed equipment to facilitate the mass production of the SRT.  This equipment will help in creating much needed jobs right here at home as well as help meet the demand for the SRT Sprinkler Removal Tool in making it available to folks all across this great nation.

     There are several options when purchasing the SRT:  The “Do it Yourselfer” is the purchase of one SRT (either model, the SRT 1000 or the SRT 2000), this option is for the person that likes to do things for themselves;  The “Gang Buster” is the purchase of six SRTs (3 SRT 1000 and 3 SRT 2000), this option is for the sprinkler repair guy that wants to make his job more efficient – saving time, making more money and wanting to better satisfy their customers by not leaving circles of dead grass and destabilized soil behind; The “Go Getter” is the purchase of a display of 12 SRTs (8 model 1000 and 4 model 2000) this option comes with a display suitable for point of purchase sales, this is for the one who wants to be one of the first Retailers in the United States to introduce this Brand New, One of a Kind Lawn Tool to the market; and fourth, the “Entrepreneur” is the purchase of twenty four (24) SRTs (or more), this is for the student or the person who wants to sell directly and perform live demonstrations and show folks just how incredible this lawn tool is. The entrepreneurs determine their own sales price. Any option that you choose - You won’t go wrong. People get excited about the SRT Sprinkler Removal Tool when it is demonstrated.  With over 1000 sold, not a single one has been returned.  The SRT is made from U.S. steel and is manufactured to last a lifetime.

     If this campaign falls short of its funding goal, the funds received will be put aside until the additional funds are acquired for the funding of the special equipment needed.

The Impact

     If you have ever had to replace a broken sprinkler, you know what a chore it can be and the mess it leaves when having to dig a broken sprinkler up with a shovel.  The SRT Sprinkler Removal Tool makes the job Quick, Easy and Clean. When the SRT is used to remove and replace a lawn sprinkler it leaves a perfectly trimmed installed sprinkler head behind. NO MESS and NO Disturbed soil around the replaced sprinkler. The SRT usually takes less than a couple of minutes to use and will save you more money the first time you use it than what it costs to purchase it.

     The most common comment we get from people who have purchased the SRT Sprinkler Removal Tool is:

“It worked exactly the way you told me it would!”

 

Other Ways You Can Help

     You may not have a need for a SRT Sprinkler Removal Tool at present – that’s ok, we still need your help. Kindly hit the share button and forward this campaign to your FaceBook friends and the folks on your email list. Tell your Family, Friends and Neighbors about this tremendous lawn tool. By doing this, one day when you do need to replace a broken lawn sprinkler, you will be able to go to your Local Hardware Store or come back to our website  www.pciAbility.com and purchase the "One and only SRT Sprinkler Removal Tool."

       

               THANK YOU!

            Duane and James
story_txt:
Short Summary
     James and Duane Sanders are brothers. James is a U.S Disabled Veteran and Duane is a Retirement Investment Advisor.  James and Duane have always had innovative minds and have the ability to make their ideas materialize.  A perfect example of that is the SRT Sprinkler Removal Tool that comes in two sizes, (the SRT 1000 for sprinklers with tops 1 3/4" to 2 1/4" in diameter and the SRT 2000 for sprinklers with tops 2 1/2" to 2 3/4" in diameter) that they have a Utility Patent pending on and currently have local retailers including a number of nationally known ACE Hardware Stores. 
     This direct sales campaign is two fold: one, to inform Sprinkler System owners across the nation that this tremendous lawn tool exists and two, to raise the funding required for equipment that will allow mass production of the SRT. The SRT allows one to quickly remove and replace pop-up lawn sprinklers versus having to use a shovel to dig the broken sprinkler up which leaves a circle of dead grass and disturbed soil in your lawn.  The SRT grips the top of the sprinkler and enables one to unscrew it from the riser below the surface and twist it right out of the ground leaving a perfectly formed hole for the installation of a new sprinkler.
     The intent of this campaign is to inform individuals who work on sprinkler systems and sprinkler system owners across the nation that this Brand New Lawn Tool exists and is available to them immediately through this campaign.  The SRT literally allows one to "Leave the shovel in the tool shed and use the SRT instead" when repairing broken sprinkler heads.

story:
• My name is Trace Cummings and I'm a small town kid with large, silly dreams.
  • Beginning in March, I hope to be able to ride my bike from my hometown in southern Indiana to the Indiegogo headquarters in California, planting trees and camping along the way. 

If the goal of $2500 is not reached, then the trip will not be happening. However, all of the proceeds will still be donated to www.testicularcancersociety.org


Other Ways You Can Help


If, for some reason, you cannot donate but still want to help, feel free to spread the word by sharing this campaign on all social media sites. You can also share it using Indiegogo's share tools!

If you want to help, but don't like any of the perk options, you can also order a one of a kind Johnny Appleseed Project t-shirt here!

story:
WHO AM I? 

  • Junior at Seattle Pacific University
  • Major: Applied Human Biology
  • Career goal: Surgery in Emergency/Trauma medicine
  • Officer and future Co-President of SPU MAPS (Medical Association of Pre-Health Students)
  • Executive Board Member of SPU's Up 'Till Dawn raising funds for St.Jude Children's Hospital
  • Passion for diversity and volunteering in underserved communities

WHAT AM I RAISING MONEY FOR?

  • Mission Trip to the Dominican Republic costs $3,500 
  • Cost will cover my immunizations, airfare, visa, travel health insurance, housing, food, training, debriefing, transportation within the host country, and other activity/program expenses

WHEN WILL THIS TAKE PLACE?

  • June 17, 2013 - July6, 2013

WHERE WILL THIS TAKE PLACE?

  • In 3 Batey Communities Near Barahona, Dominica Republic

WHY AM I RAISING FUNDS?

  • Malaria Control
  1. Place ProVector mosquito control devices in the communities
  2. ProVector is a flower-like device containing a substance that attracts mosquitoes. Once mosquitoes feed on the substance the chemicals will kill them.
  3. CNN Video on ProVectors placed in Kenya http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VwX9Ta3sJOA
  4. Malaria is prevalent in the DR causing many deaths among families especially children
  5. Our goal is to reduce and eradicate malaria in the communities
  • Community Education
  1. Provide ProVector device training for each household 
  2. Batey communities, home to marginalized Haitian immigrants are not recognized as citizens by the Dominican Republic government and therefore have NO ACCESS to social services such as education or health care
  3. Our goal is to educate the community on malaria prevention so that they will pass on their knowledge to their children and villages around them to stop the spread of the illness
  • Clinic Visits
  1. See what health care is like in a third world country and use that experience in my future interactions with patients as a medical provider

HOW CAN YOU HELP?

  • Donate money to help me help others 
  • Send good thoughts and prayers for our safety, open minds, open hearts, that we would serve with humility and a desire to engage in the culture

Please join in me on my journey as i prepare to serve and work together with the families in the Dominican Republic.

Thank you! <3

Nichole Montinola
