Near Steamboat Lake State Park, north central Colorado.Global Warming Psychology -- Adventure, Discovery and Intrigue: The Solution to Climate PollutionWe break the obvious news that yes, 30 years of delay has made climate change much worse and far more risky. The delay has largely been caused by what research at Drexel and Stanford Universities label the Climate Change Counter Movement (CCCM), whose $900 million in annual funding has destroyed trust in climate scientists. (1) To restore trust and finally implement climate pollution reform, global warming psychology says "Foremost, be innovative." This film uses the psychology of adventure, discovery and intrigue, delivered with music and beauty, to discover the truth in disparaged science, and portray the simple solutions, dismissed due to mistrust.The messaging campaign? The psychology says that because climate change has never happened to our advanced civilization before, we do not understand what will happen. We have no memory of what we need to do. Because we do not know how to behave, unfamiliarity inhibits deep thought. Fear, paranoia, skepticism, doubt and delay are the result. For trust in climate science to return, new and unique communications strategies are needed. Our polar bears and messages, our prose and our images, and especially our music--good old rock, blues, jazz and folk--all embody this new psychology. Our BackgroundThe Climate Change Now Initiative is the oldest independent climate science education organization in the world. Founded in 2005, We specialize in reporting the latest climate science discoveries directly from academia, field investigation of climate impacts happening now, and global warming psychology. Bruce Melton, our principle resource, is a professional engineer, environmental researcher, and climate science outreach specialist with over 30 years of experience in critical environmental issues. Our knowledge base, films, images, and music are at ClimateDiscovery.org.Grand Teton National Park: A native bark beetle driven berserk because of warming is abruptly changing 89 million acres across North America into something different. Click on the image for a high resolution image to see the redkill on the flanks of Grand Teton, the tallest peak.Climate Change Today: Not What You ThinkThe Climate Change Counter Movement has destroyed the ability of climate scientists to communicate not only their most important recent discoveries, but the simple basics too. With full implementation Paris Commitments of 80 percent emissions reductions, our climate warms, not cools, by up to triple what we have already endured, in just the next 35 to 45 years, and warming quintuples by 2100. (2)Climate scientists told us 30 years ago that if we did not act promptly there would be trouble, and this is where we find ourselves today. The delay has now allowed initiation of abrupt changes up to 100 years ahead of, and 100 times more extreme than projections by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change. (3)South Padre Island, non-storm conditions: During the Spring and King Tides, beaches around the world are under water. The reason we don't hear about it more is that the beaches that almost everyone visits are artificially nourished with dredged sand.Abrupt Change: The New Era of Climate Pollution The West Antarctic Ice Sheet is collapsing. The Gulf Stream is shutting down. The Amazon has flipped from a carbon sink to a carbon source. (4, 5, 6)  These are not distant future climate change horrors stories. Thirty years of delay has taken its toll. These abrupt changes (and more) are all happening now and the science has been masked by this extraordinary debate caused by the CCCM. This "movement" has engendered so much doubt--even among believers--that warnings from the scientific community go unheeded, unheard, and  wrongly believed as being some part of a "natural cycle." This film, and the Climate Change Now Initiative, specialize in communicating the badly maligned basics, and poorly communicated recent discoveries.Dirt on the Greenland Ice Sheet from record melt in 2012, 32 miles onto the ice near Kangerlussuaq, 20 miles north  of the Arctic Circle.The dirt is eons of accumulated dust from as far away as Siberia and the biggest lake is almost a half mile across.  Google Digitalglobe, U.S. Geological Survey 2012. (link)Graciously, There Is Good News The same strategies that have created the disconnection between climate science and the rest of us have masked new discoveries about solutions. But climate scientists have basically had 30 years to research the solutions. We now have proven, cheap and unambiguous technologies to take excess carbon dioxide pollution directly out of our sky and make up for the difference that emissions reductions strategies, decarbonization, agricultural techniques, bio energy carbon capture and sequestration (BECCS), and all of the other strategies combined together cannot accomplish. (7) The 2013 IPCC even thought these technologies were important enough to include in their Summary for Policy Makers: "climate change resulting from CO2 emissions is irreversible on a multi-century to millennial time scale, except in the case of a large net removal of CO2 from the atmosphere over a sustained period."In other words, we have to remove "largely" more than we emit every year. "Paris" is only reductions in emissions. We must remove more CO2 from the sky than we emit every year--largely more, regardless of costs. Fortunately, the costs are as manageable as many, many different things we do in our society every year.Carbon Engineering, Squamish, British Columbia: This first of its kind industrial scale facility uses WW II technology that kept our sailors alive in submarines by cleaning carbon dioxide from the air with lye.But the Climate Change Counter Movement has brought action to a standstill. We have the engineers to do the job, we have the emission reductions strategies to decarbonize our economy, but we cannot muster the will. If we can take action--almost immediately--and remove enough of the excess CO2 from our sky, abrupt changes that are initiating now will reverse. Failure to act however, as per NOAA in 2016, will result in ten feet of sea level rise in just the next 35 to 45 years. (8)  To break the stranglehold we need global warming psychology. If we can overcome this astonishingly ironic deadlock, we can fix the problem for as little money as we spend on advertising across the planet every year. (9)Global Thermostat, Menlo Park California. First generation designer amine process for removing carbon dioxide from the air. At this early stage of development this technology can remove 1 ton of CO2 for $75 using waste heat. As solar energy falls to $0.01 kWh by 2025 (it's $0.07 kWh now), costs will plummet.What We Do, What This Film Will DoAdventure, Discovery, Intrigue:  Global warming psychology says to show viewers what's really happening in the world. So we get out and get dirty. We go to where it is and bring it back. In July 2017, we depart for field work on the West Coast--with or without funding, although with a much reduced scope of work without funding. The challenge now is abrupt change, not the relatively slow 2100 projections that we have been practicing for. This is why our work is so important.To finally create action, the psychology says: Simplify communications. Minimize ambiguity. Instill trust in our scientists. Don't create fear. Create learning through innovation. Tell a story. Relate, don't dictate. Reveal the innocence of reality and magnitude of risk. Invite participation. And fundamentally, combine science with entertainment: If they aren't in their seats, they aren't listening.The most important part of our platform is our Knowledge Base and over 400 interpretations of academic literature almost completely unknown outside academia.  It's this knowledge base that our films and music are based upon. Climate change is out there and it is far more meaningful than we have been drilled into believing. It's also a rare, beautiful, and fascinating thing to behold. Abrupt changes have never happened to our advanced civilization, or even to our species, in time frames that matter. It's out there where you least expect it, more fantastic than can be imagined, waiting to be experienced.~ ~ ~ We Bring It! ~ ~ ~The Climate Change Now Initiative 501c3 was founded in 2005, – ClimateDiscovery.org -- Over 400 reports on the latest most critical science, innovative filmwork and good old blues, rock and folk music, that tells the complete story of climate change.Music Can Sooth The Climate BeastWhy music? It's innovative and global warming psychology says to communicate in ways that have not been tried before. Music is the universal language. Music heals. It relates through a different part of the brain. The psychology says this is good, our old pathways have become inured. Think about the blues. It's all bad in the blues, but we enjoy the blues as music. So, why not present climate change through music? And besides, how else would an organization from Austin do it?!The band has been together since 2002. We love the blues. This film will sooth your soul. It uses the advanced global warming psychology technique of presenting through the lens of music. The redkill pine forest above is a common site across the American West. Usually blamed on natural occurrence by unsuspecting news people victimized by the Climate Change Counter Movement and their insistence on "fair and balanced" reporting,  these are actual abrupt climate change impacts, that have happen every time our climate changed abruptly. Climate Change Across America Field Work 2017In 2015 and 2016 we completed 15,000 miles of filming, observing beetle kill in the Rockies, drought kill in Texas, all sorts of mortality in the Chihuahuan Desert, and sea level rise and dune erosion on the Padre Island wilderness beach--the world's longest barrier island. Another 15,000 miles in the U.S. and Canada is on the books for summer and fall 2017, plus an all important trip to Greenland. This work builds upon our previous two films, The Ice and the Sea, Abrupt Climate Change Happening Now (2008) (22,000 views!) and What Have We Done: The North American Pine Beetle Pandemic (2009).  This new 15,000 miles of fieldwork has four focus areas:
Document the effect of West Coast beetle kill in the Sierra Nevada and Cascades after their record drought, focusing on the  most vulnerably high altitude areas.
Visit leading atmospheric carbon dioxide removal scientists and showcase their advanced work on industrial scale field trials with Global Thermostat, Carbon Engineering and associated scientists from Columbia University, University of Arizona, University of Calgary, and Carnegie Mellon University.
Film the Big Melt again in Greenland, retracing our 2007 expedition path from Point 660 on the edge of the ice sheet near Kangerlussuaq, where melt has been as high as 30 feet per year, to the Jakobshavn Icefjord and the most prolific glacier in the world near Ilulissat. 
Film sea level rise impacts during the King Tides in October between the Outer Banks of North Carolina and South Padre Island, Texas, via Key West, Florida.
Global Warming T-shirt Psychology Messaging CampaignBecause we have never experienced meaningful climate change before, it's an innate response to the unknown to be suspicious, doubting and even fearful. This inhibits deep thought. After seeing the plight of the polar bear for going on 30 years now, the polar bear image has become ingrained in our minds as being related to climate change. Global warming psychology says that even just the sight of a climate change icon initiates thought in our brains. As neurons blink, our minds grow more comfortable with the topic. As our comfort levels increase, our ability to have rational thought increases too, and the tactics of the Climate Change Counter Movement can be defeated!You can see more about the psychology here at our almost completed eCommerce site. The site is not fully functional yet, but the catalog is! Soon, all of our art will be available on all sorts of apparel and climate change gear ~ ~ ~Tax Deductible! or Pay by CheckYes! Tax Deductible, but not through Indiegogo so you need to donate directly to the Climate Change Now Initiative. We are a 501c3 nonprofit charity designated by the IRS and their charitable tax deduction rules apply if you donate directly to us. Our EIN is 90-1006128. You must send your donation directly to us through our Paypal portal, or with a check to: Climate Change Now, 8103 Kirkham, Austin, Texas 78736. Please let us know your check is coming. All perks still apply, let us know -- bmelton@earthlink.net, Subject: "This Land Is Your Land." (512)799-7998.Perks
Updates from the field.
Everyone gets a film download.
Just want to donate? Go to Climate Discovery Support!
Basic Global Warming Psychology Perk -- $25 and $30 -- (See the apparel below) -- Contribute to this effort and get a global warming psychology T-shirt!  Twelve different pieces of art, seven different types of apparel, five colors, and four sizes.Climate Pollution Reform Perk $100 -- If you are going to be in Austin, drop by for band rehearsal! We meet most Friday's at 7, the band usually shows about 7:30! Bring friends ~ ~ ~  (You really don't have to donate to come to rehearsal--just show up!)Team Zero (Climate Consultation) Perk $250 -- Get a consult from our climate change outreach specialist and registered professional engineer B. MeltOn. Do you have a special project, an advocacy challenge, or a pitch that needs something special to set it off? Or a science challenge you need citations for? Or want to know how your personal skills and goals can make the best contribution to the effort?  MeltOn has been an engineering consultant for 30 years and knows what to do.Policy Wonk Perk $500 -- Digital Images -- Get all of our Supporter Perk images (below) in digital files to use in a screen saver for your computer with the built in Windows 10 screen saver. If you haven't found this on Windows 10 yet, we will help you set it up too! Supporter Perk $1,000 -- Large Format Fine Art Photograph (See the prints below) -- Supporters get a large format 24" x 36" fine art print of climate change happening now, and their name or their organization in the credits with special thanks. The prints are meant for framed display and use the finest 200 year archival inks and paper. A detailed description of each image is in the Indiegogo content (below.)Healthy Climate Perk $2,500 -- Ever been to the music capital of the known universe? Come to Austin during South by Southwest (mid-March) and the band will dedicate our SWxSW studio concert to you and your friends. (We are located at the southwestern city limits of Austin, or southwest of weird as we affectionately like to say). It's always a good party, lots of food and friends, and no telling who will show up and jam.Associate Producer Perk $5,000 -- Join us for two days on one of our expeditions this season and help document climate change happening now in some of the most scenic areas in North America. Camping is preferred to get the glory light (we will set you up), but moteling is acceptable. We will feed you. Let us know how many t-shirts you want, and look forward to a draft review of the film late 2017/early 2018.Executive Producer $10,000 -- Meet us for 3 days filming on the ice sheet! Camping is preferred and may be mandatory depending on when your contribution comes in. Greenland is scheduled for late August, before the snows start, after the first freeze. The mosquitoes are gone (yay!), and all the snow is gone to reveal the crevasses (for safety!) This perk is only available if we fully fund. Let us know how many t-shirts you want and look forward to a draft review of the film late 2017 or early 2018 ~ ~ ~Climate Change T-shirtsStandard Apparel $25: Gildan Utlra Cotton 6 oz, Gildan Cotton-Tshirt 5.2 oz, Hanes Women's Nano-T 4.5 oz, Hanes Youth Comfortsoft 5.2 ozVintage Apparel ($30)--Preworn Art, Prefaded Shirt, Extra Psychology: Comfort Colors 6.1 ozSpecial Apparel ($30)-- Extra Style in Ladies Wear: Bella V-neck 4.5 oz, Bella Spaghetti Strap Tank 5.8 oz, Anvil Ladies Light Weight Tank 4.5 oz (Click on the apparel for a larger image--the bolded title is the perk title.)    Andy Surfer Bear Everywhere ($25)Gildan Ultra Cotton 2000 6 ozPreshrunk, 100% Cotton, Heavy WeightAndy Surfer Bear--Change ($25)Gildan Cotton T-shirt 5.3 ozPreshrunk, 100% Cotton, Medium WeightAndy Surfer Bear Really ($25)Hanes Women's Nano-T 4.5 oz, Contemporary FitPreshrunk, 100% Ringspun Cotton, Light WeightAndy B--Climate Change Youth ($25)Hanes Youth Comfortsoft 5.2 ozPreshrunk, 100% Comfortsoft Cotton, Medium WeightAndy Climate Change Vintage ($30)~ ~ ~ Preworn Art ~ ~ ~Comfort Colors 1717 6.1 oz, Preshrunk, Prefaded100% Rignspun Cotton, Soft-washed, Garment-dyedAndy Surfer B Really! Special ($30)Bella Spaghetti Strap Tank 5.8 ozPreshrunk,​ 100% Combed and Ring-spun Cotton Classic Silhouette Slim FitArny Beach Chair Special ($30)Bella V-neck 6005 4.5 oz, Slim FitPreshrunk, 100% Combed and Ringspun CottonAnuk Everywhere Special ($30)(Anuk the six-toed polar bear)Anvil Ladies Tank 4.5 oz, Semi-fitted Contoured SilhouettePreshrunk, 100%  Ringspun Cotton Anuk Six Toes Skeptics are Tasty ($25)Hanes Nano-T 4.5 oz, Contemporary FitPreshrunk, 100% Ringspun Cotton, Light WeightAnuk Climate Change Vintage ($30)(Anuk the six-toed polar bear) ~ ~ ~ Preworn Art ~ ~ ~Comfort Colors 1717 6.1 oz, Preshrunk, Prefaded100% Rignspun Cotton, Soft-washed, Garment-dyedPenguins 4 Everywhere Special ($30)Anvil Ladies Tank 4.5 oz, Semi-fitted Contoured SilhouettePreshrunk, 100%  Ringspun Cotton Penguins 12 Weather Special ($30)Bella V-neck 6005 4.5 oz, Slim FitPreshrunk, 100% Combed and Ringspun CottonClimate Change is Everywhere Perk ($1,000)~ ~ ~ Fine Art Giclee Prints ~ ~ ~Large format 24" x 36" fine art, high resolution photography, the finest 200 year archival inks, and semi-gloss archival paper. Borderless or with a border for matting. With or without caption.Supporter -- Teton Red...  At the foot of the Tetons, the beetle has impacted less than half the trees. The same can't be said for the white pine in the greater Yellowstone ecosystem however. Over 90 percent of this species, which provides a major source of food for grizzlies, were wiped out.Supporter -- Groundhog Park, Spruce Beetle Attack... This astonishing attack took out 100,000 acres in three years beginning 2012. It's in south Central Colorado in the La Garita Mountains above 11,000 feet. The peak in the background is Mesa Mountain, elevation 12,944 feet. This forest is (was) almost all Englemann spruce except for the fringe along the road of young blue spruce, which are less susceptible to the spruce beetle than the mature Englemanns.Supporter -- Underice River, Point 660... Point 660 is WW II code for this remote area that is literally at the end of the longest road in Greenland (only 18 miles long!). The underice river is at the heart of the area that is melting the fastest in Greenland, at up to 30 vertical feet per year. It's along the west coast, 200 miles south of the Arctic Circle, east from Kangerlussuaq, or Bluie West as this vitally important airfield was known in WWII.Supporter -- Padre Mile 11, Surf in the Dunes, South Padre Sea Level Rise...  Apply named The Narrows, at mile 13 beyond the end of pavement the four-wheel drive trail disappears into the surf. Sea level rise during normal high tides has outpaced the natural beach regeneration process, and beach disintegration has begun.Supporter -- Padre Mile 14, Missing BeachSouth Padre Mile 14...  Normal high tide on South Padre Island. At the turn of the century, the beach on most of Padre during normal, non storm high tides, was one to two hundred feet wide, with some places greater than 300 feet.Supporter -- Padre Mile 15, Beach Erosion... Up South Padre, in the pristine wilderness beyond the end of the road, the beach is almost gone. Erosion from sea level rise during non-storm conditions has overwhelmed the natural beach regenerative process.Supporter -- PINS Mile 50, Padre Island National Seashore, 50 miles beyond the four-wheel drive only sign... Sand starvation from dams on rivers and natural subsidence from sediment compaction are challenging enough for our beaches. Add sea level rise and the beach disintegration threshold has already been passed in critical areas like this one where the beach is non-existent at high tide.Supporter -- The Flats, Padre Island National Seashore... They are (were) located on the back side of Padre Island and were once nearly a mile wide at the widest. These flats disappeared with the sea level jump along the Texas Coast in 2013, and then again in 2016. This time they may be gone for good.Supporter -- RMNP Westgate, Rocky Mountain National Park Westgate Entry Monument... the mountain pine bark beetle, dendroctonus ponderosae, has devastated the western half of Rocky Mountain National Park. All total, 89 million acres had been consumed across the American West with 60 to 90 percent mortality by 2013 when the attack began to wain. Now, spruce beetles, fir beetles and budworms are attacking across the West in epidemic proportions.Supporter -- Ice Sheet Muskoxe... The massive Greenland Ice Sheet overhangs its terminal moraine east of Kangerlussuaq, near the Arctic Circle. The distinct boundary between dirty and clean ice was caused by an abrupt climate change. The white ice overides darker ice from an ice age pulse where windier conditions created dirtier ice. The ice on the left remains in equilibrium because it overhangs the terminal moraine. On the right, recent ice sheet retreat is evident.What'll We Do If We Don't Get Funded?Continue on of course. Melton has been funding this work from his meager engineering revenues for a dozen years, but it's a lot more difficult today. Melton Engineering's traditional land development clients have evaporated after learning Melton was an evil environmentalist. But Melton Engineering was rebranded in 2013 to cater to residential and commercial clients who have been impacted by the repeated rainbombs in Central Texas.After the rebranding, there was enough revenue to fund 7,500 miles a year of filming in 2015 and 2016 and this will probably be the case in 2017 without additional funding. But because of abrupt change initiation, we don't have the time remaining to delay and certainly not the funds to do 15,000 miles this year and get to Greenland. Please get a T-shirt or twelve and help save the world! Most important: Share on Facebook and Twitter.Production Regardless of funding, we will get a short film out about the successful industrial scale direct air capture processes by this fall. If we make our goal, fingers crossed to make the film festival entries in spring 2018.The band is going into production in August or September, depending on Greenland.Another tour we have planned if we don't get fully funded is a 4x4 trek up and down Padre Island during the King Tide in October. It's just a few hours from Austin and can be executed with just engineering revenues. The beach was closed at Padre Island National Seashore due to high water five times during non storm conditions in 2016.Bottom line: if we do not reach our funding goal, there's still Melton Engineering. There is no reason why we would stop now. This is too important. We'll get there, but it will not likely to be until 2019. So tell your friends. Abrupt change waits for nobody.Other Ways You Can Help!
Share on social media! Create viralness!
Email your contacts and ask them to tell their close by social media maniacs to share. 
Talk about climate change. Get those neurons blinking.
Talk to those who are receptive. Talking to others is not very productive. Maximize the efficiency of your efforts.
Vote! Vote for the only issue that is the most important our civilization has ever faced!
Volunteer. Pick a climate change activist campaign: Citizens Climate Lobby, Sierra Club, 350.org. Warm bodies are what matters.
Make those calls to your elected leaders. Then repeat until we have a healthy climate.
Most important! Wear your T-shirt.
Even more important! Give lots of T-shirts to friends! Nonprofit Global Warming Psychology! ClimateChangetshirts.org 
  ~ ~ ~ Doing Something About The Weather ~ ~ ~ REFERENCES
Climate Change Counter Movement… From 2003 to 2010, $7 billion in climate change counter-movement funding has been identified from revenues reported in IRS tax returns for 91 of 118 organizations and institutions identified in the academic literature as being involved. The research from Drexel and Stanford concludes: “With delay and obfuscation as their goals, the U.S. CCCM has been quite successful in recent decades. However, the key actors in this cultural and political conflict are not just the “experts” who appear in the media spotlight. The roots of climate-change denial go deeper, because individuals’ efforts have been bankrolled and directed by organizations that receive sustained support from foundations and funders known for their overall commitments to conservative causes. Thus to fully understand the opposition to climate change legislation, we need to focus on the institutionalized efforts that have built and maintain this organized campaign. Just as in a theatrical show, there are stars in the spotlight. In the drama of climate change, these are often prominent contrarian scientists or conservative politicians, such as Senator James Inhofe. However, they are only the most visible and transparent parts of a larger production. Supporting this effort are directors, script writers, and, most importantly, a series of producers, in the form of conservative foundations. Clarifying the institutional dynamics of the CCCM can aid our understanding of how anthropogenic climate change has been turned into a controversy rather than a scientific fact in the U.S.” A criticism of this theory is that the conservative political platform funded also supports other issues such as right to life, reduced government and regulations, illegal immigration, lower taxes and etc. Fundamentally however, because the platform supported by this funding is all encompassing, the entire funding supports climate change denial equally to the other parts of the platform.Brulle 2013, Drexel and Stanford -- Institutionalizing delay: foundation funding and the creation of U.S. climate change counter-movement organizations," December 21, 2013.Melton, Climate Discovery.org -- The Climate Change Counter-Movement: $7 Billion Umbrella, February 17, 2014.Melton, Truthout.org -- Buoyed by Trump, the Climate Change Counter-Movement Gains Momentum, May 19, 2017.Media Bias and the Conservative Media… Work from McGill, Drexel and Bucknell Universities expands on previous work on the causes of the partisan divide among climate science believers. Their findings are that the media have the most important influencing effect on the public mind with the biased coverage of climate science by the most popular politically conservative media outlets carrying the largest load of responsibility.Carmichael et al., The great divide, understanding the role of media and other drivers of the partisan divide in public concern over climate change in the USA, 2001–2014 Climatic Change, January 31, 2017.https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Joanna_Hux...Corporate funding and Climate Change Bias… Work From Yale on 164 organizations identified as being a part of the Climate Change Counter Movement from 1993–2013 evaluated their oral and written outreach of 40,785 texts (written and oral presentations) and more than 39 million words and found that; "organizations with corporate funding were more likely to have written and disseminated texts meant to polarize the climate change issue. Second, and more importantly, that corporate funding influences the actual thematic content of these polarization efforts."Farrell, Corporate funding and ideological polarization about climate change, PNAS, January 5, 2016.http://www.pnas.org/content/113/1/92.full.pdfFairness Bias in Liberal Media… From the University of California Santa Cruz and American University, Boykoff and Boykoff find that not only are conservative media outlets far more likely to vastly downplay climate change risks, but that liberal media outlets too are also more likely to downplay climate change risks. It's has been subsequently labelled the "Fairness Bias" and the way it works is this: in journalists' quest to be fair and present both sides of the story, they feel compelled by their journalistic ethics to report both sides of the story equally and let the consumer determine their own answer. This generally works well with issue based discussions where only morals and ethics are involved. But when facts are involved, and "alternative" facts exist that are supported by only three percent of the climate science community or less, and those facts are presented by the media equally to the 97 percent of climate scientists facts that have been proven true, a conflict results where the consumer bases his or her interpretation on the quantity of information presented. To them, it seems like the science remains unsettled, when the reality is just the opposite.Boykkoff and Boykkoff Balance as bias global warming and the US prestige press Global Environmental Change volume 14 2004.https://www.researchgate.net/publication/248556... 2)    Current Policy doubles to triples warming we have already endured…  The IPCC’s new Representative Concentration Pathway (RCP) scenario of RCP2.6, is basically the same thing as 80 percent emissions reductions by 2050 and is described by the IPCC as a “strong mitigation scenario.” RCP2.6 has CO2 peaking at about 440 ppm between 2050 and 2060 and temperature at 1.5 degree C 30 to 40 years later. The increase of 1.6 degrees C is double the current warming since the 1700s. This increase however is the average increase. The worst-case RCP2.6 warming is 2.7 degrees C or more than triple current warming. Considering the understating nature of the IPCC consensus (See Reference 7), the upper limits should be strongly considered as a distinctly plausible. Under the average RCP2.6 modeling and 1.6 degrees of warming with aggressive emissions reductions, the concentration of CO2 in our atmosphere does not fall below today’s level until after 2150, and does not return to preindustrial era temperature until long after the year 3000. Under the most extreme RCP2.6 limits with 2.7 degrees of warming above preindustrial times, Earth’s temperature does not fall below our current temperature for well over a 1,000 years.Meinshausen et al., The RCP greenhouse gas concentrations and their extensions from 1765 to 2300, Climatic Change, November 2011, figure 6. http://link.springer.com/article/10.1007%2Fs105...MIT Joint Program on the Science and Policy of Global Change – Results of Paris… With the Paris Agreement fully implemented on schedule, we can expect 3.5 C of warming by 2100 and with additional negative emissions technologies studied of BECSS (bio-energy with carbon capture and storage--not direct air capture) the increase in warming is held back to 2.4 to 2.7 C by 2100. At 2050, Paris alone is 2.1 C warming. 2014 was 0.69 C. The record 2015 and 2016 global average was 0.87 C and 0.94 C. However, 2015 and 2016 were influenced by a record, or near record El Nino, a natural climate fluctuation. Sokolov et al., Scenarios of Global Change - Integrated Assessment of Climate Impacts, MIT Joint Program on the Science and Policy of Global Change, Report 291, February 2016.https://globalchange.mit.edu/sites/default/file... ​3. Abrupt change up to 100 years ahead of schedule and 100 times more extreme than the IPCC projected… It is difficult to quantify how much more extreme abrupt change is than the slow changes projected by the IPCC because of many different things: we have never experienced these types of impacts before (sea level jumps, shut down of the Gulf Stream, Amazon flip from sink to source, dynamic collapse of ice sheets. Their unrecoverable nature lends itself poorly to comparisons with a stable and advanced society. Two illustrations are offered: (A) Antarctic ice loss has begun 100 years ahead of schedule… Antarctic ice loss (surface mass balance, SMB) in the 2007 IPCC Report was supposed to increase, not decrease, for all scenarios, through 2100. This means that snow accumulation was supposed to be more than melt, evaporation and iceberg discharge combined. The 213 IPCC report however, tells us that Antarctic ice loss has already begun,  is substantially large, and approaching the volume of discharge in Greenland.   (B) 100 times more extreme… Abrupt temperature change has occurred 23 times in the last 100,000 years of 9 to 14 degrees F globally and 25 to 35 F in Greenland. The changes generally took decades, but the most extreme occurred in just two to three years. When compared to a world that limits warming to a middle of the road scenario of 3 degrees C (5.4 F) by 2100, 14 F in 2 years is 107 times more extreme.(A) Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, Fourth Assessment Report, Climate Change 2007: Working Group I: The Physical Science Basis, 10.6.5, Projections of Global Average Sea Level Change for the 21st Century, Table 10.7.http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/ch10s10-6-5.html The 2013 IPCC report tells us that Antarctic ice loss has almost caught up with Greenland… Summary for Policy Makers, B.3 Cryosphere, page 9, second and third bullets. http://www.climatechange2013.org/images/report/WG1AR5_SPM_FINAL.pdf(B) Alley, Wally Was Right - Predictive ability of the North Atlantic Conveyor Belt Hypothesis for Abrupt Climate Change, Annual Review of Earth and Planetary Science, February 2007, Figure 1 shows the 23 abrupt climate changes.http://shadow.eas.gatech.edu/~kcobb/abrupt/alley07.pdf Two to three years…  -- see also:Steffensen et al., High-Resolution Greenland Ice Core Data Show Abrupt Climate Change Happens in Few Years, Science Express, June 12 2008, page three, final paragraph.http://www.sciencemag.org/content/321/5889/680.abstract4. The West Antarctic Ice Sheet is collapsing… For a detailed treatment of this topic with 20 references and 30 citations see our article: Collapse of West Antarctic Ice Sheet Reveals Inadequacy of Current Climate Strategies, December 16, 2016. http://www.truth-out.org/news/item/38794-collap... Specific citations for " The West Antarctic ice Sheet is collapsing"…West Antarctic Ice Sheet Collapse Began Shortly After the Turn of the Century… Vaughan summarized the science around West Antarctic Ice Sheet Collapse beginning in 1981. While the mechanisms for ocean melt were present in publication from the early 1990s, it was not until the early 2000s that work first showed definitive evidence of thinning, grounding line retreat, and ice stream acceleration in one of the most sensitive area of West Antarctica, the Amundsen Sea Embayment. Vaughan concludes that if these symptoms are indeed precursors to collapse, then collapse has begun. From what we know today, he was absolutely correct. Vaughan, West Antarctic Ice Sheet collapse – the fall and rise of a paradigm, Climatic Change, 2008, see the abstract.http://www.researchgate.net/publication/2251669...West Antarctic Ice Sheet (WAIS) Collapse Tipping Point Defined… This work out of the German National Science Institute describes marine ice sheet collapse mechanisms, and how there is a very distinct tipping point with the West Antarctic Ice Sheet where collapse becomes irreversible in about 2050. The very important take-away from this work is that to prevent ice sheet collapse the “perturbation” that creates the warming that is responsible for ice sheet collapse, which is mostly ocean warming, must end by at the latest 2050. This means that we must return ocean temperature to its preindustrial stable temperature by 2050. The challenge here is that it is much more difficult to cool the oceans than it is the atmosphere. Figure 3 shows the model runs that define the stable state in blue.Feldmann and Levermann, Collapse of the West Antarctic Ice Sheet after local destabilization of the Amundsen Basin, PNAS, November 17, 2015.http://www.pnas.org/content/112/46/14191.full.pdf Dynamical Ice Sheet Collapse Modeling Arrives… The abstract from DeConto and Pollard states: “model coupling ice sheet and climate dynamics—including previously underappreciated processes linking atmospheric warming with hydrofracturing of buttressing ice shelves and structural collapse of marine-terminating ice cliffs—that is calibrated against Pliocene and Last Interglacial sea-level estimates and applied to future greenhouse gas emission scenarios. Antarctica has the potential to contribute more than a metre of sea-level rise by 2100 and more than 13 metres by 2500, if emissions continue unabated.”DeConto and Pollard, Contribution of Antarctica to past and future sea level rise, Nature, March 31, 2016.Full: http://www.documentcloud.org/documents/2823837-... Recent sea level rise rate jump… Sea level rise from 1900 to 1990 was about 1.5 mm per year and from 1990 to 2010 3.2 mm per year. Since 2010 there seems to have been a another jump in the sea level rise rate that puts it above 5 mm per year based on NOAA’s sea level data.http://www.star.nesdis.noaa.gov/sod/lsa/SeaLeve... Antarctic Ice Shelves Deteriorating Rapidly… Ice shelves buttressing land ice in Antarctica have seen a dramatic decline in volume due to thinning and retreat. As the shelves thin from under ice melt, their ability to cling to surrounding land and grounded ice diminishes and ice flows faster from the interior. Part of the increase in ocean temperatures doing the melting is actually caused by increased sea ice coverage in Antarctica in recent decades. The increased sea ice itself is part of a melt water feedback where less salty (less dense) melt water floats on the surface of the ocean instead of mixing with saltier denser water below. The fresh water freezes faster and is responsible for more sea ice. The combination of increased sea ice and the fresh water cap decreases wind mixing of deep ocean waters into surface waters. This wind mixing is responsible for upwelling cold deep waters so less upwelling means that more heat is trapped in upper ocean waters. It is this upper ocean water that circulates beneath the ice shelves and causes the melt that destabilizes them and increase ice discharge. Paolo et al., Volume loss from Antarctic ice shelves is accelerating, Science Express, March 25, 2016.http://www.ccpo.odu.edu/~klinck/Reprints/PDF/pa... Up to 100 meters (328 feet) of Under Ice Melt per year… The Pine Island Glacier at the Amundsen Sea Embayment, often referred to as the keystone of West Antarctic Ice Sheet Collapse, is thinning from under ice melt at a rate that is up to 100 meters per year (328 feet). The thinning is caused by increased circulation of warming ocean waters because the 3,000 foot-thick glacier has melted up off of its pinning ridge. Ocean circulation can now move far back into the ice sheet feeding the glacier in an over deepened sub glacial trough 30 miles wide extending 100 miles inland.Dutrieux et al., Pine Island glacier ice shelf melt distributed at kilometre scales, The Cryosphere, September 26, 2013.http://www.the-cryosphere.net/7/1543/2013/tc-7-... NOAA's Ice Sheet Collapse Warning… This is an "ostensible" ice sheet collapse warning. In other words:  being such in appearance. In an interview in the Insurance Journal in April, Margaret Davidson, NOAA’s senior advisor for coastal inundation and resilience science and services said "recent data that has been collected but has yet to be made official indicates sea levels could rise by roughly 3 meters or 9 feet [9.8 feet] by 2050-2060, far higher and quicker than current projections." This report was widely discounted in the press and by theoretical "experts". Davidson further explained herself in an interview in ClimateCrocks--itself with a substantially questioning title " New Sea Level Story May be a Step too Far". The words of Davidson have great meaning however and completely negate any attempt at discounting her statements. ClimateCrocks posted a text obtained from Margaret Davidson of NOAA to Eric Holthaus of Slate, of which the following quote summarizes the pertinent information: “i explained the time lag between observations/data in the field and published approved scientific consensus of peer reviewed literature can be as much as 10 years. and as before, the next approved consensus will likely see a notable uptick in slr [sea level rise] guidance (based upon field work in the period ’05-13) as it will need to have been published by 2017 when the synthesis process begins anew. I am not a scientist, but hang with them a lot. referenced recent paper by Hansen et al (which suggested 3 to 5 meters by 2100 tho Hansen has been saying 5 meters for nearly 15 years.) current work re cryosphere and mass water balance, which is a more recent area of science work. and reports regarding current field observations as mentioned and discussed by experts at various scientific mtgs on presentation rooms an corridors within past 6 months. WA [West Antarctic Ice Sheet] deteriorating rapidly… portions of shelf are now ungrounded with a lens of water underneath like Greenland but different. actually said my personal opinion was 2 to 3 meters in the next 50 years (that 2100 was not a useful frame for most people.)”Jerger, RIMS 2016: Sea Level Rise Will Be Worse and Come Sooner, Insurance Journal, April 12, 2016.http://www.insurancejournal.com/news/national/2... ClimateCrocks.com, Peter Sinclair, Caution: New Sea Level Story May be a Step too Far, April 21, 2016.https://climatecrocks.com/2016/04/21/caution-ne...More References Here.

story:
ENGLISH VERSION :

 https://issuu.com/onobproject/docs/onob_indiegogo

Brève présentation 

Alice Weil et François-Luc Giraldeau, deux passionnés d’architecture à l’origine d’ONOB Project respectivement française et québécois. Alice, étudiante en première année de master à l’École Nationale Supérieure d’Architecture de Paris-Malaquais et François-Luc, diplômé de l’école d’architecture de l’Université McGill à Montréal.

ONOB (Or Noir et Ours Blancs) est un projet de recherche qui porte sur le pipeline de l’Alaska. Ce dernier traverse l’Etat sur près de 1300km, longé par une route sur toute sa distance : il s’agit de comprendre la relation que cet oléoduc et ses infrastructures associées entretiennent avec le territoire sauvage qu’ils traversent, particulièrement avec la faune unique de l’Etat.

Nous abordons cette problématique en la faisant systématiquement graviter autour de ces deux mêmes questions: de quelle manière des architectes auraient pu être impliqués dans l’existence de ces infrastructures et en quoi une participation de leur part aurait été (ou serait) bénéfique ?


Pourquoi ce thème ?

Nous sommes au jour où les hommes et la société prennent conscience de l’impact qu’ils ont sur l’environnement (pour la deuxième fois depuis la fin des années 1960). 

Au jour où la COP21 de Paris a mis en évidence les enjeux politiques et sociaux que représentent le changement actuel du climat.

Au jour où le cours du pétrole n’a jamais été aussi bas et où de surcroit il devient de plus en plus pressant de trouver des ressources d’énergie alternatives. Au moment où l’Amérique du Nord refuse d’installer le 4ème tronçon du XL Keystone pipeline faisant battre la controverse à son plein.

Nous en sommes pour certains à une nouvelle ère, géologique, sociale, idéo- logique... à un tournant de l’histoire de l’humanité où les décisions prises ont le pouvoir de changer considérablement le cours des choses, et où les mauvais choix auront des impacts graves et irréversibles...

Il nous semble indispensable de nous intéresser à ce thème et de travailler dessus, en tant qu'architectes mais aussi en tant qu'individus.


Pourquoi cet oléoduc ?

Vu du ciel, le 49ème État étasunien présente une frontière, une coupure, une balafre qui divise en deux le territoire sur plusieurs centaines de kilomètres au milieu de la nature sauvage. Il s’agit du pipeline de l’Alaska qui depuis 1977 traverse l’Etat pour acheminer une importante quantité de pétrole vers le reste des Etats-Unis. 

Il part de Prudhoe Bay, champ pétrolier à l’extrême Nord, dans les terres les plus éloignées et inaccessibles du territoire pour arriver à la ville de Valdez, tout au sud, où les populations humaines sont les plus établies.

La nature et la diversité des 1300 kilomètres traversés par l’oléoduc ont immédiatement suscité des controverses, notamment à propos des questions environnementales de protection des écosystèmes uniques de l’Etat. Cependant, il semble que le projet de ces infrastructures ait parcouru un chemin parsemé de très peu d’embûches avant de voir le jour puis de transporter en quasi-permanence depuis bientôt 40 ans des millions de m3 de pétrole.

Ces infrastructures ont été très largement étudiées par des scientifiques de différents domaines depuis leur mise en place pour répondre à la crise pétrolière de 1973 mais très peu (voire pas du tout) par des architectes.

La recherche d’ONOB entend profiter de l’unicité de ce pipeline pour réfléchir aux implications possibles des architectes et à la réflexion territoriale dans la mise en place de telles infrastructures.

Le Trans-Alaska Pipeline System présente des spécificités relatives à des questions politiques, économiques, scientifiques, sociales, écologiques, historiques... ce qui en fait un cas d’étude extraordinaire.


Le voyage

Nous rendre sur place en Alaska pendant un mois s’avère être une étape indispen- sable pour alimenter judicieusement notre recherche.

Le voyage aura pour but premier de suivre la route de l’oléoduc sur ses 1300 km, de Valdez à Prudhoe Bay.? Lors de ce cheminement en voiture, il s’agira d’observer le pipeline et ses highways avec leur dimension de support de transport à travers le territoire, et de découvrir les infrastructures et édifices qui y sont inévitablement liés le long de la route (stations de pompages, petites pistes d’atterrissage, rares auberges, une field station de l’institut de biologie arctique, etc.).

En plus des observations directes, un séjour permettra de rencontrer et d’organiser des interviews avec des acteurs centraux dans l’histoire, la construction et la vie du pipeline. Il est donc prévu de rencontrer lors du mois passé en Alaska :

– des membres de différentes ONG environnementales à Anchorage et Fairbanks

– des membres d’institutions gouverne- mentales

– des autochtones des villages arctiques

– des acteurs de l’exploitation pétrolière

En plus de la recherche écrite qui se matérialisera sous la forme d'un document illustré d'une centaine de pages, nous réaliserons un moyen-métrage documentaire d'environ 30 minutes à notre retour, grâce aux données recueillies sur place.


Le budget


Vols

1.  Paris - Anchorage / Anchorage - Paris : 1,500 €

Déplacements internes

1. Anchorage - Whittier - Valdez? : 250 €

2. Prudhoe Bay - Barrow? : 300 €

3. Prudhoe Bay - Arctic Sea (Arctic Shuttle) : 70 €

Location de voiture (prix divisé par 2*)

4x4 pour la route : 1,500 €

150 litres d’essence (Alaska : entre 0,6€ et 1.05 € / litre) : 120 €

Dépenses pour un mois de logement :

Logement*?(Alaska : moyenne de 70€/nuit auberge de jeunesse) : 1,450 €

Trousse de premiers secours* : 150 €

Equipements d’expédition

Chaussures de montagne : 100 €

Vêtements et accessoires : 500 €

Total : 5,940 €

Total pour deux personnes : 11,880 € ou $ 13,433 USD

* Prix divisé par deux


MERCI !

Tous les soutiens sont les bienvenus pour encourager et appuyer notre démarche !

Au cours du voyage, les pages Facebook, Instagram et Twitter d’ONOB Project seront actives quotidiennement pour partager photos et récit du voyage «en live».
story_txt:
ENGLISH VERSION : https://issuu.com/onobproject/docs/onob_indiegogoBrève présentation Alice Weil et François-Luc Giraldeau, deux
passionnés d’architecture à l’origine d’ONOB Project respectivement
française et québécois. Alice, étudiante en première année de master à l’École
Nationale Supérieure d’Architecture de Paris-Malaquais et François-Luc, diplômé
de l’école d’architecture de l’Université McGill à Montréal. 
ONOB (Or Noir et Ours Blancs) est
un projet de recherche qui porte sur le pipeline de l’Alaska. Ce dernier
traverse l’Etat sur près de 1300km, longé par une route sur toute sa distance :
il s’agit de comprendre la relation que cet oléoduc et ses infrastructures
associées entretiennent avec le territoire sauvage qu’ils traversent,
particulièrement avec la faune unique de l’Etat.Nous abordons cette
problématique en la faisant systématiquement graviter autour de ces deux mêmes
questions: de quelle manière des architectes auraient pu être impliqués dans
l’existence de ces infrastructures et en quoi une participation de leur part
aurait été (ou serait) bénéfique ?
Pourquoi ce thème ?
Nous sommes au jour où les hommes et la société
prennent conscience de l’impact qu’ils ont sur l’environnement (pour la deuxième fois depuis la fin des années 1960). Au jour où la COP21 de Paris a mis
en évidence les enjeux politiques et sociaux que représentent le changement
actuel du climat.
Au jour où le cours du pétrole n’a jamais été
aussi bas et où de surcroit il devient de plus en plus pressant de trouver des
ressources d’énergie alternatives. Au moment où l’Amérique du Nord refuse
d’installer le 4ème tronçon du XL Keystone pipeline faisant battre la
controverse à son plein.
Nous en sommes pour certains à une nouvelle
ère, géologique, sociale, idéo- logique... à un tournant de l’histoire de
l’humanité où les décisions prises ont le pouvoir de changer considérablement
le cours des choses, et où les mauvais choix auront des impacts graves et
irréversibles...Il nous semble indispensable de nous intéresser à ce thème et de travailler dessus, en tant qu'architectes mais aussi en tant qu'individus.
Pourquoi cet oléoduc ?
Vu du ciel, le 49ème État étasunien présente
une frontière, une coupure, une balafre qui divise en deux le territoire sur
plusieurs centaines de kilomètres au milieu de la nature sauvage. Il s’agit
du pipeline de l’Alaska qui depuis 1977 traverse l’Etat pour acheminer une
importante quantité de pétrole vers le reste des Etats-Unis. Il part de Prudhoe
Bay, champ pétrolier à l’extrême Nord, dans les terres les plus éloignées et
inaccessibles du territoire pour arriver à la ville de Valdez, tout au sud,
où les populations humaines sont les plus établies.
La nature et la diversité des 1300 kilomètres
traversés par l’oléoduc ont immédiatement suscité des controverses, notamment
à propos des questions environnementales de protection des écosystèmes uniques
de l’Etat. Cependant, il semble que le projet de ces infrastructures ait
parcouru un chemin parsemé de très peu d’embûches avant de voir le jour puis de
transporter en quasi-permanence depuis bientôt 40 ans des millions de m3 de
pétrole.
Ces infrastructures ont été très largement
étudiées par des scientifiques de différents domaines depuis leur mise en place
pour répondre à la crise pétrolière de 1973 mais très peu (voire pas du tout)
par des architectes.
La recherche d’ONOB entend profiter de
l’unicité de ce pipeline pour réfléchir aux implications possibles des
architectes et à la réflexion territoriale dans la mise en place de telles
infrastructures.
Le Trans-Alaska Pipeline System présente
des spécificités relatives à des questions politiques, économiques,
scientifiques, sociales, écologiques, historiques... ce qui en fait un cas d’étude
extraordinaire.
Le voyage
Nous rendre sur place en Alaska pendant un mois
s’avère être une étape indispen- sable pour alimenter judicieusement notre
recherche.
Le voyage aura pour but premier de suivre la
route de l’oléoduc sur ses 1300 km, de Valdez à Prudhoe Bay.? Lors de ce
cheminement en voiture, il s’agira d’observer le pipeline et ses highways avec
leur dimension de support de transport à travers le territoire, et de découvrir les infrastructures et édifices qui y sont inévitablement liés le long
de la route (stations de pompages, petites pistes d’atterrissage, rares
auberges, une field station de l’institut de biologie arctique, etc.).
En plus des observations directes, un séjour
permettra de rencontrer et d’organiser des interviews avec des acteurs centraux
dans l’histoire, la construction et la vie du pipeline. Il est donc prévu de
rencontrer lors du mois passé en Alaska :
– des membres de différentes ONG environnementales à Anchorage et Fairbanks
– des membres d’institutions gouverne- mentales
– des autochtones des villages arctiques
– des acteurs de l’exploitation pétrolière
En plus de la recherche écrite qui se matérialisera sous la forme d'un document illustré d'une centaine de pages, nous réaliserons un moyen-métrage documentaire d'environ 30 minutes à notre retour, grâce aux données recueillies sur place.Le budgetVols
1.  Paris -
Anchorage / Anchorage - Paris : 1,500 €
Déplacements internes
1.
Anchorage - Whittier - Valdez? : 250 €
2. Prudhoe
Bay - Barrow? : 300 €
3. Prudhoe
Bay - Arctic Sea (Arctic Shuttle) : 70 €
Location
de voiture (prix divisé par 2*)

4x4
pour la route : 1,500 €
150 litres d’essence (Alaska : entre
0,6€ et 1.05 € / litre) : 120 €
Dépenses
pour un mois de logement :
Logement*?(Alaska : moyenne de 70€/nuit
auberge de jeunesse) : 1,450 €
Trousse de premiers secours* : 150 €
Equipements d’expédition
Chaussures de montagne : 100 €
Vêtements et accessoires : 500 €
Total : 5,940 €
Total pour deux personnes : 11,880 € ou $ 13,433 USD
* Prix divisé par deuxMERCI !Tous les soutiens sont les bienvenus pour encourager
et appuyer notre démarche !
Au cours du voyage, les pages Facebook, Instagram et Twitter d’ONOB Project seront actives quotidiennement pour
partager photos et récit du voyage «en live».

story:
Hello, my name is Caroline Pang. I am based in Singapore. I work with local communities and NGOs in Asia to develop ecotourism projects. I help them with fundraising and also provide them with marketing support through Indie Travellers (www.indietravellers.com), a company that I set up for this purpose.  I am also a conservation and travel photographer. 

Prior to setting out on my own, I have spend most of my career life in the Kinabatangan floodplain, promoting nature-based tourism as well as ecotourism as a tour operator and later with WWF as a communicator and a fundraiser for a project on sustainable management of wetlands. 

The Kinabatangan - Rasig project, in the eastern part of Sabah on the island of Borneo, is the current community-based ecotourism project that I am working on. This project is a collaboration with Mr Mursalin Abdullah, a local community from the village of Sukau. 

The project is to safeguard a 5.9 acres (about 2.38 hectare) land which is an important wildlife corridor.  It is located along the Kinabatangan, Sabah’s longest river, in the eastern part of Malaysian Borneo. Rasig was the name of the early settlement on this particular land inherited by Mursalin. Therefore, we named it "The Kinabatangan – Rasig Project". 

The lower Kinabatangan floodplain is renown as a haven to many rare and endemic flora and fauna in Borneo. It is one of the few remaining freshwater swamp forests in Southeast Asia. Much of the land in the lower floodplain are being converted to palm oil plantation by external investors and other minor human activities carried out by the local villagers. This has caused major habitat fragmentation and also decreases food source especially for Borneo Pygmy Elephants. Hence, increases wildlife conflicts such as crop raiding by elephants and Orang Utans with land owners and village settlements. Within the floodplain, about 26,000 hectare of fragmented forests are protected as the lower Kinabatangan wildlife sanctuary. 

Rasig is also located on one of the critical bottlenecks for elephant movement, and adjacent to the lower Kinabatangan wildlife sanctuary. Borneo Pygmy Elephants that cross the river from the other side of the wildlife sanctuary to this side will use Rasig to get to the next forest reserve and vice versa. The herd usually congregates within the land for several days, to feed and play in the swamp forest before moving on. This makes it an ideal wildlife safe-house where elephants and other wildlife can be monitored for injuries or even new birth. 

Other wildlife that were being observed frequenting Rasig includes wild Orang Utans, rare reddish form silver langurs, leopard cats and wild boars. There are abundance of fig trees along the riverbank. Figs are major food source for birds especially hornbills, Orang Utans and fishes. Recently, the White Fronted Falconet, Borneo's smallest bird of prey was spotted in the area too. When the water level is low, the sandbank is visible on the northwestern side of the land, which is also a breeding and resting ground for estuarine crocodiles.

The land owner, who is also a fisherman, has voluntarily agreed to protect his land, pledging no development that may affect the wildlife corridor. It is possibly the first pragmatic move by a local villager in making such commitment. Most villagers, whose income are affected by depletion of fisheries, would have sold their land to agriculture companies for huge profit. 

There are a lot more to be done. So, this campaign is to raise enough funds to build the local capacity, to enable local villagers to manage their own land for nature conservation and to generate sustainable income through ecotourism activities. 

This project hopes to serve as a platform to attain conservation results through ecotourism with participation and support from the local community.  


Your contribution in any form will help us achieve our objectives as follows:

1)  To build local capabilities in ecotourism in relation to wildlife and habitat conservation

2)  To enhance the knowledge of wildlife ecology in degraded habitat

3) To promote and to communicate nature conservation to target audience through ecotourism activities

4)  Ensure direct benefit and equitable distribution of tourism opportunities to the local communities

6) Develop a set of guidelines for responsible wildlife tourism activities (control carrying capacity, code of ethics)

7) Promote lower Kinabatangan to niche ecotourism market at domestic and international level for the benefit of economics and conservation values


What we need:

We need your help to raise US$34,000.00 to make this happen, although any amount of money donated is appreciated. 

We have already started to raise some to cover the startup including promotional and marketing materials but your contribution will go directly to the following that will create a huge impact not just to the area but the region:

#1. Three months preliminary survey and assessment of the 5.9 acres land headed by a wildlife biologist. It is essential to link local and scientific knowledge to promote sustainable tourism and the environment. Survey and assessment include forest inventory, wildlife assessment to identify type of wildlife accessing the area, identifying possible habitat restoration after classification and forest condition are identified. Amount: US$ 6,500.00

#2. Two field assistants from the local communities to assist with the three months assessment. Amount: US$ 3,500.00

#3. Field equipments for assessment and survey (include 3 compasses, 3 binoculars, 3 units of GPS). Amount: US$ 1,800.00

#4. Boat transportation with boatman and fuel for field survey and assessment. Amount: US$ 1,500.00

#5. Construction of an inland tower for long term wildlife monitoring (approximately 7 meters high, 4 feet by 8 feet, including manpower, transportation and materials). Amount: US$ 4,500.00

#6. Construction of a floating jetty for embarkation and disembarkation, and riverside observation of elephant crossing from the river and other wildlife (approximately about 8 meters by 6 meters, including manpower, transportation and materials). Amount: US$5,500.00

#7. Three camera traps inclusive of storage cards and batteries, to document wildlife presence, behaviours and other important data that may be of help for wildlife conservation of the area. Each camera will be placed in strategic areas. Amount: US$ 3,000.00

#8. A two day workshop to develop a set of guideline for responsible ecotourism activities and training for long term wildlife monitoring. Participants include the land owner and local communities who will also be our team of naturalist guides. Amount: US$ 1,600.00

#9. One local villager trained to collect data from camera traps and to do wildlife monitoring - 12 months wage. Amount: US$ 4,200.00

#10. Food source plot -  The preliminary planting of food source for wildlife such as Borneo Pygmy Elephants and Orang Utans would include banana trees, fig trees and other plants that are native to the area. This includes boat transportation, seedlings, and manpower. Amount: US$ 1,900.00


The Impact:

Support this campaign to protect not just the lower Kinabatangan floodplain, or Borneo, but our planet. Your contribution will make this happen! Help the Borneo Pygmy Elephants, Orang Utans and other wildlife to safeguard their habitat. The success of this campaign will enable us to jumpstart all the tasks and activities required. We believe that this project has the potential to be replicated or applied locally and perhaps regionally and globally in areas that combine nature conservation and ecotourism.


The Contribution and What You Get:


$5 - A big Orang Utan hug

Any amount helps !

# Public thank you on our FB page and Twitter


$10 - A big Elephant hug

Any amount helps !

# Public thank you on our FB page and Twitter


$50 - Sponsor wildlife food source plot (Refer to #10)

# Public thank you on our FB page and Twitter

# Update on our progress


$100 - Sponsor our field surveys (Refer to #1, #2, #3, #4)

# Public thank you on our FB page and Twitter

# Update on our progress

# Three personalized postcards from the field featuring flora and fauna of Kinabatangan


$160 - Sponsor our two days workshop (Refer to # 8)

# Public thank you on our FB page and Twitter, 

# Update on our progress

# An awesome t-shirt that has one of the key wildlife of Kinabatangan / Borneo


$200 - Sponsor a field assistant for one year data collection (Refer to # 9)

# Public thank you on our FB page and Twitter, 

# Update on our progress

# Three personalized postcards from the field featuring flora and fauna of Kinabatangan

# An awesome t-shirt that has one of the key wildlife of Kinabatangan


$300 - Sponsor three camera traps (Refer to #7)

# Public thank you on our FB page and Twitter

# Your name featured in our camera trap gallery

# Update on our progress with latest camera trap photos

# An awesome t-shirt that has one of the camera trap photos imprinted on it


$450 -  Sponsor a wildlife tower (Refer to #5)

# Public thank you on our FB page and Twitter

# Update on our progress

# A thank you certificate

# Your name listed on our thank you plaque

# 20% discount on our 6 days Kinabatangan-Rasig programme.


$550 - Sponsor a floating jetty (Refer to #6)

# Public thank you on our FB page and Twitter

# Update on our progress

# A thank you certificate

# Your name listed on our thank you plaque

# 30% discount on our 6 days Kinabatangan-Rasig programme.


Other ways you can help:

Besides monetary contribution you can still create an impact by helping to spread the word about this campaign to your families and friends or anyone who are interested in supporting nature conservation and sustainable tourism.


The channels we used for updates:

Besides being in our mailing list as our contributors, updates and shout out on progress of the Kinabatangan - Rasig project will be made via the following channels: 

Facebook: 

https://www.facebook.com/pages/Caroline-Pang-Photography/267506946620532;

https://www.facebook.com/indietraveller

Twitter: https://twitter.com/IndieTravellers; https://twitter.com/carolinepang_;

https://twitter.com/IndieTravellers

Web: http://www.indietravellers.com/blogs/the-kinabatangan-rasig-project; http://carolinepang.com/blog/the-kinabatangan-rasig-project/

Video: http://www.youtube.com/user/indietravellers; https://vimeo.com/71239863

story:
About Us 

We met on the frisbee field fall of Sophomore year of college.  Liz likes to describe her first interactions with Erika like meeting a walking entertainment machine with big hair.  Erika has the ability to make anyone laugh and is always entertaining those around her with her energetic attitude.  Erika says she had a good feeling about their friendship when Liz laughed at all her weird jokes.  

After sometime we learned our similarities extended way beyond on our shared enjoyment for ultimate frisbee.  We both love to adventure including all things outdoors: camping, kayaking, canoeing, rock climbing, biking, skiing, and backpacking.  We both find great reward in teaching kids about the outdoors through experiental education.  We both love sporatic and spontaneous outings and have had our fair share of goodtimes as a result.  To top it off, we're both from Madison, Wisconsin.  

But what makes our friendship really special is we make a great team.  We've worked together guiding and organizing with several different groups.  People tell us we make an unstoppable pair.      

More about us...

ERIKA grew up in Madison, WI where she could most often be found canoeing in a large puddle in her backyard or sailing on Lake Monona. She attended the University of Minnesota, Twin Cities earning a degree in Theatre Arts. During her undergraduate career, she spent her summers working at Camp Manito-wish YMCA, in Boulder Junction, WI; empowering participants between ages ten and eighteen with collaborative leadership skills through wilderness tripping. Erika has led trips for the Center for Outdoor Adventure through the University of Minnesota and with Wilderness Inquiry in Minneapolis. She enjoys figuring out new ways to infuse art and theatre into every experience she has in the outdoors. 

LIZ is a native Wisconsinite growing up just outside of Madison, WI.  She left home in 2008 to attend school at the University of Minnesota-Twin Cities where she pursued a degree in Environmental Education and Sustainability Studies.  During college, her ongoing love for the outdoors merged with her studies during two off campus experiential education courses, fueling her current passions and interests.  The first, a domestic program in the Twin Cities, broaden Liz’s perspectives around different issues such as environmental justice, sustainable agriculture, and renewable energy.  The second experience took Liz halfway around the world to India where she spent six weeks hiking and camping in the Himalayas while studying culture, alpine ecosystems, mountain farming, and sustainability in a developing nation. These experiences lead her to a summer and fall guiding wilderness trips in the Midwest with Wilderness Inquiry. 

This unstoppable pair is going to jump in a tandem canoe with eight others and paddle down America's largest river, The Mississippi.  But we need your help to make it happen.    

Why the Mississippi? 

Growing up in Wisconsin and then moving nextdoor to Minnesota, the Mississippi has always held a special place in our hearts.  After college this connection deepend when we both spent time taking youth down a portion of the Mississippi in Minneapolis and St. Paul in voyager canoes with Wilderness Inquiry.  As many people know, it's easy to develop a realitionship with outdoor places.  We're both concerned that this important waterway isn't recieveing the attention it needs and is threatened by inevitable impacts of Climate Change.

As the climate debate comes to a head in the United States, it’s easy to get caught up in abstract political jargon and lose sight of the everyday people whose lives revolve around the health of a natural resource. We love paddling rivers that encompass an array of social and environmental issues because they tell a great story. One that needs to be heard.

In the fall of 2013, we, along with eight other people, will embark on and film a three month long canoe journey down the Mississippi River from the headwaters in Lake Itasca, Minnesota, to New Orleans. As we paddle, we will engage communities in an ongoing dialogue about their relationships to and interactions with this watertrail to give voice to the Mississippi River, its inhabitants, and the many perspectives we encounter along the way. Upon completion of the trip, we will produce a documentary of this journey so that these vital conversations can continue with others beyond the flow of the river.

What we need:

The breakdown is simple.  First and foremost, we need to eat.  We are asking for $720 each to cover our food expenses. 

Per Person:

Food for one day:

$9

Food for one week:

$63

Food for one month:

$279

Food for the whole trip:

 

   $720 

Besides our food expense, we need a way to get home.  (Erika is still working on her teleportation device but it's not quite ready.)

Transportation for our canoe back to Minneapolis

$260

Pay for one person to travel back to the Twin Cities

   $150

                                                                         

Our total expenses add-up to $1,000 each.  

(the extra $200 is to help offset fees)

Your support means so much to us, we have a few prizes to offer you!

$25 – a really, REALLY, really big hug, and lots of karma points!

$50 – A personalized postcard from a town along the way, plus an Erika and Liz hug sandwich and karma points! 

$100 – Your name featured in the credits of our documentary, a postcard, Erika and Liz hug sandwich, and karma points!

$500 – A shout-out to you or your organization on our Twitter and Facebook with a picture of me featuring your name or company, your name featured in the credits of our documentary, a postcard, Erika and Liz hug sandwich, and karma points!

$1,000 – A Paddle Forward T-Shirt, photo shout-out, your name in the credits, Erika and Liz hug sandwich, untold amounts of karma points, and our eternal gratitude. 

$1,500 - A Paddle Forward T-Shirt, photo shout-out, your name in the credits, Erika and Liz hug sandwich, untold amounts of karma points, and our eternal gratitude.

The Impact

Without your support, this trip is not possible.  Not only will we personally grow from this challenging and unique experience, but we will connect with new people to develop a constructive dialogue about our lives in the United States and the world.

Upon returning, we will have the incredible opportunity to construct a national dialogue about the Mississippi by creating a documentary of our experiences.  This documentary will spark conversations about our national resources, water usage, the meaning of community, and the very nature (pun!) of what it means to be "in nature."  We believe strongly that these are dialogues that our nation must be having more often with one another, and we would be proud to be a part of this legacy.  Besides, everyone likes a good documentary!

Other Ways You Can Help

You might not be able to contribute, but that doesn’t mean I can’t use your help.  Please spread the word about our campaign by sharing this page on facebook, twitter, or any other social platform you prefer. 

Send me a message if you think you have connections or information that may be helpful for us.  Though our group has varying degrees of paddling experience we can always use community support.  We welcome your insights.
story_txt:
About Us 
We met on the frisbee field fall of Sophomore year of college.  Liz likes to describe her first interactions with Erika like meeting a walking entertainment machine with big hair.  Erika has the ability to make anyone laugh and is always entertaining those around her with her energetic attitude.  Erika says she had a good feeling about their friendship when Liz laughed at all her weird jokes.  
After sometime we learned our similarities extended way beyond on our shared enjoyment for ultimate frisbee.  We both love to adventure including all things outdoors: camping, kayaking, canoeing, rock climbing, biking, skiing, and backpacking.  We both find great reward in teaching kids about the outdoors through experiental education.  We both love sporatic and spontaneous outings and have had our fair share of goodtimes as a result.  To top it off, we're both from Madison, Wisconsin.  
But what makes our friendship really special is we make a great team.  We've worked together guiding and organizing with several different groups.  People tell us we make an unstoppable pair.      
More about us...
ERIKA grew up in Madison, WI where she could most often be found canoeing in a large puddle in her backyard or sailing on Lake Monona. She attended the University of Minnesota, Twin Cities earning a degree in Theatre Arts. During her undergraduate career, she spent her summers working at Camp Manito-wish YMCA, in Boulder Junction, WI; empowering participants between ages ten and eighteen with collaborative leadership skills through wilderness tripping. Erika has led trips for the Center for Outdoor Adventure through the University of Minnesota and with Wilderness Inquiry in Minneapolis. She enjoys figuring out new ways to infuse art and theatre into every experience she has in the outdoors. 
LIZ is a native Wisconsinite growing up just outside of Madison, WI.  She left home in 2008 to attend school at the University of Minnesota-Twin Cities where she pursued a degree in Environmental Education and Sustainability Studies.  During college, her ongoing love for the outdoors merged with her studies during two off campus experiential education courses, fueling her current passions and interests.  The first, a domestic program in the Twin Cities, broaden Liz’s perspectives around different issues such as environmental justice, sustainable agriculture, and renewable energy.  The second experience took Liz halfway around the world to India where she spent six weeks hiking and camping in the Himalayas while studying culture, alpine ecosystems, mountain farming, and sustainability in a developing nation. These experiences lead her to a summer and fall guiding wilderness trips in the Midwest with Wilderness Inquiry. 
This unstoppable pair is going to jump in a tandem canoe with eight others and paddle down America's largest river, The Mississippi.  But we need your help to make it happen.

story:
N/a'an ku sê Foundation Trip

My name is Jaclyn Turville and I am a 20-year old from Canada, and I am raising money to volunteer at the N/a'an ku sê Foundation in Namibia. While there, I will be aiding in both the wildlife conservation program as well as in the Foundation's preschool program. I am passionate about working with children and animals because they do not have a voice and need someone to help meet their needs. I am NOT Dr. Doolittle, and cannot speak cheetah, but I do plan on helping as much as I can.

Your generous support will be used to offset the fees charged by the foundation and expenses involved with this volunteer opportunity.

About the N/a'an ku sê Foundation

This foundation aims to improve the lives of the marginalized San Bushman community. They now run several award-winning projects including:

Supporting African Wildlife

The foundation provides a safe home for orphaned and injured animals who sadly cannot be released back into the wild and also supports the Carnivore Conservation Research Project, which researches and protects threatened wild cheetahs, leopards and brown hyena.

Supporting the Marginalized San Bushman Community

The Clever Cubs School provides free education for San Bushman children and the Lifetime Clinic, which provides free healthcare to the San Bushman community in Epukiro.

The foundation's philosophy is "Conservation through Innovation" and they strive to create sustainable and long-term solutions. Their vision is to play a pro-active role in nature conservation. "We cannot undo what has been done... but we can shape our future." http://www.naankuse.com/home/learn-about-naan-ku-se.html
