story:
What is Whaler Watching ?


The Whaler Watching Programme is a citizen-led campaign to document and expose the full truth about commercial whaling in Iceland. The idea for Whaler Watching was born in 2014 when during a vacation in Iceland we were appalled to learn about the existence of Iceland's commercial whale hunt. We hold the belief, shared by the overwhelming number of individuals and governments worldwide, that the slaughter of these majestic animals for commercial purposes is unconscionable. We believe the notion of "humane whaling" is a myth created and perpetuated by those who have a vested economic interest in the continuation of this gruesome practice.

The Whaler Watching Programme will offer an independent source of information about the hunt of nature's most massive mammals. By gathering comprehensive, first-hand information about the brutal killing of Iceland's most majestic marine mammals and sharing this information with the Icelandic public, we hope to persuade more people to end their silent acquiescence of this controversial hunt and to join forces with those who oppose the hunt on ethical and ecological grounds.


Why Whaler Watching is urgently needed 


Since Iceland resumed its commercial whaling programme in 2006, over  550 endangered fin whales and over 400 northern minke whales have been killed by Icelandic whalers. Whaling activities are conducted far offshore where they are largely shielded from public scrutiny. Due to the absence of independent whaling operation monitors, the whaling industry presently enjoys a monopoly both on the gathering of information about its own operations and the dissemination of this information to the public. As a result of this, the public perception of whaling in Iceland is to a great degree shaped by the information that the whaling industry itself provides.

According to a 2013 poll, 73 percent of Icelanders hold the view that it is important that whaling operations are conducted in a humane manner, indicating that the overwhelming majority of Icelanders are concerned about the welfare of whales. In the same poll almost 60 percent of Icelanders expressed the belief that Iceland’s whale hunt is carried out in a humane manner. The widespread nature of this belief stands in stark contrast to the fact that the whaling industry has so far refused to make important data about the supposed humaneness of the whale hunt available to the public.

One has to wonder whether the perception that the whale hunt is conducted humanely is based on facts or whether this impression is the result of the marketing efforts combined with a very selective information policy of the industry that has a vested economic interested in maintaining the appearance of being humane.


This is where the Whaler Watching Programme wants to come into play.



How we work



  • We document

The idea for the Whaler Watching Programme was born from the realization that most people know very little about the brutal reality of commercial whaling. The Whaler Watching campaign has a strong visual media focus. Our citizen-led initiative will use the power of the camera to document whaling activities on- and offshore as comprehensively as possible. The Whaler Watching team will trace and supervise whaling operations and will gather visual footage that will subsequently be made available to the public.

The primary purpose of our campaign is educational. All our operations will be conducted in a strictly non-confrontational manner. This means that we will not interfere with any whaling activities, which are legal under Icelandic law. Instead we will use all available legal means to document and expose the highly controversial hunt.


  • We inform

Most of the information about whaling practices, including the information that is directly pertinent to the all-important question whether or not the hunt is conducted humanely, is strictly controlled by the parties who have an economic interest in the continuation of the hunt: namely the whaling and fishing industry and their official counterparts in the Icelandic government.

The public's access to detailed and sensitive information is intentionally restricted, which undermines any possibility of a critical public debate about the ethical defensibility of whaling in Iceland. 

The Whaler Watching campaign will use all gathered data for public information purposes. Our intention is to provide information that is in the interest of everyone.




Wildlife experts and ex-whalers speak out against the practice of whaling


Conservationists, nature enthusiasts, and animal welfare advocates have long spoken out against commercial whaling. In recent years even people who have been personally involved in whaling activities have gone public with their personal accounts of the brutal reality of whaling. These accounts paint a picture that differs significantly from the account that the Icelandic whaling industry likes to spread. Among those who have witnessed whaling activities on the high seas, there exists hardly any doubt that killing these sentient animals at sea is a horrific and morally deeply troubling event. Contrary to what is often claimed by pro-whaling parties, animals that are struck by harpoons rarely die instantly.

Have a look at what wildlife experts and people who have worked on whaling vessels say about this controversial industry.



What we intend to use the money for


The Whaler Watching Campaign is spearheaded by the German registered NPO  "Hard To Port e.V.". We are obligated by German association law to document that all financial and material contributions to our campaign are used solely for their intended purpose.

For the Whaler Watching Campaign your donations will contribute to cover some of the following expenses :                 

  • purchase a small used Whaler Watching motor boat
  • transportation costs (ferry tickets - Denmark - Iceland - Denmark)
  • fuel costs in Iceland
  • budget accommodation
  • technical and safety equipment
  • vegan provisions


What's in it for you


Hard to Port is a non-profit organization run entirely by volunteers. As a fairly young NPO, we have yet to attract the backing of any major donors. The success of a major campaign like our Whaler Watching Programme depends heavily on the generous contributions of people who are concerned about the welfare of animals and who share our belief that commercial whaling is an outdated and inhumane practice that all civilized nations should end once and for all. To maximize the impact of your donation, the money that you donate will go directly toward our Whaler Watching campaign. Unlike bigger organizations, who can incentivize their donors with flashy giveaways, we are unable to offer any comparable rewards for your support. We at Hart to Port also firmly believe that the money that you donate is best spent when it is used to advance our campaign goals. As a small volunteer-run organization, we have the great advantage that our administrative expenses are virtually zero. All the money that you donate to us will go toward the Whaler Watching campaign. As a token of our gratitude for the immense trust that you place in us by donating to our campaign, our volunteers have come up with some personal, campaign-related perks through which we would like to express our great appreciation for your support (please visit our image gallery to view some of our perks).




Other ways you can help protecting Iceland's unique wildlife


Your financial support is crucial for realizing the Whaler Watching Campaign in 2015.

However, there are many other ways in which you can effectively help us to get active for the protection of Iceland's gentle giants of the sea.

  • Spread the word. Get the message out. Share our campaign with your social circles.

Invite your family, friends, and colleagues to our crowdfunding campaign, and share the link to our campaign site on your social media platforms. By spreading the word, you can help us reach more compassionate people who may also want to help us to realize this ambitious project. Please go to our social media sites and “friend” or “follow” us. We look forward to connecting with you!


  • Join the global call and get active with us

In order to demonstrate the great diversity of the people who support the anti-whaling cause and who feel that Icelandic whaling needs to stop, we have launched a visual petition on our website. Feel free to upload your personal image and statement and add your voice to our collective call to end commercial whaling once and for all.


  • Help with us with equipment 

In addition to much-needed funds, we are looking to procure equipment for our Whaler Watching Programme. If you happen to own one of the following items on our “wish list” and you want to donate it to support our cause, please get in touch with us. Every help is very much appreciated.

story:
Imagine the High Sierra Nevada of California - expansive views, granite peaks, spectacular clear lakes, rushing streams, and fresh cool air.  These things and the places they represent stand tall in all our hearts and dreams. The US Forest Service keeps them pristine and cared for, and they need your help.

Friends of the Inyo is a Bishop, CA based conservation non-profit dedicated to the preservation, exploration, and stewardship of public lands in California's Eastern Sierra. We work closely with the U.S. Forest Service and the Bureau of Land Management to make sure this spectacular region gets the love and care it deserves and needs. 

We are working hard to raise funds to sponsor a full time Wilderness Ranger Intern on the Sierra National Forest this summer. This position will be based out of the Eastern Sierra and work in areas of the John Muir Wilderness most easily accessed from the east side of the mountain crest.

In a time of declining federal budgets, wilderness management resources are becoming strained and harder to come by. Simultaneously, more and more Americans seek solace and adventure in the wilderness every year. With this continuous increase in wilderness and backcountry use, Wilderness Rangers Interns help ensure the health of America’s public lands. 

This is a life changing opportunity. Working as a Wilderness Ranger Intern is a gateway to a career in land management and conservation. The intern will leave their time in the backcountry with an increased love of the wilderness and public lands and valuable skills to prepare them for future employment. The experience gained will help shape their lives in many ways, cultivating self reliance, increasing  conservation ethics, and building a foundation for the future!

Help us make their dream a reality!

As a routine part of their job the Wilderness Intern will:

  • Perform basic trail maintenance, keeping trails open, clean, and passible.
  • Clean and maintain campsites so all visitors can enjoy their experience.
  • Help visitors and hikers find their way by maintaining trail signs and providing critical advice and a friendly face in the backcountry.
  • Coordinate volunteer events and help volunteers get involved on their public lands.
  • Provide interpretive information, historical context, and interesting information to visitors.
  • Gather essential data to help inform management decisions.
  • Organize and coordinate wilderness restoration projects.
  • Act as a critical voice on the ground for agencies managing wilderness areas.

Please help us reach our goal of $5,000!

Your contribution will help fund:

  • A full season, paid internship for a Wilderness Ranger Intern including job training and field experience to those interested in a career in public lands management.

               Comprehensive training including:

                         o  Leave No Trace skills
                         o  Cross Cut Saw and minimum/traditional tool use
                         o  Campsite inventory and rehabilitation
                         o  Public contact and interaction
                         o  CPR and First Aid certification
                         o  GPS use and data collection methods
                         o  Radio communications
                          o  Stock packing and working with horses and mules

  • Housing for the Intern when not on duty.
  • Tools needed to complete their work.

Part of the funds raised will also be used to facilitate a week long backcountry volunteer stewardship trip. This project will pair volunteers with professional wilderness staff, including the Wilderness Ranger Intern, for a full wilderness work experience.

  • Volunteers will be packed into the Fourth Recess area in the John Muir Wilderness by mules.
  • Volunteers will be supported by and work with professional wilderness staff.
  • Volunteers will experience what it is like to live and work in the backcountry.

A full time Wilderness Intern is critical to the health and safety of Sierra National Forest Wilderness. These individuals also help YOU get involved in wilderness by working with Friends of the Inyo and other volunteer organizations.

Please help us put their boots on the ground!
story_txt:
Imagine the High Sierra Nevada of California - expansive
views, granite peaks, spectacular clear lakes, rushing streams, and fresh cool
air.  These things and the places they
represent stand tall in all our hearts and dreams. The US Forest Service keeps
them pristine and cared for, and they need your help.
Friends of the Inyo is a Bishop, CA based conservation non-profit dedicated to the preservation, exploration, and stewardship of public lands in California's Eastern Sierra. We work closely with the U.S. Forest Service and the Bureau of Land Management to make sure this spectacular region gets the love and care it deserves and needs. We are working hard to raise funds to sponsor a
full time Wilderness Ranger Intern on the Sierra National
Forest this summer. This position will be based out of the Eastern Sierra and work in areas of the John Muir Wilderness most easily accessed from the
east side of the mountain crest. 
In a time of declining federal budgets, wilderness
management resources are becoming strained and harder to come by.
Simultaneously, more and more Americans seek solace and adventure in the wilderness every year. With this continuous increase in wilderness and backcountry
use, Wilderness Rangers Interns help ensure the health of
America’s public lands. This is a life changing opportunity. Working as a Wilderness Ranger Intern is a gateway to a career in land management and conservation. The intern will leave their time in the backcountry with an increased love of the wilderness and public lands and valuable skills to prepare them for future employment. The experience gained will help shape their lives in many ways, cultivating self reliance, increasing  conservation ethics, and building a foundation for the future!Help us make their dream a reality!As a routine part of their job the Wilderness Intern will:

Perform basic trail maintenance, keeping trails
open, clean, and passible.
Clean and maintain campsites so all visitors can
enjoy their experience.
Help visitors and hikers find their way by
maintaining trail signs and providing critical advice and a friendly face in
the backcountry.
Coordinate volunteer events and help volunteers get involved on their public lands.
Provide interpretive information, historical
context, and interesting information to visitors.
Gather essential data to help inform management
decisions.
Organize and coordinate wilderness restoration
projects.
Act as a critical voice on the ground for agencies
managing wilderness areas.

Please help us reach our goal of $5,000!
Your contribution will help fund:

A full season, paid internship for a Wilderness Ranger Intern
including job training and field experience to those interested in a career in
public lands management.

               Comprehensive training including:                         o 
Leave No Trace skills                         o 
Cross Cut Saw and minimum/traditional tool use                         o 
Campsite inventory and rehabilitation                         o 
Public contact and interaction                         o 
CPR and First Aid certification                         o 
GPS use and data collection methods                         o 
Radio communications                          o 
Stock packing and working with horses and mules


Housing for the Intern when not on
duty.


Tools needed to complete their work.

Part of the funds raised will also be used to facilitate a week long backcountry volunteer stewardship trip. This project will pair volunteers with professional wilderness staff, including the Wilderness Ranger Intern, for a full wilderness work experience.
Volunteers will be packed into the Fourth Recess area in the John Muir Wilderness by mules.
Volunteers will be supported by and work with professional wilderness staff.
Volunteers will experience what it is like to live and work in the backcountry.

A full time
Wilderness Intern is critical to the health and safety of Sierra National
Forest Wilderness. These individuals also help YOU get involved in wilderness by
working with Friends of the Inyo and other volunteer organizations.
Please help us put their boots on the ground!

story:
Drakes Bay Oyster Farm is a historic family farm located in Point Reyes National Seashore, about an hour north of San Francisco, California. The oyster farm has been in operation for over 80 years. The current owners are the Lunnys, a fourth-generation ranching family in Point Reyes, where they also raise grass-fed and organic beef.

The Lunnys purchased this historic oyster farm to revive a part of the community and ensure the health of the estero. The oyster farm provides local jobs and a sustainable food product that supports local businesses and comprises almost 40% of California’s shellfish production. The Lunny family’s stewardship of the oyster farm has resulted in award-winning oysters, and has protected the pristine waters of Drakes Estero and its abundant wildlife. The seals in Drakes Estero have never been more plentiful.

In November 2012, the National Park Service issued a decision to shut down the business. The oyster farm contested that decision, and appealed the case to the United States Supreme Court. On Monday June 30, that appeal was denied. That ended the injunction that had been keeping the farm in business.

On-farm retail sales at the oyster farm are ending July 31, 2014. At least for the foreseeable future. The oyster farm has been granted at least 30 days to harvest more oysters from the estero. Look for these prized Drakes Bay oysters at the finest restaurants in the Bay Area. 

A group of concerned citizens including Tomales Bay Oyster Company and farm-to-table chefs Patty Unterman and Margaret Grade are pursuing their own, separate lawsuit against the Park Service for its unjust actions. 

HOW YOU CAN HELP

Funding received through this campaign is used to increase awareness of the injustice of this decision. Visible public support is crucial to our cause. 

The Park Service and its allies have justified their preference for an oyster-free estero by misrepresenting the facts. We intend to continue to counter this misinformation. 

During Round One of our crowdfunding effort, our supporters provided funds that are helping us to maintain our advocacy website and to retain public-relations professionals to help us handle the increased attention to our cause.

We will continue to update the website, and we will continue to document the stories of the oyster farm's brokenhearted customers.

So many families have been visiting the oyster farm for generations. Our oysters are part of many people's holiday traditions. One family told us they have an annual tradition of visiting our oyster farm, saying "Our trip not only gives us reasons for the family to travel together and spend quality time with each other but it also provide an educational experience for my children." This family travels 500 miles to visit us!  

We are so honored to have kept this tradition alive, and deeply saddened to see it end. Most upsetting is the human cost--30+ loyal, longtime workers with specialized skills. The oyster farm recently won the right to continue to harvest for at least another month past its forced closing date for on-farm retail operations, July 31, 2014; this allows them to retains some workers for a time.

Visit our website and join our mailing list to stay current on next steps. 

THESE SKILLED WORKERS ARE LOSING THEIR JOBS

Pictured Above: Isela Meza, our staff marine biologist, oversees the handling of microscopic oyster larvae, ensuring that they set and begin to grow properly at the beginning of the oyster-planting process. The photo above shows Isela with a baby oyster in the hatchery.

Drakes Bay Oyster Farm employed 30 full-time workers and provides housing for some of them. Many of these employees have worked at the oyster farm for decades.The historic oyster farm has traditionally been a source of work for the wives of the ranch hands working in this agrarian community, a tradition the Lunnys have been proud to continue. 

To learn more about these wonderful workers, please visit our Meet the Oyster Workers page on our advocacy site.

LUNNY FAMILY STEWARDSHIP

The Lunnys are one of the ranching and farming families in West Marin that keep this beautiful land connected to its agrarian past and are creating a sustainable future. The Lunny family began dairy ranching in Point Reyes in 1946 and is known for its agricultural innovation.

The Lunny ranch created the first certified organic and certified grass-fed beef herd in Marin County, and was the first beef ranch in California to be certified Salmon Safe for the management of its riparian areas, pastures, and manure. The Lunnys received an Excellence in Rangeland Management award from the Society of Rangeland Management in 2009, and were the first beef ranch in California to receive the Animal Welfare Approved seal for humane treatment of animals.

In late 2004, the Lunnys purchased the historic oyster farm in Drakes Estero from the Johnson family, its previous owners since 1957. The farm dates to the 1930s. The Lunnys named it Drakes Bay Oyster Company, its original name.

The Lunnys are known as careful stewards of the land and water, not only through their own sound farming practices but also with their philanthropic contributions to conservation; donated Lunny oyster shells support both theSnowy Plover habitat restoration efforts of the San Francisco Bay Bird Observatory and the NOAA Fisheries San Francisco Bay Native Oyster Habitat Restoration project (news story here).

The Lunny family also provides educational tours of the oyster farm for school groups and for the public, increasing awareness of sustainable farming and educating the public about the importance of a healthy ecosystem.

In 2007, the Lunnys were recognized by the Park Service for environmental stewardship and innovation in its publication Stewardship Begins with People. (See page 45) To learn more about our stewardship practices, please visit our advocacy site.

story:
The Vitruvian Man Project

The Vitruvian Man Project is about finding hill tops and high places all over the planet and placing vertical wind turbines that are only ten feet tall and nine feet square on a mosaic tile pad. 

There are millions of hilltops around the globe where the wind blows night and day. And yet, there exist nothing to catch, harness and put that free energy to use.

Here, in Bodega Bay, our home, where Alred Hitchcock made The Birds, 1963 is where we want to place our first vertical wind turbine and a thousand more just like it on a 30 acre parcel of land. Our idea is simple. Our concept is sound. Our passion creates a crescendo of possibilities that take us back to Leanardo di Vinci and The Vitruvian Man. 

Here is our concept: 

Place 1000 turbines on mosaic art tile pads in the linear configuration of The Vitruvian Man. It will produce 5,000,000 watts of free sustainable enery which can be seen from satellites orbiting 24 hours a day,  and air travel passenges from San Francisco International Airport and Oakland International airport and many others. The grid of wind turbines will be plugged into Pacific Gas & Electric  (PG&E) and they wll pay the local villagers for their energy. 

Congresswoman Lynn Woolsey has been presented with this idea by visionary filmmaker, Robbin Michael Wagner and Brooke Laurel Denman and myself, Jessica Barry, Actress and Producer. Congresswoman Woolsey loves it! Pacific Gas & Electric (PG&E) loves it! However Congresswoman Woolsey's advice and PG&E's advice is to get this project into the grass roots mainstream. That means everyone on the planet. That means you, me, us and everyone. We need your Indiegogo help to get to phase one. How can you help? 

Wear with pride The Vitruvian Man Project medallion with chain. Everyone will ask about it and want to know more about you. YOU are the future of free energy. Simply point them to this site. IndieGoGo.com/TheMan

What is Phase One And What Do You Get?

Phase One is to have a landscape archetectual model of The Vitruvian Man Project created. This is what we will be showing to Congress and to Sir Richard Branson who is bullish on sustainable energy. So far we have, at our own expense, presented the idea to two Congress people. That is about as close to the White House as we can get without your help! Everyone is bullish and enthusiastic on the environment and how free sustainable energy will change Mother Earth's face forever.  

 

The Vitruvian Man Project will have a major IMPACT on Earth. Be part of that now! Please help! Every dollar helps us to make The Vitruvian Man Project a reality.

If everyone contributes $10 dollars.... the possiblities will be reality! 

Thank you IndieGoGo for your suggestions. We love your site!

And that’s all there is to it.

story:
What is this?

 

This year I learnt about an incredible opportunity to travel to Antarctica to experience the last great wilderness on earth and to learn how climate change is affecting it. I applied and was accepted as one of thirty young people from around the world into the 2013 Antarctica Youth Ambassadors Program (AYAP) with Robert Swan and his company 2041.

Antarctica is the last great-untouched wilderness on earth, and I cannot wait to go and experience it for myself. Yet Antarctica is currently facing some of the worst effects of climate change, and by attending this expedition I am going to learn the skills to be able to bring back my knowledge and share it with my community. 

Who am I?

 

My name is Morgan Pettersson and I am a 22-year-old environmental journalist from Perth, Western Australia. I graduated from Murdoch University in March this year with a Bachelors degree majoring in Journalism and Public Relations and a Bachelor of Arts majoring in History.

 

In 2011 I was awarded the Global Environment Journalism Initiative scholarship to study environmental journalism in Thessaloniki, Greece for one semester. Whilst there I learnt more about climate change and the current threat that the world economic crisis was having the worlds environment.

 

I care deeply about the environment and volunteer my time in my home town with the Australian Youth Climate Coalition as State Media Coordinator to try and communicate more effectively about the environment.

 

As a journalist I know that communicating to people about the environment can be hard, as you need to tell an engaging story that wills people to want to keep reading, and I think that going to Antarctica and seeing climate change and environmental damage on the front line will help me to become a better communicator.

 

The Expedition:

 

Polar explorer, environmental leader and public speaker Robert Swan, OBE, the first person in history to walk to both the North and South poles founded 2041.

Swan has dedicated his life to the preservation of Antarctica by the promotion of recycling, renewable energy and sustainability to combat the effects of climate change.

 

Each year since 2003 Swan has lead expeditions down to Antarctica, taking with him an international team of young people, teachers, scientists, environmentalists and corporate leaders as part of his ‘Leadership on the Edge’ program and this year the expedition will run from February 28-March 13.

 

In the year 2041 the Protocol on Environmental Protection to the Antarctic Treaty could potentially be modified or amended. This treaty currently forbids mining and drilling in the Antarctic, but come 2041 this could all change and Antarctica and the waters surrounding the continent may no longer be protected.

Robert Swan and 2041’s aim is to work towards the continuing protection of the Antarctic Treaty so that the last great wilderness on earth is never exploited through education and implementation of renewable energy.

Post Antarctica:

 

As part of my application to attend the expedition, I had to create a project that I would implement that would help to further spread the word on renewable energy and the threat facing Antarctica when I returned from the expedition.

As a writer and communicator I am passionate about communicating about the environment in effective and engaging ways.

 

My project that I am committing to post the expedition is to communicate about Antarctica and renewable energy projects around the world. You see all around the world there are young people, such as those attending the 2013 AYAP, who are creating change in their communities about the way others see climate change. For example there was a past participant from China who engineered a waterless toilet for a remote village in Ghana and a young Swedish girl helping to put solar cookers on the roofs of the favelas in Brazil.

 

These stories of young people making a difference are what I am going to travel and write about, including the great stories that are here in our local communities in Australia.

I am going to publish these stories to get the word out about young people making positive change in their local communities, and also film these stories and make them into a documentary.

 

The Impact

 

The environment belongs to everyone, but this is especially true for Antarctica.

Antarctica has no claim on it by any country or indigenous people.

Antarctica belongs to all of us, and therefore it is all of our jobs to protect it.

If we don’t work to protect Antarctica then we are going to be faced with a monumental crisis.

If Antarctica holds 70% of the worlds fresh water, and if this melts……well lets not think about it.

In 2041 the Antarctic Treaty is going to expire, and if it is not renewed 100% then Antarctica might become open to mining and drilling by companies looking to exploit the natural reserves.

This might lead to the catastrophe that we are currently seeing in the Arctic currently.

We need to make sure that renewable energy is so common, that by the year 2041, no one wants to go to Antarctica and spoil the pristine wilderness by mining.

Why you should sponsor me?

 

Everyone wants to help the environment, but not everyone can actually go to Antarctica to do so.

Well I want to act as an ambassador for my community to go and learn the knowledge and skills that I will acquire and bring them back so that everyone can benefit.

Through my project and writing I will be able to pass on everything I have learnt to even more people outside of my local community, so that everyone has a chance to learn and feel inspired from my journey.

I think as young people we are really powerful to create change because we are passionate and believe that anything is possible.

So if you too believe that this expedition is possible, and that this is an incredible opportunity, be sure to help me reach it!

How you can help:

 

Getting to Antarctica is quite expensive as you can imagine, and I need all of the help that I can get to make my dream come true.

The total cost of the expedition is $20,000.00!

BUT If you are able to help me raise ¼ of my goal, $5,000.00, then I will be able to secure my place on the trip 100%.

I am hoping to get help from sponsors to fund the remaining part of the expedition costs.

There are great incentives to donate to my campaign, so I hope you do and are able to come along on this journey with me!

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Ask your friends and family to get the word out and share this campaign through email, facebook and twitter
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools
  • Become active in your local community and make the change to lives as sustainably as possible
  • Think about investing in renewable energy for your house?

Want to learn more?

Connect with me:

Twitter: morgan_petters

Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/MorganInAntartica

Website: https://morganinantartica.wordpress.com

Through my project and writing I will be able to pass on everything I have learnt to even more people outside of my local community, so that everyone has a chance to learn and feel inspired from my journey.
I think as young people we are really powerful to create change because we are passionate and believe that anything is possible.
So if you too believe that this expedition is possible, and that this is an incredible opportunity, be sure to help me reach it!
How you can help:
 
Getting to Antarctica is quite expensive as you can imagine, and I need all of the help that I can get to make my dream come true.
The total cost of the expedition is $20,000.00!
BUT If you are able to help me raise ¼ of my goal, $5,000.00, then I will be able to secure my place on the trip 100%.
I am hoping to get help from sponsors to fund the remaining part of the expedition costs.
There are great incentives to donate to my campaign, so I hope you do and are able to come along on this journey with me!
Other Ways You Can Help

Ask your friends and family to get the word out and share this campaign through email, facebook and twitter
Use the Indiegogo share tools
Become active in your local community and make the change to lives as sustainably as possible
Think about investing in renewable energy for your house?
Want to learn more?
Connect with me:
Twitter: morgan_petters
Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/MorganInAntartica
Website: https://morganinantartica.wordpress.com

story:
HELP however you can.

Ronald Pressley is a 72 year old Marine Veteran – living on social security and his only home is an RV that he paid $24,000 for about 6 years ago from a small medical settlement that he got from an injury in his last job. There was a barn fire which destroyed the barn next to his trailer, the heat completely ruined his RV. It’s amazing that it did not burst into flames as well. The skylights and AC literally melted as did the outside lights on the trailer. The roof sealant melted and ran down the sides of the RV like syrup. The slide out has rubber gaskets all around it to make it air tight, those melted. His trailer now smells absolutely horrific from the melting plastic. .

He did not have insurance on the trailer. We hope to raise enough money to buy him another RV of similar size since this is his only home. But if we can’t raise enough to buy a new RV, we need to try to at least make it safe enough for him to live in.  We are grateful that no one was hurt in this tragic event but it’s outcome has definitely been felt quite painfully.

story:
Hi. I'm Vanessa, a student of Urban and Regional Planning at the University of Iowa and a proud Filipina-American. As part of RAGBRAI, I am riding across the great state of Iowa on my bambike to raise awareness about climate change impacts on the Philippines and to fundraise for InHand Abra—an inspiring Philippine non-governmental organization (NGO) working for climate justice. 

InHand Abra provides a starting point for creating sustainable communities by teaching classes on bamboo management and production village by village, creating an inclusive pathway for bamboo weaving and furniture communities to compete in local and national bamboo market. 

$42,800 will pay for a much needed bamboo processing tank for InHand Abra. It's a steep goal, but every bit we raise here will help!

To stay updated during the ride, I have set up a Wordpress blog and will be posting daily!

What We Need & What You Get

Your donation will...

  • Directly benefit the bamboo farming community in Abra~including increased efficiency, yield, and greater profits from improved bamboo products

  • Contribute to community resilience and climate adaptation~ bamboo farmers will increase their financial security upon a natural, sustainable resource that enables them to support their families. 

  • Support a local effort to create a "green collar" local economy that lifts people as it climbs~not all efforts to create environmental economies endeavor to lift people from poverty. InHand Abra works with bamboo-based communities to make sure the green revolution leaves no one behind.

And to entice you further, every $10+ pledge will recieve a thank you letter from InHand Abra's Executive Director, Carmelita Bersalona, describing the impact the new tank has on the community along with pictures of the installation.

1 Preservation Tank: $25,000

Customs tax            + $7,000

Installation               + $5500

Transport to Abra  + $2500

Indiegogo Fees       +$2800

Total                          = $42,800

If we don't reach all of our fundraising goal, InHand Abra will use whatever is raised and put it toward purchasing other critical items, such as chainsaws or equipment for turning bamboo into charcoal.


But what is B.O.N.G.G.A?!

Well, B.O.N.G.G.A is an acronym, but you likely knew that. It stands for Bamboo On New Green Ground Ang (Ride for Climate Justice). Because, as an island nation, they are literally losing ground in the Philippines due to climate change and rising sea levels. Planing bamboo is one way to adapt to the changing tide.

It's also a play on "bongga"-- the Filipino word for fabulous, outlandish, or crazy in a good way. Which is pretty much how I feel about this ride! :)


The Impact

When Typhoon Haiyan (a.k.a. Typhoon Yolanda) hit last November, millions of Filipinos were displaced and hundreds were killed due to the strength and magnitude of the storm. That's one projected impact of climate change that the Philippines are facing~ stronger typhoons that unleash unprecedented damage to the countryside and its communities. Humanitarian efforts are important, but focus largely on sending relief to the areas damaged by these natural disasters. Funding this bamboo project is one way to directly contribute to  empowering communities to adapt and thrive in this time of changing climates.

How so, you may be asking? Well, bamboo has a rhizomatic root structure that literally grows across the underside of the soil; thus is able to hold in the soil, making it less likely to give way to rain events. Mountain communities have been experiencing deadly landslides that could be alleviated by planting bamboo along the mountainsides-- something bamboo farmers are already doing! 

I wouldn't be advocating for this if I hadn't seen these villages and talked with these farmers. Added income from bamboo production can also make a real difference for families who farm vegetables or have temporary work as construction hands. Even a small increase in weekly incomes, from selling bamboo hats or woven mats, can provide these communities with much needed safety nets from natural disasters that are only predicted to get worse.


Risks & Challenges

I hope that together we can collectively bring a real change to one small (and important!) part of the world. We might not make this funding goal, but I am going to do my best in providing pictures, links, videos, you name it, to make sure InHand Abra has a shot at getting some funding for their communities. I will be tweeting pictures from my ride, making sure that everyone is updated and plugged in during my 400+mile bicycle ride across the state of Iowa. The rest is up to you.


Other Ways You Can Help

I realize that not everyone can donate money (although every little bit helps!), I will only ask that if you are reading this you spread the word about this campaign as far and wide as possible! Tweet it, Facebook share, Indiegogo share, whatever works for you! 

Thank You~ Salamat!

story:
Without the pollinators, a vibrant, diverse, and beautiful environment is impossible!  For our sake and the health of the future of Planet Earth, we (all of humanity) must immediately deal with the issues that threaten the honey bees, butterflies, and all beneficial insects, as well as the health of the air, the soil and the water.  


So, with this in mind, The Honey Bees Project, through the media of song, video, and storytelling, offers the opportunity to experience the power of expressing gratitude as a path toward positive change.


We are seeking donations to enable the creation of a state-of-the-art music video which will be a fun and inspiring sing-along, filmed on the Garden Island of Kaua`i.  The soundtrack being featured is called “Owed To The Honey Bees” and is a happy love song to the honey bees and to all of nature.  

To hear “Owed To The Honey Bees”, and for more information about our cause, please visit our website at:    www.beebuzzz.org

Our website has payment options for your donation, including how to donate by check or money order. 


Mahalo Nui Loa for your love and support of the pollinators!

story:
Our Project

We are the Georgia Tech International Genetic Engineering Machine (iGEM) team competing in the 2014 iGEM International Jamboree, this October/November. iGEM is a synthetic biology competition where teams try to give an organism an ability that it didn’t have before which benefits both the community and the world. The competition features teams from colleges around the world and we collaborate with these groups to help each other accomplish our goals. Our team is composed of young and experienced students, passionate and ready to take on a project like this.

Our project this year is to give E. coli the ability to convert methane into methanol. Methane contamination of water is a big issue in areas where fracking activity occurs. The US Geologic Survey suggests that greater than 10 ppm of methane in water is harmful; however, greater than 50 ppm have been seen in some areas, including places in Texas and Pennsylvania. We are looking to reduce the problem of methane contamination in an effective manner to better the environment and improve the health of residents near areas where fracking exists. Your help would clean the drinking water of fracking-affected people and in conjunction with EPA could clean our air of methane and reduce greenhouse gases.

Your contributions will be used to fund our research and reach out to those who are affected by and those who are tired of the ever-changing weather. Right now, water treatment methods, such as aeration, are ineffective in removing the methane from the water. Also, these methods do not remove all the methane and can end up releasing the methane into the air. According to the EPA, “pound for pound, the comparative impact of methane on climate change is over 20 times greater than carbon dioxide over a 100-year period.” Your help will put us one step closer to our goal: to help these people live better lives in better conditions. This is not end-all-be-all solution for these people but your support can go a long way.

Additionally, the Georgia Tech iGEM team won gold for the 2013 iGEM competition last year, and we look forward to achieving the same honor this year.

What We Need & What You Get

Your contributions will go towards travel expenses to attend the iGEM Giant Jamboree competition in Boston, Massachusetts from October 30-November 3. As of now, we have only have enough funding to bring a few of our members; however, we'd love for all of our members to experience this amazing opportunity. Below is the estimated cost of the entire trip.

Estimated Costs:

Team registration fee:  $3,500

Attendance fee:  $750/person (8 people)

Flight:  $350/person (8 people)

Hotel: $200/night (4 nights, 2 rooms)

Seeing our research make a difference: Priceless

TOTAL COST: $13,900

Yikes! That's a lot of money, but luckily, team registration is paid for and the cost of food and activities will be incurred on our members.

To acknowledge your donations, any donator of and above $250 towards our project, will be given an iGEM T-shirt with our team logo on the front and your name on the back of the T-shirt listing you as a sponsor for our project. We will also wear these T-shirts to the competition sponsoring your company in front of hundreds of people from all over the world. It’s a good platform for advertising

Stretch Goals

In addition to reaching the $2,000 goal, we'd love to accomplish a few more things with the extra money.

Group dinner at the Jamboree:  $200

Allow another member to attend: $1,100

Lab materials: $800

Boston American History Tour: $320 ($40/person)

Any other additional funds will be saved for our future iGEM team!

The Impact

The success of this project would allow us to have a new system of removing methane from water using bacteria. The EPA could produce the bacteria in appreciable amounts and release it in the soil in areas where methane contamination is a problem. This project could not only improve the lives of people directly affected by methane contamination in water but also help to reduce the worldwide problem of global warming. Your assistance could get us one step closer towards our goals.

Risks & Challenges

All great projects come with their challenges but we are prepared for every obstacle. Our biggest challenge is producing the necessary components in our E. coli so that they work as intended. These parts are not currently functional in E. coli because they are native to another bacterium, Methylococcus capsulatus. With advanced computer modelling of these components, we can solve the problem effectively and efficiently when conducting our experiments with the bacteria. Another challenge further down the road is handling methane gas when testing the newly formed parts. To ensure that this will be done safely, treatments of the bacteria with methane gas will be in air-tight chambers and at levels that will not pose harm to the bacteria.  

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot give a us a monetary donation, water sample donations are very welcomed. People in fracking-affected areas can send us videos of your water lighting on fire or we will send you water sample tubes. You can fill them with your tap water and we will pay for the shipping to send it back to our lab. Please share this project to help spread the word of our project!

Thanks,

GT iGEM

story:
Heart message

Living Water brings peace into our hearts and into the world. By supporting living water activities, we get closer to world peace. 

Our story

How it started
5 years ago, a group of spiritual leaders from all around the world gathered in Istanbul.

This meeting was initiated by professor Johannes Witteveen, former managing director of the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and leader of the International Sufi Movement. He has dedicated his life to bringing loving kindness and harmony into the world; something that was equally important for the leaders who were present. This meeting was the start of a unique friendship between leaders from all kinds of religious, spiritual and indigenous traditions such as Buddhists, Sufi’s, Hindu’s, Sikhs, Muslims, Catholics, Jews, Inuit, Maasai, and Indians. 

Water for all: action is needed
These spiritual leaders agreed that we need to collaborate to tackle global issues which threaten world peace. 

The lack of clean water is one of the most urgent problems to address. Without water, life on earth would not exist. Many water resources are polluted or exhausted. Glaciers in the Himalayas and Greenland are melting. There are water shortages in India and Africa. Crops are being destroyed by flash flooding. 

Water mixing ceremony in Assisi June 2018 with Spiritual leaders from around the world. 

Our purpose
This is why Living Peace Projects was established: a foundation that puts loving kindness and compassion into action through water projects and education. We want to raise global awareness of the need to preserve our sacred water sources. 

We want to raise €50.000 to help finance our water and education projects:

  • Living Water Drops: jewels to spread the message 
  • Living Cycles: innovative sustainable sanitary buildings for developing countries
  • Children’s book on sacred water sources
  • Water for all conference, June 1st 2022, International Peace Palace, The Hague.
     

Support our projects

Below we describe the projects and how we put the donations to good use. Donors receive a special gift as a token of our gratitude.   

Living Water Drop: a jewel 
The Living Water Drop is a beautiful handmade jewel, that symbolizes the life-bringing and healing power of water. The glass waterdrop contains water mixed from 10 sacred springs, which has been harvested and blessed by the spiritual leaders. You can wear the Living Water Drop close to your heart as a token of your contribution and connection with all those who value the importance of our water sources. 

Our aim is to have 100.000 people wearing the Living Water Drop and spreading the message over the next two years. This crowdfunding exercise will finance the collection of sacred water sources, as well as the production and distribution of the Water Drops. You can pre-order the Water Drops on the Donation page. 

Living Cycles: sustainable sanitary buildings 
With support from the Technical University Delft we have designed an easy-to-build sustainable sanitary unit for developing countries. This unit provides safe and clean toilet facilities for women and girls, who otherwise often have to use the open field. The unit also includes wash-hand basins for extra hygiene, and a healthy water tap. Living Cycles also teaches children and communities how to create healthy, sustainable water supplies. 

The sanitary unit includes a rain harvesting system that collects and stores water in the rainy season, and provides clean, purified water throughout the year. For power we use solar panels, and the composting toilets provide compost to enrich the soil. It is also a micro-financed social project: local women can earn a living by maintaining the unit and keeping it clean. 

With your donations we can build the first Living Cycle unit as a pilot in India. The builders are local people. The first selected locations in India are Himachal Pradesh ,Palpung Sherabling Monastic Seat and Dharamsala.

Children’s book on sacred water sources
This is a beautifully illustrated book describing the sacred water sources. Religious, spiritual and indigenous leaders tell the story of their sacred water springs and the meaning of water in their tradition. 
We have the funds for publishing the book in English. With this crowdfunding we can finance the translation of the book into 10 languages to educate more children and raise awareness.

Water for All conference
The Water for All conference, where spiritual leaders meet scientists and business leaders, is scheduled for June 1st 2022, at the International Peace Palace in The Hague, Netherlands. There will be a special water ceremony where water from 18 sources coming from all continents will be merged. This water will be distributed in Living Water Drops and shared all over the world.

This unit provides safe and clean toilet facilities for women and girls, who otherwise often have to use the open field. The unit also includes wash-hand basins for extra hygiene, and a healthy water tap. Living Cycles also teaches children and communities how to create healthy, sustainable water supplies. The sanitary unit includes a rain harvesting system that collects and stores water in the rainy season, and provides clean, purified water throughout the year. For power we use solar panels, and the composting toilets provide compost to enrich the soil. It is also a micro-financed social project: local women can earn a living by maintaining the unit and keeping it clean. With your donations we can build the first Living Cycle unit as a pilot in India. The builders are local people. The first selected locations in India are Himachal Pradesh ,Palpung Sherabling Monastic Seat and Dharamsala.Children’s book on sacred water sourcesThis is a beautifully illustrated book describing the sacred water sources. Religious, spiritual and indigenous leaders tell the story of their sacred water springs and the meaning of water in their tradition. We have the funds for publishing the book in English. With this crowdfunding we can finance the translation of the book into 10 languages to educate more children and raise awareness.Water for All conferenceThe Water for All conference, where spiritual leaders meet scientists and business leaders, is scheduled for June 1st 2022, at the International Peace Palace in The Hague, Netherlands. There will be a special water ceremony where water from 18 sources coming from all continents will be merged. This water will be distributed in Living Water Drops and shared all over the world.

story:
Short Summary

Last year, a group of Fordham Law students launched an advocacy project for the right to water for Bedouin communities in the Negev in Israel. This year, we're continuing the work, authoring a comparative advocacy paper and several academic articles on water rights in both the West Bank and Israel. We will be exploring various aspects of the water rights issue - the international and legal framework surrounding it, the impact a lack of water has, and means of redress for individuals denied their right to water.

The project has been designed as an independent academic study at Fordham Law, and has garnered strong administrative support. We have also been working closely with several human rights organizations on the ground in Israel and Palestine, who are very excited about our work and the value-add of this unique comparative study.

What We Need & What You Get

To complement our research, we have planned a 10-day factfinding mission to the West Bank and the Negev in March. The cost of the trip is roughly $10k, of which we've already raised about $4k. Looking to raise the remaining funds through your help!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you want to make a tax deductible donation, please email us for details.
 
Whether you donate or not, please follow our progress at our blog (http://legalright2water.blogspot.com/) and spread the word about our project by passing along this campaign information!

story:
First, I would like to introduce myself. My name is Alexander Semenov, I'm a marine biologist and a professional underwater photographer and also I'm a head of the scientific divers team at the White Sea Biological Station of Lomonosov's Moscow State University, Russia. Our station was founded in 1938 and mostly it was built by enthusiasts who came here because of the amazing atmosphere that had being developed over many years at the station. This is an unusual and unique mix of students energy, serious science and the harsh northern nature.

Over the summer season, the station has more than 600 visitors: students, PhDs, scientists from different countries and volunteers, and they all leave the station happy looking forward to come back again and again. Theese people were gathered into volunteer construction teams and came to the station every year, reaching out electricity, building materials and with their own hands were building biological station from scratch. Now it is a modern scientific village at the Kindo peninsula on the border of the Arctic Circle. It's isolated settlement with no road - it is possible to get there only by boat or snowmobile in winter when the sea is covered with ice.

And all we have is almost excellent: students have their field practice, scientists investigate the sea, we dive and pick all what is necessary for scientific work from under water. But there is one little problem - it is our diving shed, where we spend most of the time, because all our equipment, tanks, air compressor are kept there. There we are changing clothes, discussing plans and preparing to dive, but the trouble is that this building - a tiny and very old barn, fourth rooted into the ground, and it is at the edge of being collapsed.

In recent years, as the imortance of scientific diving raised, necessity of diving operations increased greatly. Earlier at the station there were just a few divers who dived two or three times a week, now there is a entire team making 2-3 dives every day during 4-5 months. There is not enough space for all of us anymore.

As soon as I was appointed to lead a team of divers, I immediately began to look for an opportunity to demolish this shed, until the roof falls on divers or until they are not harmed by some huge nail, with which the barn is stitched - probably, this is the only reason why it's still stays still. After a long search and talking with various people, it became clear that in Russia funding the construction by the university - it is a sort of science fiction, and the only way to construct a building at the biological station is to find some private funds or to buy building materials and pay workers by yourself.

We found money for building materials, part of the funds raised with the help of staff and friends of the biological station, but this is not enough - the cost of materials, especially the cost of delivery of the materials to the station isolated from civilization turned out to be prohibitively high. At the moment we bought most of the lumber and laid it out to dry until the fall comes, we also paid for and received the architectural project and all calculations. Then our money ran out, and to buy all other materials we need 18 thousand dollars more, excluding shipping, shipping costs will increase it by another $2000. Doors, windows, insulation, wind and moisture protection material for the roof, paint and impregnation of wood, cement for the basement, as well as all necessary things like nails and screws - all this we need to buy as soon as funds become available.

We planned to start construction this fall, in mid-September it is the end of the field season and the weather still allows you to build something. We will have time to finish till November, because in November there comes the Polar Night that lasts six months and snow falls. If we raise money to planned time, we will succeed, and in March/April next year we will be able to start our dives in icy cold waters, working in brand new divers house, and heated with a mug of hot tea after hours in the White Sea.

If we fail gathering the whole amount, then we will buy basic materials - cement and profiled sheeting for the roof, which will allow us to build the basement and walls of timber, which is alredy purchased, and place it under a roof. This building will already be much better than our old barn. Then we will insulate and finish building it, when we raise more, maybe next year. But I hope we will succeed this fall!

That is. It is our goal, and my biggest dream.

story:
Hi Everyone! 

I'm really excited to be on the homestretch of this book. It's been an odyssey and I've learned tons in the process; things that I'm very eager to share. I strongly believe that this book brings together in a new form, many of the ideas and inspirations that have motivated us in the ecology movement over the past few decades. Most importantly, the book isn't an abstract set of ideas, but rather a "cookbook" for practicing the key ingredients of a lasting culture.

"Pfeiffer’s “Wild Earth, Wild Soul” is a recipe for realizing our greatest longing: to live in a culture rooted in the Earth where each of us is treated with love and respect. Filled with indigenous wisdom; this rich, practical offering provides a way for small groups to experience that now as well as hope for the well being of future generations."  - Thom Hartmann

All of the funds we're hoping to raise here will go toward paying editors, proofreaders and creating a website. After almost three years, and countless hours of helpful conversations with friends and colleagues, now it's time to get it to the publisher. Every contribution, no matter how small, is key to the project's success. This is about more than the book, it's about creating healthy communities, based on the successes of cultures that have come before, with new tools for healing and transformation. 

"Bill Pfeiffer has followed his own wild heart in growing ways to build an Earth-honoring culture.  His passion to heal our alienation from the natural world led him to deep ecology and then on to aboriginal elders of Siberia and the Americas.  Knowing that a shift in consciousness at the personal  level is essential, he has developed workshops to bring us back to our true nature as conscious members of the sacred living body of Earth.  It is good news for us all that Bill has chosen to share his approach and his methods in this manual.  I've known Bill for twenty years and would trust him with my life." -Joanna Macy 

No matter how you ended up here, if you find this project inspiring, please send this link to your friends and networks.

"This book was a blessing for me, both for its clear, vibrant articulation of basic principles of shamanic and ecological healing, and for its practical transmission of how to create powerful experiences for others."  -Charles Eisenstein

From my heart to your heart,

Bill Pfeiffer

story:
SUMMARY

The Sunseeker Solar Car Project is the solar car racing team at Western Michigan University. The team is comprised of students from many academic disciplines, who join together to design and build a solar powered vehicle that utilizes state of the art technology, to make the most efficient use of the available solar energy. Students have the opportunity to apply classroom knowledge to a hands-on project, utilizing teamwork to achieve a common goal. The culmination of the project is the biennial, cross-country, international, intercollegiate American Solar Challenge (ASC). The ASC is a 1,700 mile test of the efficiency, safety, and durability of the student built solar car. The team has participated in all ten American Solar Challenges, and is one of only four to have done so.


IMPACT

Sunseeker promotes the use of renewable, alternative energy and the advancement of related technologies by educating the public through the presentation and demonstration of our solar powered vehicles at schools, museums, energy fairs, car shows, parades and other special events.

WHAT WE NEED

The $25,000 will be used to fund expenses for the 2014 FSGP and ACS races. The race fees are $7,000 ($1,000 entry, $3,000 track, $3,000 road race). Additional ASC travel, food, and lodging (3 days) is expected to be $3,000 (approximately $1,000 per day for each of the eight "rayce" days & $500 each non-"rayce" day). Team uniforms (matching shirts required for racing) for 16-20 participants are estimated at $1,000.

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

Spread the word! Share our campaign with friends, family and co-workers. Like us Facebook. Follow us on Twitter!

RACE SCHEDULE

Exact locations of stage/checkpoints are still being finalized.

Mon, July 21: Start in Austin, TX with a checkpoint in Weatherford, TX

Tue, July 22: Arrive at stage stop in Norman, OK

Wed, July 23: Depart Norman, OK with a checkpoint in Wichita, KS

Thu, July 24: Arrive at stage stop in Overland Park, KS

Fri, July 25: Depart Overland Park, KS and arrive at stage stop in Omaha, NE

Sat, July 26: Depart Omaha, NE with a checkpoint in Ames, IA

Sun, July 27: Arrive at stage stop in La Crosse, WI

Mon, July 28: Finish in St. Paul/Minneapolis, MN

story:
Who are we?

We ( Leslie and Darren) are a couple of young folks who are madly in love and we have a new addition in our 5 month old son Finnegan.   We recently had to put our dog Blanca to sleep because of lung cancer and tumors caused by asbestos inhalation at our home.   

What happened?

We have been living in a rental property for the last 2 years.  We were planning on moving and buying our first home as a family next Spring.  When we found out why our dog was sick and had to put Blanca to sleep we immediately had the home tested for asbestos.   

Blanca is the white puppy we had to put to sleep

The test results came back that the asbestos levels in the tile in the furnace room are 300-400% above EPA and OSHA health standards of containing 1% asbestos.   The material is falling apart and releasing particles into the air which are then circulated into the rest of the home via our furnace.   The landlord has not fixed the issue and upon further investigation we found there is black mold in the basement as well.   The mold was caused when a sewer backed up and the landlord wouldn't even have someone come look at it for 13 days!  EEEW!

Black mold^^

Asbestos Flooring^^

Our doctor told us that our son's respiratory issues are likely from a combination of asbestos and mold being in the air in our home.  We immediately moved ourselves out of the house and started the legal process of asking the landlord to fix these issues, to let us move out and be released from our lease.   In this process it was discovered that the landlord didn't even have a rental license and has been renting the property illegally! 

We started looking for homes and by the grace of God found one that fits our family, our small budget and that allows us to move in early due to these health circumstances.  

What We Need

We were not planning on having to come up with our down payment this quickly or to have to pay for all this mold/asbestos testing etc.  Now we have to be out by 10-31-14. 

  • We are seeking help funding part of the down payment of our new home so we can escape the unhealthy environment that we are in  
  • Financial help is needed to pay for all different air sample testing for asbestos and multiple mold / sewage tests
  • If we don't meet our entire financial goal we will use the funds first for the mold/asbestos testing, legal fees and then use the remainder towards our down payment for our new home

The Impact

If we do not do the testing we will not be able to have legal grounds to go after the management company to have them pay for our son's medical expenses with any ongoing health issues.   

  • We are trying to have the management companies rental license revoked
  • We are trying to set a example in Minnesota and nationally that landlords need to have proper inspections done prior to renting properties
  • If you were renting a home or apartment you would want to know if there was asbestos or mold right?
This video talks about how little exposure to asbestos can cause health issues.  They are talking about adult exposure.  Our son's lungs have been developing in an asbestos environment.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vL20S4qGpEY 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Even if you can't help financially please keep us in your prayers that this will all get resolved and most importantly that our son does not have long term health issues from living the first 5 months of his life in an unhealthy environment
  • Share this with your friends in case they can help

Thank you so much for your kind thoughts and support as we try and get out of this house and to a more healthy home!
