story:
Project Summary

Lincoln, Illinois is a heavily traveled Route 66 community midway between St. Louis and Chicago, but few of its Route 66 attractions remain open.

To partially remedy that situation, a group of volunteers have formed the 501(c)(3) Route 66 Heritage Foundation of Logan County to help preserve county sites affiliated with the famous Mother Road.

The premiere project tackled by the group is saving the Mill restaurant, a derelict building that was once a hotspot on a portion of Route 66 that ran through Lincoln. The plan is to use the building as a tourist attraction and a Route 66 museum.

A great deal has been accomplished at The Mill – including a new roof, new and replacement windows and restoration of the downstairs floor and foundation - but there is still much to do.

What We Need & What You Get

First, a contractor must be hired to finish wiring the facility for electricity. The walls need to be insulated from the inside and the large holes and damaged floor behind the bar area downstairs and the front area upstairs need to be replaced. Knotty pine must be rehung behind the bar and drywall ceilings and an HVAC system must be installed. A small addition must be added to the back of the facility that will house a handicap restroom and handicap entrance. The cost for completing the project will be $93,900. All donations are tax-deductible.

Here's what you get from your donation level:

  • $15 Individual Donation: Includes one year membership and free tour of The Mill (transportation not provided).
  • $25 Business/Organization Donation: Includes one year membership and free tour of The Mill (transportation not provided).
  • $50 Donation: Includes free collectible Bob Waldmire Mill print, one year membership and free tour of The Mill (transportation not provided).
  • $66 Donation: Includes free collectible Bob Waldmire Mill print, 8x10 glossy photo of The Mill, one year membership and free tour of The Mill (transportation not provided).
  • $100 Donation: Includes free limited edition Save The Mill t-shirt, free collectible Bob Waldmire Mill print, one year membership and free tour of The Mill (transportation not provided).
  • $500 & Above Donation: Includes hand-made apron (like Blossum might have worn), free limited edition Save The Mill t-shirt, free collectible Bob Waldmire Mill print, one year membership and free tour of The Mill (transportation not provided).

Donations in any amount are welcome. PayPal and check-by-mail donations can be made at www.savethemill.org. We accept International Donations at all pricing levels.

The Impact

The Mill is considered a prime example of early American roadside architecture and is one of the few buildings in the area still standing from that era. 

Opening the Mill will add to the number of Route 66 visitors and increase both civic pride and economic development in this rural, central Illinois community.

In 2006, The Route 66 Heritage Foundation of Logan County was created. The foundation will attempt to use the funds raised through this campaign as matching money for any available grants. The goal for completing the renovation work is in time for the annual October celebration in 2015.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Spread the word and share the link! Let all your friends and social media friends know about this important Route 66 restoration project that has already gained international attention.
  • We also take in-kind donations, building materials and estate and flea market items (by delivery only).
  • We welcome enthusiastic volunteers
  • Memberships and updates available on our website at savethemill.org

More About The Mill

Paul Coddington of Lincoln formally opened his restaurant at the corner of Washington St. and Stringer Ave. on July 25, 1929, under the name of the Blue Mill. As a special treat that night, his manager's children dressed in Dutch costumes with wooden shoes and passed out roses to all of the patrons.

The eatery was constructed by local contractors in the shape of a small Dutch windmill with sails on the front. The building had blue trim and the continuously turning sails were decorated with lights. Waitresses, dressed in blue with white aprons, served food on plates from the Illinois China Company that were emblazoned with a “Blue Mill” design.

One of the opening day specials was fried ham with peanut butter on toast with mayonnaise and head lettuce – three high. Soon, the Blue Mill became known for serving patrons grilled sandwiches at any time of the day or night.

The small shop, which was located on Old Route 66 near the Lincoln Developmental Center, enjoyed much success for several years thereafter.

Heavily reliant on other area businesses, the establishment served meats from Eckert's Market, locally made Marcucci ice cream and soft drinks from the Chero-Cola Bottling Company in Springfield, Ill.

On Sept. 9, 1936, Raymond Hickman purchased the property, His wife, Fern, who had formerly operated a private catering service, took over supervision of the kitchen. Hickman enjoyed squirrel hunting and he liked to share his bounty with his customers. On at least one occasion in the 1930s, he was said to have served a squirrel dinner at The Mill.

In 1945, Blossom Huffman purchased The Mill, unbeknownst to her husband, Albert. He, nevertheless, ended up helping to run the establishment. The Huffmans obtained, at no cost, an old Army barracks from Fort Ellis in Ipava, IL. Fort Ellis served as a detention camp for World War II prisoners of war.

The Huffmans moved one barracks building to Lincoln and attached it to the back of the original restaurant and painted the entire building barn red. They operated the business as a restaurant, bar and dance hall, with live country bands on weekends.

Albert replaced the sails of the windmill once in 1945, and then had to do the repair job a second time after his handiwork was destroyed by a storm.

During a get-together at the Mill a few years ago, a former truck driver who delivered soda pop for the restaurant recalled Albert Huffman. "He had muscles the size of my head," the man said. "He never had to throw anyone out; he just showed them to the door."

Colorful customers at the Mill included Coonhound Johnny, a local bootlegger, and the notorious Chicago mobster Al Capone and many of his cohorts.

In the 1950s and '60s, Lincoln was plagued with illegal gambling activities centering on pinball machines, and The Mill was implicated in the illegal activities. 

One of the restaurant's claims to fame was its fried schnitzel, originally made of veal and later of pork. Louise “Mom” Rofschansky brought the original viener schnitzel recipe with her from Austria. The cook introduced the sandwich to Blossom, who Americanized it and made it a Mill specialty.

Blossom passed the recipe – and the restaurant – on to her son George and his wife, Eleanor. Next in line were George and Eleanor's son and daughter-in-law, Randy and Teresa. Blossom's great-grandson, Brian, and his wife, Cheri, use the same schnitzel recipe today at Hallie's restaurant in downtown Lincoln.

Along with the schnitzel, Blossom developed a tangy sauce that the restaurant used on the sandwiches and sold in jars for take-out. 

By the mid-1980s the Mill had lost most of the Dutch-themed interior and along with its food offered a museum of strange objects. A mechanical leg appeared to have just kicked its way through a hole in the ceiling. Additional oddities included four life-sized figures, a suit of armor and a 20-pound stuffed catfish.

There was also a “jack-in-the-box toilet” that made noise when one raised the lid. Albert once explained, "I had to keep changing things so people would come down here and see what the crazy nut was doing now."

The Mill closed in 1996, and stood deteriorating for many years, the subject of increasing neighborhood complaints about unsafe conditions. Ernie Edwards, owner of the famous Pig Hip restaurant on Route 66 in Broadwell, pleaded for the building to be saved for use as a museum, especially after his own Pig Hip Museum burned.

In 2005, The Mill was sold for taxes, but the new owner could not afford to demolish it due to costly commercial demolition regulations. A year later, then Logan County Tourism Director Geoff Ladd stepped up to work with Edwards and other supporters in an effort to save the building.

In 2006, The Route 66 Heritage Foundation of Logan County was created to promote and preserve Route 66 sites in Logan County. Working with the owner and city council members, the organization managed to save the building from the wrecking ball and gain title to the property.

Using the property as collateral, Regions Bank in Lincoln advanced a $20,000 loan, which was used to pay for the abatement and demolition of two later additions on the side and back of the building. These sections were not in salvageable condition.

This left a large, cellar-sized pit on the north side of the building, where the restaurant kitchen once stood. For two years, Contractors Ready Mix brought their leftover dry materials to The Mill and dumped them in the pit. Finally, the filled pit was topped with concrete.

An early fundraiser was the Route 66 Garage Sale, co-sponsored by the foundation and the local tourism bureau, and spearheaded by Bruce Huskins. At its peak, the sale covered 37 miles of Route 66 in Logan County and included approximately 100 vendors. An estimated 20,000 people visited the various locations in 2009.

The sale continues but due to a lack of volunteers has been taken over by another organization. An outgrowth of this activity has been the establishment of a flea market, which is held during the warmer months inside the Mill.

This year, flea markets have been scheduled for the second Saturday of the month, April through October. Fees from the rental space go to the Route 66 Heritage Foundation to continue renovation of the building.

An annual classic car cruise-in, held in conjunction with the Railsplitter Antique Auto Club with food, a dance and tours of the building started about 2006. The annual fundraiser has continued every year since that time and has included everything from reminiscences to paranormal investigations.

In July, 2007, local philanthropist Larry Van Bibber donated $15,000, which was used toward repair of the building's foundation.

The site was listed by Landmarks Illinois on their 2008 endangered attractions list, and has been frequently mentioned in print and internet articles.

The new flooring was installed by construction-savvy board members in 2008. The expense was covered by a $10,000 cost share grant from the National Park Service Route 66 Corridor Preservation Program, which was announced in August of that year. The funds also helped cover the cost of the foundation repair.

On March 22, 2008, the foundation secured a $12,000 grant from the Danner Trust, which works to encourage and aid preservation and restoration of historical locations. That money was used to replace 40+ windows in the building.

A Route 66 Roadside Attraction Sign was added to the site on April 26, 2008.

Preservationists from the Route 66 Association of Illinois used one of the decaying sails as a pattern to construct new sails, which were installed in August 2008. The sail used for the pattern was given to the Illinois Route 66 Museum, the official museum of the Mother Road, in Pontiac. The Route 66 Preservation Committee, chaired by John Weiss, held several volunteer work days at The Mill.

Route 66 icon Ernie Edwards cheered us on and volunteers included the famous Route 66 artist, Bob Waldmire.

The Mill was inducted into the Route 66 Association of Illinois' Hall of Fame on June 13, 2009.

Other donors and supporters through the years have included the City of Lincoln, County of Logan, Illinois Route 66 Scenic Byway, Lincoln Rotary, Eaton Corporation and a number of anonymous donors, members and local businesses. A wall of the future museum will be dedicated to those who have volunteered and donated funds and issued grants over the years.

Eventually we hope to have a portion of the upstairs that will contain a small military museum, filled with items on loan from the Heritage in Flight Museum in Lincoln. The downstairs portion will offer souvenirs and tourist information, as well as a chance to view local Route 66 memorabilia, including many surviving items from the Pig Hip restaurant and museum.

In 2013, an anonymous donor paid for the creation of “Made in the USA” T-shirts emblazoned with the Mill on 66 logo. The shirts have been sold at special events as well as through the foundation's website.  To purchase t-shirts or or to get more information, visit us at savethemill.org.

The Mill remains under the auspices of the private foundation, Route 66 Heritage Foundation of Logan County, a group of dedicated volunteers.

Board Members

Bob Wilmert - President

Andrea Dykman - Treasurer

Geoff Ladd - Secreatary

Barb Wilmert

John Sutton

Nancy Saul

Juanita Buttell

Courtney Crowell

Rebecca Strait

Dave Dunham

Vicki Dunham

story:
The Grateful Garden was founded in 2014 to support the local food movement with locally grown produce, home garden installation, organic garden supplies and home gardening education. It is our goal to grow vegetables and gardeners as sustainably as possible by using products that are local, renewable, post consumer or made using sustainable practices. At The Grateful Garden we consider every homegrown vegetable as a win for the Earth.  Imagine if every person were to grow just one tomato a summer how much petroleum would be saved each year shipping billions less tomatoes around the world. Better yet Imagine if they grew those tomatoes using Biochar. Sustainably created biochar is a powerfully simple tool that can 1) fight global warming; 2) produce a soil enhancer that holds carbon and makes soil more fertile; 3) reduce agricultural waste; and 4) produce clean, renewable energy. 

This campaign is important because it will help us fund the installation of biochar into our garden, raise awareness about biochar and give contributors the opportunity to fund an action day that will benefit our local economy and the environment.  As well those who can attend the Earth Day Bioblitz will learn and participate in a sustainable and fun Earth Day event while learning ways to build sustainable home gardens.

We are looking to raise $5000 dollars in order to cover the cost of 120 bags of BioChar Source which will enable us to amend six rows ( 3’w X 100’L)  equalling 1800 square feet of growing area. This $5000 includes installation of the biochar, advertising and the fee to Indie GoGo. The minimum individual donation is $35.00 to cover one bag of biochar, installation and expenses.  If we don’t raise the entire amount we will buy as many bags as we have raised funds for. 

If cash funding isn’t for you please join us at the Bioblitz to pitch in or just learn and have fun. Visit our website at www.thegratefulgarden.biz or Facebook at www.facebook.com/gardenmoreworkless

story:
On Tu b’Shevat 2013, Jewcology will conclude our Year of Learning.  In appropriate Jewish fashion, we will turn immediately from this year of learning to applying our new wisdom through action. 

Year of Action: Bal Tashchit (Do Not Destroy)

In 2013, we will organize a Year of Action, focusing on the Jewish mitzvah of Bal Tashchit (avoiding “unnecessary destruction” or “waste”).  We will focus on two key actions, both especially relevant for reducing waste in the Jewish community: reducing energy use, and avoiding food waste. 

Reducing Energy Use:

Saving energy is very important to address today’s environmental concerns, and recognized by the Talmud as a part of the mitzvah of Bal Tashchit.  Every Jewish institution can make a difference and also save money but streamlining their energy use.  This project will empower Jewish individuals and institutions to take action and model sustainable energy use.

Avoiding Food Waste:

In synagogues, in schools, at Kiddush and in our own refrigerators, the Jewish community has an opportunity to reduce the edible (or recently spoiled) food that we throw away.  

As part of our Year of Action, Canfei Nesharim’s food waste program will include a monthly blog posting encouraging individuals to take specific actions to reduce their food waste.  The posts will include tools like menu and shopping planners, instructions for how to find your local food bank, and recipes to spice up leftovers before they go bad.  

Measurable Results:

To measure the results of change, we will create and post website calculators on Jewcology to enable individuals to measure their impact and see the collective impact of their actions.  For example, people will have the opportunity to check a box indicating specific actions (such as using a smart powerstrip, changing lightbulbs, or turning down the thermostat) and will be able to see how much energy will be saved by them, and by the entire Jewcology community throughout the year. 

The calculators and their results will also be promoted to our network of change agents and to the global Jewcology community.

How You Can Help:

We are seeking to raise $7,500 to design this campaign, create interesting and engaging resources for the Year of Action, and build the calculators on the Jewcology site. Thanks to the ROI Community, all funds raised up to $7,500 will be matched dollar for dollar.  Your funds go twice as far!

Join us in supporting the Year of Action!  You'll be eligible for cool perks and become part of our superhero squad.

Keep up to date with the campaign to see how we're doing and what we'll be able to pull off next year.

About Jewcology

Jewcology is building the Jewish environmental movement through a social media portal, leadership trainings and high quality resources.  Here's what we're up to right now:

  • Hosting and leading the development of Jewcology.com, an online home for the Jewish environmental movement (launched in November 2010), which features social media tools for collaboration and a rich library of shared Jewish environmental materials for learning and teaching. 
  • Leadership Trainings: Providing leadership trainings to Jewish environmentalists. Our most recent training took place June 14.
  • Resources: Our Year of Jewish Learning on the Environment, begun on Tu b’Shevat 2012, includes more than 20 sponsoring organizations (including the Jerusalem Post, My Jewish Learning, and Torah Café) partnering with us to share a wide range of Jewish environmental teachings across the Jewish community.


Check out the site at www.jewcology.com, and stay tuned as our work develops!

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Student interns always wanted and much loved.
  • Join our blogging corps!  Commit to blogging 1-2x per month about your Jewish environmental work, and we'll give you a free ad on our site for 2 weeks. 
  • Do you have a community of Jewish and/or environmental leaders who could benefit from leadership skills? Host a Leadership Training!  

For the above opportunities, email us for more information at info@jewcology.com.

story:
Short Summary

  • My name is Joey van Wyk, Neil van Rooyen is my partner in this project. -Having a passion for the environment, uplifting communities, children, people with special needs and good old fashioned family values I decided to give up my job over 3 years ago to combine these passions with our life's experiences into a project that will be for the higher good. It's been a tough road but well worth it and was not a spur of the moment decision. For years I was getting signs and messages about these issues then spent 9 months brain storming with my business partner until we came up with this concept, only then did I resign and spent 3 years doing research 24/7, often only getting 2 / 3 hrs sleep a night. We have just launched our campaign to take our vision to reality and need all the support we can get..
  • Contributing today will help future generations, it goes far beyond us or our business, in fact...it is not about us or our campaign at all. Schools will send students to our camps to learn about the environment, what better time to instill good values. the unemployed will be shown a way to earn an income for themselves and be able to feed / clothe their families and pay for their childrens education. This will clean up the area they live in at the same time and that is a good thing while alleviating poverty. Not hundreds but thousands of peoples lives will be affected in a positive way while helping heal Mother Earth. The conference center will be used for informing companies how they can contribute to the carbon footprint by making just a few simple changes

What We Need and; What You Get

  • The first priority is to be able to purchase the property, the property we have selected is 60 hectares and in the second oldest mountain range in the world, It is therefore imperative that this farm be bought so we can begin this very important project so that is first on our list, as soon as that is done we can already begin training the unemployed, next is the organic gardens, petting zoo and picnic area, bungalows for school camps. Only once that is all done will we begin the buildings for restaurant, spa, holistic centre. $250,000 is required to begin (property, organic gardens & petting zoo), anything contributed over that will be used for the next phase as described above.
  • Careful consideration was given when deciding on the perks, for locals the options are vast, it was important to offer something of value to the international community so it was decided to offer African hand made products that are very popular with overseas visitors, Please note that they are not factory made and therefore not replicas, they are all very unique and individually made so you may not get the exact paintings we have here. Click on gallery to see pics of the perks. The great thing is that we are buying them from people that can't find work and are trying to earn an income through their craft whilst the jewelry supports the "save the Rhino" fund. Everyone that contributes will be sent a picture of the wall with your name on it. Your name will be put on our website within 24 hrs, emails and products will be sent at the end of our campaign.
  • Regardless of how much is collected through this campaign the business will be started, there is no question about that, if necessary a new campaign will be done for the next or each phase.

The Impact

  • This project will change lives in wonderful and positive ways, no doubt about it, the great thing is that something like this causes a wonderful ripple effect. Don't most people wanted to see cleaner streets and less unemployed ? How can people be expected to understand the bigger picture like our Rhinos being slaughtered if they don't understand the little things like "don't litter". Once this company is established it would be great to have franchises all over the world, naturally adapted to suit each country. 
  • In the past we were forever raising funds for those in need through organising events at no pay, it was simply a matter of "here is a need, let's do something about it". They were always a great success.
  • It was decided years ago that something like this was vital so almost a year was spent brain storming and thrashing around ideas, looking at all the issues that concerned us which is the environment, the cost of organic foods, children, holistic healing, the unemployed, family values and people with special needs as well as our wildlife and we eventually managed to fine tune all our ideas and came up with this concept that incorporates all of those things. We believe in this so strongly that 3 years ago I gave up my job to research everything full time to ensure that it was a success and that we had all the facts, it's amazing once you begin how much is discovered about green building, recycling +++++, it's been a long hard road getting here but all worth it as it is a passion and calling for us.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Please could you kindly help spread the word about this campaign, it would be much appreciated and you really will be playing a huge part in changing lives.
  • Use Indigogo share tools to make it easier

It was decided years ago that something like this was vital so almost a year was spent brain storming and thrashing around ideas, looking at all the issues that concerned us which is the environment, the cost of organic foods, children, holistic healing, the unemployed, family values and people with special needs as well as our wildlife and we eventually managed to fine tune all our ideas and came up with this concept that incorporates all of those things. We believe in this so strongly that 3 years ago I gave up my job to research everything full time to ensure that it was a success and that we had all the facts, it's amazing once you begin how much is discovered about green building, recycling +++++, it's been a long hard road getting here but all worth it as it is a passion and calling for us.



Other Ways You Can Help

Please could you kindly help spread the word about this campaign, it would be much appreciated and you really will be playing a huge part in changing lives.
Use Indigogo share tools to make it easier

story:
The Problem

There are about 750 pure, wild greenback cutthroat trout in the world, all living an extremely fragile existence in an unlikely place - Bear Creek, a small stream west of Colorado Springs, CO.  Such a small population of mature fish put them at risk of poor genetic diversity, and the creek itself is at high risk of significant damage from erosion, wildfires, and human impacts like poor trails, motorized trails, rogue campsites, and unauthorized angling.



Greenback Cutthroat Trout History

Like all of Colorado’s native cutthroat trout, greenbacks were pushed to the brink of extinction through overfishing, development and pollution as Colorado was settled and developed in the early 1900’s, leading to the presumed extinction of the species in the 1930's.  However in the late 1960’s, scientists discovered what they thought were relic populations of greenbacks.  In an attempt to repopulate the species they harvested and used these fish as the broodstock for stocking activity throughout Colorado's Front Range.  As a result, the species was downgraded from "endangered" to "threatened" status in 1978.  It was named the State Fish of Colorado in 1994.

However, over the past couple decades the identity of those re-populated “greenbacks” was called into question.  Advances in genetic testing indicated those repopulated fish were actually another species of cutthroat – the Colorado River cutthroat. 

Fortunately, samples of greenbacks and other cutthroats were collected throughout Colorado and preserved by scientists in the late 1800’s, but only until recently did the technology exist to accurately test them due to their age.  In 2010, samples of contemporary fish,  including the fish from Bear Creek (tested due to their distinct and unique physical characteristics versus other cutthroats) were tested against those historical samples.  The results yielded a roadmap to cutthroat populations throughout the state:  two species were extinct, 3 reside in other watersheds, and one genetically pure population of greenback cutthroat had persevered and reside in Bear Creek.

How the greenbacks came to live in Bear Creek is an unlikely story unto itself.  An entrepreneur owned property in the area and ventured to cash in on tourists making their way up Pikes Peak.  As part of his attractions he built a pond suitable for fishing. Since Bear Creek was historically fishless at that point he collected some fish from a nearby South Platte river tributary to stock it.  As it turned out those fish were greenback cutthroat trout, direct predecessors of the current population. 


Our Goal

Bear Creek, and its greenback residents, is at high risk of elimination due to fire and erosion.  We are raising funds for:

  • Restoring and maintaining the access road next to Bear Creek to prevent further erosion from entering the stream and damaging the habitat for its resident greenback cutthroats.
  • Proliferation of greenbacks through supporting stocking programs and the gear required for our volunteers to successfully pack fish into remote areas.
  • Seed money to leverage larger grants for in-stream restoration projects.

Through the generous donations of the fly fishing industry, the time of our 100% volunteer organization, and the support of Colorado Trout Unlimited, we have accumulated a very impressive collection of perks to help us meet our goal.  Please give as generously as you can so that we can all have a chance to feel the tug of a wild greenback cutthroat trout on the end of our lines.  Please also share this initiative with other like-minded anglers and conservationists wherever you can.  

For more information on the greenback cutthroat trout, the obstacles the species is facing, and our plans to help visit 1of750.com

- The Greenbacks

Who We Are

We are a group of young and passionate anglers that are hoping to make conservation fun and engaging while promoting and protecting cold water fisheries.  Although largely independent, we operate with the administrative support of Colorado Trout Unlimited and it's 501(c)3 non-profit status.

thegreenbacks.org

1of750.com


Huge Thank You To Our Campaign Sponsors:


                                        

   fishpondusa.com    greenfishmovement.com       tenkarausa.com           vedavoo.com


Our Perks:

Greenbacks Stickers:                                   Greenbacks Patch:  

     

fishpond Pitchfork Clippers:                         Greenbacks Hat:

      

Greenbacks Hoodie:                                    Vedavoo Hip Pack:

      

fishpond Pawnee Gear Bag:                          Vedavoo Sling Pack:

story:
Our Story

My name is Thea and I am a participant of the Youth initiative program, YIP in YtterjÃ¤rna, Sweden. Together with Clara I am going to Findhorn for an  Internship to attend a course on Permaculture, community-living, alternative currency, alternative energy, house construction, earth-healing ect .. and in order to attend this course and pay for travel expanses, we would appreciate your help to either donate a little bit of money or spread this website to someone who can..
We see that the learning, inspiration and insights we gain at Findhorn, can benefit the whole Yip and YtterjÃ¤rna community, and hopefully a lot more people further in our path.
My personal focus will be to investigate the direct relationship between the consumer and the producer, fx: the fact that all the food you eat is produced by your neighbour. I would like to investigate what this means for our way of consuming and valuing our food, if this has an impact on our relationship to and way of using money, on the relationship we have to each other and to the nature. I am already investigating this in JÃ¤rna, working with the local restaurant that only provides food from local organic and biodynamic farmers, and tries to create a direct relationship between the farmer, the cook and the consumer in the restaurant.  I would like to bring this project further, bring an angle that includes way more aspects of society and through a website ( www.feedingjarna.withtank.com) and video, let it be an inspiration that reaches over the boarders of YtterjÃ¤rna. I think Findhorn can help me get a more clear picture of how everything is interconnected and how to give the website a more global thinking as Findhorn has all aspects of society in a little community. So in order to do this I need the knowledge and I think Findhorn is the perfect place to gain this..
 Therefore, beautiful people, I kindly ask you for a small donation.. In the end hopefully it will benefit us all.


My name is Clara, I'm studying with Thea and we both hold the quite same vision of the relationship between human being and their food, Iâ€™m interested in knowing what  quality the food will bring us if we know from where does it come from and if we are being part of the process in a active way and not just consuming. I'm interested in the daily life that they have in Findhorn and how it affects and inspire people that are not part of that environment.  It is important to me to see people who are living in a sustainable way and to learn from them,  further on,  to bring it to my daily life and embody what Iâ€™ll need in order to grow in this life. I have future projects that relate a lot to this kind of approach to human being and earth. I see community life as one of the major keys for a better world.
Thank you for nay contribution and your support through the path I'm walking.

The Impact

We see so clearly how important it is to be part of this training, we can see it in our future and from calls we've been receiving in our past. We have a month for an Internship in our YIP program, which we want to spend at Findhorn, getting to know their work and their ways of living. It is so important for the continuation of our future, to realise our dreams and to practice sustainable living. And we see this as having an impact on three different levels: our selves, people around us and the world; because the way we live has a direct impact on the world as we all are interconnected.
It will therefore be fruitful for many others around us, as we hope to embody the wisdom the Findhron community holds and to make it accessible for our friends and others that might be interested. 



What We Need

http://www.findhorn.org/programmes/53/ - Ecovillage Training 2012

Our one month training costs x2: Â£3150 for participants with low income

We asked for a bursary and they gave us Â£1000 discount, now the training costs: Â£2150


We will fly, so it costs Â£159, and then local transport from Edinburgh to Forres and back it is around Â£140

We won't spend any money with accommodation or food :D (it is included in the training payment) 


We have a budget coming from our YIP payment which is Â£1860 (20 000 SEK - Swedish money)

We received Â£220 donated by Thea's brother -Thank you very, very much, Albert-

So we have: 

2150-1860-220= 70  + 159+140= Â£369


Â£369 in USD = 583!!!


Other Ways You Can Help

If you don't have any money, it would be a big help for us  if you pass it forward in your network. 

You can also send us some good energy :D

Our Story
My name is Thea and I am a participant of the Youth initiative program, 
YIP in YtterjÃ¤rna, Sweden. Together with Clara I am going to Findhorn 
for an  Internship to attend a course on Permaculture, community-living, 
alternative currency, alternative energy, house construction, earth-healing
 ect .. and in order to attend this course and pay for travel expanses, 
we would appreciate your help to either donate a little bit of money or 
spread this website to someone who can.. We see that the learning, 
inspiration and insights we gain at Findhorn, can benefit the whole Yip 
and YtterjÃ¤rna community, and hopefully a lot more people further in our 
path.My personal focus will be to investigate the direct 
relationship between the consumer and the producer, fx: the fact that all 
the food you eat is produced by your neighbour. I would like to 
investigate what this means for our way of consuming and valuing our 
food, if this has an impact on our relationship to and way of using money, on the 
relationship we have to each other and to the nature. I am already 
investigating this in JÃ¤rna, working with the local restaurant that only
 provides food from local organic and biodynamic farmers, and tries to 
create a direct relationship between the farmer, the cook and the 
consumer in the restaurant.  I would like to bring this project further, 
bring an angle that includes way more aspects of society and through a 
website ( www.feedingjarna.withtank.com) and video, let it be an inspiration that reaches over the 
boarders of YtterjÃ¤rna. I think Findhorn can help me get a more clear 
picture of how everything is interconnected and how to give the website a
 more global thinking as Findhorn has all aspects of society in a little
 community. So in order to do this I need the knowledge and I think 
Findhorn is the perfect place to gain this.. Therefore, beautiful people, I kindly ask you for a small donation.. In the end hopefully it will benefit us all.

My name is Clara, I'm studying with Thea and we both hold the quite same vision of the relationship between human being and their food, Iâ€™m interested in knowing what  quality the food will bring us if we know from where does it come from and if we are being part of the process in a active way and not just consuming. I'm interested in the daily life that they have in Findhorn and how it affects and inspire people that are not part of that environment.  It is important to me to see people who are living in a sustainable way and to learn from them,  further on,  to bring it to my daily life and embody what Iâ€™ll need in order to grow in this life. I have future projects that relate a lot to this kind of approach to human being and earth. I see community life as one of the major keys for a better world.Thank you for nay contribution and your support through the path I'm walking.

story:
I need your financial support to make what you will read below possible! Help me reach my goal by giving what you can, and join this collective effort to make what is inconnu…. connu. ( un- known… known)

My Story

Hello! My name is Melissa Lafontaine, I am a 24 year old Canadian/ American living in the vibrant city of Montreal. In just two months I will depart from my comfortable life in Montreal for the mysterious, richly bio-diverse, politically challenged and poverty stricken country of Madagascar. A country with 80% of its biodiversity seen nowhere else in the world, 'inconnu' to many. Many of you who have been a part of my life during the last several years know that I am a nature lover dedicated to environmental sustainability and community connectivity. I moved from my much missed community of Colorado Springs a year ago to learn French in Quebec with hopes to to open the door to work in the field of international development. After spending the past year translating my thoughts into broken yet now workable French sentences, volunteering for the Global Campaign for Climate Action(http://tcktcktck.org/) and filling out a slew of competitive international development volunteer applications I have *excitingly* been accepted to serve as a volunteer with the World Wildlife Funds, EXPLORE- Youth Volunteer Programme in the Midgony-Atsimo Forest Corridor in Madagascar! In addition to the conservation work I will be doing in Madagascar, I have high hopes of adding in a personalized creative project to collectively involve those who have been a part of my journey in the past, and those who will commit to support me and follow me as I am in Magnifique Madagascar via my Blog Spot at (http://lafontainewwf.blogspot.com/)

Madagascar and the WWF Explore Programme

The Moist Forests in South-Eastern Madagascar contain a very rich biodiversity, and the development of its flora and fauna is spectacular thanks to a very favorable climate. However, this is threatened by the activities of the local population whose lives depend on the forest's natural resources.

With a view towards the participatory management of forests with local communities, WWF has been implementing the Community Forestry Project in Midongy du Sud in three stages since 2003. The project is funded by the Swedish National Development Agency (SIDA). WWF’s mission is to protect, develop and restore the forest for the well-being of the local communities. WWF’s intervention sites in the Midongy du Sud region are located in the Forest Corridor between the Midongy du Sud Befotaka National Park and the Vondrozo Forest Reserve. The implementation is carried out in the framework of three main sections: 1) Forest conservation; 2) Gender approach, and 3) Development of alternatives to slash and burn cultivation (tavy).

 

The goal of the WWF volunteer programme is to provide young environmental leaders with a powerful, direct experience of the unique challenges developing nations face in protecting their environment and its assets and to share these challenges and  tangible solutions through photography, compelling stories, media and videos. WWF encourages its volunteers to share this project with otthers in hopes to INSPIRE others to support  the growth of naturally protected areas such as the Forest Corridor of Midongy and become stewards for the encouragement and practice of environmental responsibility in theireveryday lives. 

 

http://wwf.panda.org/how_you_can_help/volunteer/

The Impact

I will be working within the Forest Corridor of Midongy- Atsimo with the World Wildlife Funds Youth Volunteer Program in establishment of a new protected area and will be involved with a range of activities such as the collection of field data, consultations with local communities, and building infrastructure support. My role as a volunteer includes observation and data collection of the lemur population; contributing to the local knowledge of the importance of their protection and the role they play in stabilizing global biodiversity. I will participate in sustainable projects such as aiding the locals in the fabrication and utilization of compost, serving as an environmental educator in primary schools, and reinforcing the local community to have responsibility towards educating their youth with the environment in mind.  I will be living in remote poverty stricken areas, with some of the most under represented populations.  As I conduct these projects I will be documenting my experience through photography and upon my return will hold a photography exhibition, pairing each photograph with an environmental fact and real time story. I will also be engaging the children through providing art supplies and environmentally inspired art projects in my free time. I hope to bring back several creations from the children to display in the exhibit as well.

 

Your support

The support you will be providing me is to initially help offset the costs of travel expenses to Madagascar and the cost of living, ultimately enabling me to serve as a volunteer with no income for 3 months. The remaining support raised will be used to buy useful products for the children, women and men in the villages such as mirrors, socks, shoes, toothpaste and soap ect (whatever appears to be the biggest need).

Each supporter will be mentioned on my blog and will receive a personal e-mail update of the progress and highlights of the project. Those who give $100 or more will receive a printed photograph. Those who give $250 or more will receive 2 printed photographs, including a black and white film photo displayed at the exhibition.   

Other Ways You Can Help

Pass this Campaign along!!

Send me your creative ideas and/or Art Supplies that I can bring along with me for the children at m.lafontaine13@gmail.com. Send me e-mails of encouragement and blog posts while I am in the field. Most importantly send me your positive and contented thoughts and give me your strongest commitment to continuously become a more environmentally conscious  active individual in your corner of the world.

story:
People Concerned About Chemical Safety provides water relief for Toledo.

When the Elk River Chemical Spill hit, we didn't know how long it would last or when our water would be safe.  It was a frightening and stressful time for over 300,000 West Virginians.  Six months out from the event, our neighbors in Toledo, OH are dealing with a similar situation as an algal bloom has contaminated the drinking water supply for 500,000 people.  A Do Not Drink ban is still in place and they are uncertain of when the ban will be lifted.  Parents will have to bathe their children in bottled water, cook with bottled water, brush their teeth with bottled water...  Sadly, we know what that's like.

It's time for West Virginians to do what West Virginians do best and help our neighbors. 

People Concerned About Chemical Safety is traveling to Toledo to deliver water but WE NEED YOUR HELP!  We need to raise $1,000 to rent a van that we can fill full of bottled water. 

Won't you help?

  • $250 will help us get the van
  • $150 will help with gas
  • $600+ needed for water

If we don't reach our goal of $1,000, we'll do what we can with what we've got, but $1,000 is a drop in the bucket of what is needed for the people of Toledo.  Anything in excess will go toward on the ground relief efforts as directed by the people on the ground.

DON'T FORGET TO SHARE THIS REQUEST!

story:
Short Summary

Greetings!

My name is Rik Burns and I hail from all over this beautiful land. From the Southeast of Virginia Beach, VA to the Northwest of Ashland, OR and from the Southwest of Las Vegas to the Northeast of New York City, I have seen much and realized from early on that we are all intimately connected to each other and the Earth. I have decided to combine my passions for Nature, Sustainable Solutions, Travel, and Diversity with my experience in the Film and Television Industry by creating an exciting new web series, GREEN MACHINE TV! 

Every day I see the stakes get higher as the struggle against destructive "economic growth" and greed-driven "progress" continue to exploit OUR planet's resources and unbalance the perfectly intricate web of Nature. Fortunately, every problem we are facing has a solution. It merely requires the right information and a change of consciousness and habits. This is why the sharing of know-how and inspiration is so crucial. There also exists a lot of misinformation in our media. It is thus my mission to further educate myself and discover the facts, all while detailing the solutions I discover and incorporating them into my daily life.

Your contributions will go far! Green Machine TV is going to be the gift that keeps on giving. Once the show hits the road, it will continue investigating viable green technologies and practices and help connect communities with the green solutions they need. The van itself will be an educational tool and thus a literal vehicle for change. The website www.greenmachinetv.com has many more details and will continue to grow and become a go-to conduit for all things green.

The future is green, the future is now!


What We Need & What You Get

Our goal of raising $97,000 will allow Green Machine TV to

  • Buy the Van and cover the Conversion, Retro-fitting, etc. = $23,930
  • Purchase additional Equipment = $7,156
  • Hire a core Production Team = $52,800
  • Cover Production Costs = $9,914
  • Expand the Website ( www.greenmachinetv.com ) = $3,200
  • Produce 12 Official Episodes and loads of Bonus Material
  • And the creation of your unique, Eco-friendly, perks!

If we do not reach our entire goal, then cutbacks will be made to the scope of the production and certain equipment we will have to do without. I will personally take on more responsibilities at my own expense of monetary gain, time and effort, if needed. This is my passion after all and I will do whatever it takes (within reason of course) to make this show a reality. As the wise Joseph Campbell used to say:

                                       "FOLLOW YOUR BLISS"


Funding of Additional Episodes of Green Machine TV

We are currently considering a number of options to fund additional episodes of Green Machine TV beyond the original twelve.

Here are a few:

* Get picked up or sponsored by network/cable TV
* Have a second indiegogo fundraiser
* NO advertising but compatible business, non­profit, individual or group sponsorships
* Seduce Ted Turner or Oprah Winfrey
* Have a donation button on site
* Sell Green Machine TV related items on website and on road

Future episodes are currently estimated to cost $4,500 ­ $5,000 per episode.


The Impact

Here are just some of the ways in which GREEN MACHINE TV will generate positive change and uplift our World:

  • Green Machine TV will benefit the World by actively networking and showcasing green solutions to the ecological problems our people and planet are facing.
  • This project is valuable to each contributor as it allows you to be a crucial part of this great quest. I cannot do it without you!
  • I've been a part of many organizations like the New York Public Interest Research Group (NYPIRG), Green Peace, Working Families Party (WFP), World Wildlife Fund (WWF) and others that have successfully fought for human rights, land conservation, protection of species, effective legislation to improve education and the handling of our environment, etc. Imagine what more can be done via an immersing and entertaining, free to everyone, web-series!
  • With your help, I will tackle the tough questions surrounding the Green Movement, such as the feasibility of some technologies or the commodification of good intentions. What are the real dangers of wholesale development and growth and their degradation of our planet? What alternatives exist that don't require environmental risks? Do we really have the know-how to solve humanity's needs for healthy food, soil, water, air, energy and habitats and still properly and respectfully manage Earth's resources? What are the possible paths towards a near future where Earth, Humanity, and Our Actions exist in Harmony? How can I, Rik Burns, grow in ability and wisdom in the process? If I can do it, then what's stopping us?
  • With your help, I will better be able to improve myself from newbie apprentice to skilled tradesman of all things green and therefore be of more service to the greater community.
  • With your help, the Green Machine will roam the highways and byways of this great land providing assistance and awareness through information and
    networking of resources.
  • Together we will help bring about positive change.      
  • Join me on this exciting quest.


Other Ways You Can Help

Some of you reading this just won’t be able to contribute financially. Trust me, that's fine; I understand and I've been there myself! But that doesn’t mean I couldn’t use your help:

  • Please help me make some noise about this campaign and get the word out in any way you can.
  • You can utilize the Indiegogo share tools for your convenience!

Thank you all for taking the time to check out my campaign. Your support, in any form, is greatly needed and appreciated.

Much love and respect,

-Rik Burns-

story:
Al Fatiha Global is committed to helping humaity, with atrocities and humanitarian crisises increasing globally, we have an ethos to not only restore humanity but to also bring happiness and peace to those who desperately need it through the implementation of our projects, delivering food packages, viral medication and medical resources and helping schools/children re-build their lives.

We work tirelessly to ensure your donations reach those in need. We all have a 'hands on' approach to personally deliver the aid when possible, we actively work together towards a better future for everyone.

We view this mission as an obligation upon us to help those whose circumstances have left them in a vulnerable position and we endeavour to fulfil our promises to the best of our abilities, God willing.. 


If would like to claim an extra 25% from your donation via gift aid please email us on giftaid@alfatihaglobal.com for a gift aid form.

We all have a 'hands on' approach to personally deliver the aid when possible, we actively work together towards a better future for everyone.We view this mission as an obligation upon us to help those whose circumstances have left them in a vulnerable position and we endeavour to fulfil our promises to the best of our abilities, God willing.. If would like to claim an extra 25% from your donation via gift aid please email us on giftaid@alfatihaglobal.com for a gift aid form.

story:
Salmon is Life, a Seattle-based delegation of artists and organizers, will take a school of 350 illuminated batik salmon windsocks held aloft on bamboo poles to “swim” through the streets of Paris during the UN Climate talks (COP21) in December 2015. Your help is needed!

Standing for the salmon is standing for nature. Wild salmon indicate healthy forests and streams. When waterways can no longer support salmon, nature’s ability to continue supporting any life there is also at risk. People all over the world are already suffering the terrible consequences of climate chaos, but together we can turn this around.

Salmon swim upstream seemingly against all odds to ensure future generations, and so must we. People from around the world will carry 350 artist-made salmon windsocks outside the international climate conference, visually speaking for people and species who have no voice. When the large school of fish moves as one, the performance will symbolize the power of people working together to protect what we love.

We are not fighting for nature.

 We are nature defending itself.

                                         - Climate Games


Salmon as a Climate Delegation

This project expresses our desire to inspire the awakening of the heart and reverence for our natural world through beauty. We believe creative expression calls to our deeper connections with nature and each other.

We’ve learned from doing artful activism and collaborating with other grassroots groups that pictures have an immediate impact and move people without the use of language. Images that are beautiful and hopeful inspire people to take positive action.

As much as this project is about making salmon illuminate the streets of Paris, it is also about making connections with and between people who are inspired to act on behalf of the natural world that sustains all life. Moving 350 salmon will require the coordination of 150- 175 people moving together, and the collaboration of even more (including YOU!).  

People from all over the world will be at the UN Climate Summit, and so will the media. We want to create images that will remind all of us that the beauty of the natural world comes with a responsibility to care for living beings. 


Why 350?

The number 350 is significant -- 350 parts per million (ppm) of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere is the point above which the thin atmosphere covering Earth and keeping temperatures relatively stable, starts trapping too much solar heat. This causes global warming which results in changes in weather patterns, droughts, floods, melting ice, rising seas, wildfires, and super storms.

We are currently above 400 ppm and by continuing to burn oil, coal, and gas at the present rate, we are adding 2 ppm of CO2 into the atmosphere every year. "Unless we are able to rapidly turn that around and return to below 350 ppm this century, we risk triggering tipping points and irreversible impacts that could send climate change spinning truly beyond our control.” ~ Dr. James Hansen, former head of the Goddard Institute for Space Studies.


Our Budget 

Our costs (in US Dollars) cover materials and travel, lodging, and food for our team of three. All of the labor is donated.  We are grateful to all of the people who are batiking, painting, and sewing the salmon and providing other assistance to make this vision a reality! 

Supplies:

Silk for 350 salmon                      $1,400

Fabric paint                                         $150

Soy wax and wax sticks                  $250

Lights and batteries                         $650

Tubing (for mouth)                           $100

Paper stock for handbills                $150

Rod for attaching lights                 Upcycled lumber strapping (free!)

Cord for tying to poles                    Donated

150  8' bamboo poles                      $400

Shipping and supplies for perks  $500

PA system                                           $300

Total supplies                           $3,900 USD.

For our core team of three:

Airfare                                                 $3000

Food                                                        $500

Lodging                                                $1000

Ground transportation                     $400

Total travel for three                $4900

TOTAL:                                        $8,800

Stretch Goals

If we are able to raise additional funds or reduce our costs by connecting with individuals and/or groups providing lodging, food, and/or transportation, we would like to bring additional crew members up to a total of five. Estimated cost: $1, 500 per person for airfare, lodging, food, and ground transportation. 

We'd like to pay our documentation team an honorarium of $500. 

Our Perks 

All of our perks are hand-made and designed by local Northwest artists. 


The Salmon Booklet 

At the $10 level, we'll send you a PDF file to be printed on one piece of standard-sized paper. Follow the instructions and you will make yourself a four-page booklet of salmon inspiration to share with others.  The booklet was inspired by reading the excellent book King of Fish: the Thousand Year Run of Salmon written by geologist Dr. David Montgomery, King of Fish: the Thousand Year Run of Salmon. Quotes from his book are included with David's permission.  The booklet also includes 2 images by the Ketchikan artist, Ray Troll, with Ray's permission. http://www.trollart.com.

The Hard Copy Booklet 

At the $25 level, we'll send you a printed version of the digital salmon book. It’s easily folded from a single sheet of paper. They are fun and it will make us happy to send you fish tales in the mail.

Smile Cards are included in all perks at the $25 and above. Smile Cards are a fun way to pay forward random acts of kindness. They are produced for your enjoyment by helpothers.org. Thank you for the kindness you are passing forward to us.


Prayer Flag

At the $50 level, we'll send you one individual prayer flag, as well as all the perks above. We've traditionally produced these for other public events to help increase awareness and citizen participation in causes affecting our communities. 


String of Prayer Flags

At the $100 dollar level, you receive all the previous perks and a string of 5 prayer flags with varied designs. (Two of the designs are shown here.) 


One Wind-Sockeye Salmon

At the $150 dollar level, we will send you a salmon that illuminated the streets of Paris on behalf of the people and the planet. (LED included, but no pole.) If you'd like, please send a prayer or wish for what you love and want to protect. We’ll write your prayer on your salmon so your message will be illuminated in the streets.


Three Wind-Sockeye Salmon

At the $400 dollar level, we will send you three salmon that have illuminated the streets of Paris on behalf of the people and the planet. If you'd like, please send a prayer or wish for each of your fish, so your message will be illuminated in the streets of Paris.


A School of Salmon

At the $1200 dollar level, we will send you your own school of salmon.  A set of 12 hand-made, silk-batik wind Sockeye salmon that have traveled to Paris (shipped after event). Perfect for environmental organizations or places of learning or worship that want to use them for actions, performances, and celebrations.  If you'd like, please send a prayer or wish for each of your fish, so your message will be illuminated in the streets of Paris.


Other Ways You Can Help

1) Spread the word!! 

Share our project and this campaign. Join us on Facebook: SalmonIsLife, share our web site: SalmonisLife.org, and help us connect to people who believe in the power of respect for nature and want to live in a world where salmon thrive. 

2) Collaborate with us! 

We are continuing to build our international network and are still seeking people and organizations in Paris to collaborate with. 

  • Friends in Paris to help dance the salmon on 12/12/15 and the week leading up to it. (Dancers and people with movement training seem to be naturals at making the salmon swim elegantly. If you're a dancer or part of a troupe or movement collective that wants to join us, let’s talk!)
  • Friends who can help us navigate French language and culture.

If you know of any organizations, dance collectives, churches, or community groups that would like to be involved, we'd love to connect with you. 

3) Educate!!

Most importantly, educate yourself on climate change and talk to folks. Find things you can do, large or small, individually or collectively, to help address climate change. We have no other planet. We must find ways to express our collective voice and demand world leaders preserve the one earth we have here now.  


Our Team Members:

We are a collective of artists and community organizers who work with 350 Seattle and allied groups to support each other in making the world a better place. We have a long track record of success engaging the community in art-making for social good. 

Good things happen when people come together. In the words of Maya Angelou, "Life is not measured by the number of breaths we take, but by the moments that take our breath away." We believe celebration art -as a form of protest, action, and collective communication- has the potential to awaken the heart and inspire people to take positive actions.


Our Traveling Crew

Paul Cheoketen Wagner is an internationally performing presenter of traditional songs and stories of his Coast Salish tribal ancestors. Cheoketen is a member of the Saanich tribe of South Western Vancouver Island British Columbia. He is an award-winning Native-American flutist. His songs have come to him with visions of healing and prayer for all our relations; the Tree people, the Animal people, and the Human people. Che oke ten has shared the stage with some of Seattle's and Japan's greats such as Eyvind Kang, Seattle Symphony Orchestra and Kitaro.

Lisa Marcus is co-founder of 350 Seattle, and the 350 Seattle Artful Activism Facilitator. She has been running public art builds and coordinating large imagery and banner design, creation, and implementation for almost all 350 Seattle events since its founding, as well as for other organizations and broad coalitions, including most of the Shell No! imagery for both land and water. She has coordinated large and powerful climate awareness related ensembles in the Fremont Solstice Parade for years. She led a team in New York for the People's Climate March last year where she mobilized Backbone Campaign's beautiful large props, and created banners and more on the People's Climate Train and in the busy art space on site in NY with anyone who wanted to help. She finds this work energizing and fun, and loves connecting with people while creating and displaying beautiful evocative imagery to invite more and more people to open their hearts, find their power, and join the climate justice movement.

Denise Henrikson has been making and teaching celebration art and coordinating community arts events for over twenty years. She fell in love with salmon when she saw Sockeye spawning in the Cedar River in 2001 and has been experimenting with making different styles of illuminated salmon puppets ever since.  Denise was one of the early instigators of Seattle’s Fremont Summer Solstice Parade and was on the team that was awarded Neighborhood Matching Funds to build the Fremont Troll. ArtsAGlow, a lantern festival Denise launched in 2007, recently received the Spotlight Award for Best Arts and Cultural programming by Washington Recreation & Park Association (WRPA). During the ShellNo! Campaign in Seattle, Denise coordinated the World Environment Day Luminary Flotilla with the Backbone Campaign and was inspired to make a school of salmon windSockeye that has continued to grow.  

Other Team Members:

Patrick Mazza is a veteran activist-journalist who has worked for a sustainable future since the 1980s.  He has placed primary focus on climate change since the late 1990s, working on solutions ranging from renewable energy and electrified transportation to sustainable forestry and agriculture. Patrick serves as co-facilitator of 350 Seattle's Sustainable Solutions Working Group. 

Barb Turner: Barb has brought her organizing, writing, coaching and art-making skills to help the salmon see Paris. 

Heather Elder: A local graphic artist, Heather applies her extraordinary skills and insights in print media and marketing to help make many worthwhile projects a reality.  See more of Heather's art and illustration at: http://www.leadfeatherstudio.com .


Our deep appreciation to all the people who have been helping us on this project and have helped make salmon in communities from Lopez Island, WA to Cave Junction, OR including: Lars, Lida, Susan, Lauren, Barb, Sue, Carl, Jen, Kate, Regent, Martha, Sandy, Kitty, Debra, Deborah, Lea, Susannah, Serina, Cecile, Anne, Maureen, Maggie, Beth, Roxy, Gloria, Annah, Robin, Wendy, Kara, Diane, Bea, Chris, Marnie, Sommer, Jon, Angela, Den, Cecile, Nicole, Catherine, Gail, Gunnel, Jim, Ray, Joannah, Jane, Margie, Cindy, Eddie, and many others.

We believe good things happen when people come together with love and compassion. In the words of Mary Oliver, “I tell you this  to break your heart, by which I mean only  that it break open and never close again  to the rest of the world.”

Thank You!! 

Thank you for your time and interest in this campaign!!
